{{Summary |opClass=leapmotionTOP_Class |opLabel=Leap Motion |opFamily=TOP |opLicense=Non-Commercial |opType=leapmotion |opFilter=False |long=The Leap Motion TOP gets the image from the [[Leap Motion]] controller's cameras. To enable this feature the option '''Allow Images''' must be turned on in the Leap Motion Control Panel. ==== Licensing for Leap Motion ==== TouchDesigner does not include a license to use the Leap Motion hardware or software. Make sure to check with the [https://www.ultraleap.com/ UltraLeap website] regarding any applicable licenses that you may need for your project. ==== Installation ==== As of TouchDesigner 2022, the Leap Motion library files are no longer included with the TouchDesigner installer. These files, along with the drivers, are available from the UltraLeap website here: https://developer.leapmotion.com/releases * API Version 5 Gemini - Download Gemini v5.6.1 * API Version 4 Orion - Download Orion Beta v4.1.0 * API Version 2 Tracking - Download Orion Beta v3.2.1 Depending on your operating system, there are different instructions for installing the library: '''On Windows:''' You can use the Library Folder parameter to point to the location of the LeapC.dll (Orion/Gemini) or Leap.dll (Version 2/3) files on your system. The file is installed as part of the LeapSDK and the location may vary depending on the version and options selected during installation. '''On MacOS:''' Requires legacy Mac driver available [https://developer.leapmotion.com/releases/mac-2-3-1 here]. The libLeap.dylib file must be copied into a folder where TouchDesigner can find it (the Library folder parameter is not available on MacOS). The file is available in the LeapSDK/lib folder of the driver package downloaded from UltraLeap. The file can be copied into usr/local/lib so that it is available to all copies of TouchDesigner on the system, or it can be copied into the frameworks folder inside the package contents of a particular TouchDesigner app i.e. TouchDesigner.app/contents/frameworks. See also [[Leap Motion]], [[Leap Motion CHOP]] |short=The Leap Motion TOP gets the image from the Leap Motion Controller's cameras. |opCategories= }} {{ParameterPage |pageSummary= |pageName=LeapMotion |opFamily=TOP |items= {{Parameter|parSummary=If set, this TOP will capture data from the cameras. |opFamily=TOP |opType=leapmotion |parOrder=0 |parLabel=Active |parName=active |parType=Toggle |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|parName=api |parItems= {{ParameterItem|itemName=default |opFamily=TOP |parName=v2 |itemLabel=Version 2 Tracking |itemSummary=Legacy tracking that includes gesture and tool tracking. Download [https://developer.leapmotion.com/releases Leap Motion Orion Beta 3.2.1] }}{{ParameterItem|itemName=on |opFamily=TOP |parName=v4 |itemLabel=Orion (v4) / Gemini (v5) |itemSummary=Orion offers more stable and reliable hand and finger tracking compared to v2. Download [https://developer.leapmotion.com/releases Orion 4.1.0]. Gemini offers even better performance with improved stability and much faster hand recognition to start tracking. Download [https://developer.leapmotion.com/tracking-software-download/ Gemini 5.6.1]. }} |parOrder=1 |parLabel=API |opFamily=TOP |opType=leapmotion |parSummary=Select between Leap Motion V2 or V4/V5 SDKs for tracking. V5 offers the fastest and most stable tracking, V2 offers some legacy features like gestures. |parType=Menu |parReadOnly= }} {{Parameter|parName=libfolder |parOrder=0 |parLabel=Library Folder |opFamily=TOP |opType=leapmotion |parSummary=This parameter should point to the location of the library file (.dll on Windows) that corresponds to the selected API version. The dll file can be found in the driver kit downloaded from the Ultra Leap website inside the 'LeapSDK/lib/x64' folder. For V2, the file will be called 'Leap.dll' and for V4/5, it is called 'LeapC.dll'. '''Note:''' This is only applicable for Windows, on MacOS follow the instructions in the '''Installation''' section above for copying the libLeap.dylib file. For Gemini V5, first install the tracking software, then set this parameter to C:\Program Files\Ultraleap\LeapSDK\lib\x64 where it will find the LeapC.dll file. |parType=Folder |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|parOrder=1 |opFamily=TOP |parItems= |parName=camera |opType=leapmotion |parLabel=Camera |parSummary=Select between the two cameras in the Leap Motion Controller. |parType=StrMenu |parReadOnly= }} {{Parameter|parSummary=Flips the image in X. |opFamily=TOP |opType=leapmotion |parOrder=2 |parLabel=Flip X |parName=flipx |parType=Toggle |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|parSummary=Flips the image in Y. |opFamily=TOP |opType=leapmotion |parOrder=3 |parLabel=Flip Y |parName=flipy |parType=Toggle |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|parSummary=Corrects the image for lens distortion. |opFamily=TOP |opType=leapmotion |parOrder=4 |parLabel=Image Correction |parName=correction |parType=Toggle |parReadOnly= |parItems=}} {{Parameter|parOrder=5 |opFamily=TOP |parItems= {{ParameterItem|opFamily=TOP |parName=hmd |itemName=default |itemSummary= |itemLabel=Default }}{{ParameterItem|opFamily=TOP |parName=hmd |itemName=on |itemSummary= |itemLabel=On }}{{ParameterItem|opFamily=TOP |parName=hmd |itemName=off |itemSummary= |itemLabel=Off }} |parName=hmd |opType=leapmotion |parLabel=HMD Mode |parSummary=Switches the device to '''H'''ead '''M'''ounted '''D'''isplay mode. |parType=Menu |parReadOnly= }} }} {{:TOP Generator Common Page }} {{InfoCHOPChannels |opFamily=TOP |opLabel=Leap Motion |infoChannels=}} {{History }} {{TOPNavBox |opFamily=TOP }} {{#invoke:Category |list|TOPs}}

{{Summary |opClass=moviefileinTOP_Class |opLabel=Movie File In |opFamily=TOP |opLicense=Non-Commercial |opType=moviefilein |opFilter=False |long=The Movie File In TOP loads movies, still images, or a sequence of still images into TOPs. It will read images in .jpg, .gif, .tif, or .bmp format. It will read movies in QuickTime's .mov format, .mp4, .mpg, .mpeg, .avi, .wmv, .dpx, [[GoPro Cineform|Cineform]] and [[Hap]] Q formats (including Hap Q with Alpha). It also supports the [[NotchLC]] codec, [[EXR]] files (.exr) and some .swf and .flv Flash files as well as DXT1/3/5 and RG compressed .dds files. Images and movies can also be fetched from the web by using http:// to specify a URL. Access the hardware decoder on Nvidia GPUs with the Hardware Decode parameter on the 'Tune' page. This supports 10 and 12-bit H264/H265s and YUV 444 files on supporting hardware, converted into 16-bit pixel channels. Other codecs that this also decodes include VP8, VP9, JPEG, AV1, VC1. More information [https://developer.nvidia.com/video-encode-and-decode-gpu-support-matrix-new here.] When reading file formats that support higher bit depths such as 10-bit/16-bit/32-bit, an appropriate pixel format will be automatically used as long as the 'Pixel Format' menu on the Common page is left as 'Use Input'. i.e. a 16-bit file will cause each pixel to have 16-bits per color channel automatically. For a complete list, see [[File Types]]. Examine the state of a Movie File In TOP by attaching an [[Info CHOP]] to it (see below on Info CHOP). This will show info like movie length, resolution, the number of images per second (the sample_rate channel), and whether there is audio in the file. It also shows dynamic information like movie open status, current frame, readahead frames and queue size, dropped frame count, CPU decode time and GPU upload time. Note that a movie's "images per second" (sample_rate) may be different than the timeline's frames per second. When referring to the movie's "index", it's in reference to the sequence of images in the movie file, not related to the global project frame rate. See also the page on Movie File In TOP optimizations [[Movie Playback]], plus [[Hap]], [[Movie File Out TOP]] and [[GoPro Cineform|Cineform]]. |short=The Movie File In TOP loads movies, still images, or a sequence of still images into TOPs. |opCategories= }} {{ParameterPage |pageSummary= |pageName=Play |opFamily=TOP |items={{Parameter |parSummary=The path and name of the image or movie file to load. Image and movie formats are those found in [[File Types]]. You can specify files on the internet using http:// ... To treat a folder of images as if they are one movie, specify the folder containing the images instead of a filename. All the files must be the same resolution. It will treat all stills/movies in that folder as if each is a frame in one movie. The order of the images is the alphanumeric. By default the first image has an index of 0, second is 1, etc, regardless of their file names. Overriding the sample rate on the Trim parameter page will let you playback the image sequence at any frame rate. Using an info.xml file in the directory containing a sequence of images allows you to specify the frames per second and an audio file to be used with the sequence of images. Example xml file: URLs can be used to fetch images and movies. The image or movie is downloaded to the user's Derivative temp directory and is read into the Movie File In TOP. |opFamily=TOP |opType=moviefilein |parOrder=0 |parLabel=File |parName=file |parType=File |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter |parSummary=Change from 0 to 1 to force the image to reload, useful when the file changes or did not exist at first. |opFamily=TOP |opType=moviefilein |parOrder=1 |parLabel=Reload |parName=reload |parType=Toggle |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter |parSummary=Instantly reloads the file. |opFamily=TOP |opType=moviefilein |parOrder=2 |parLabel=Reload Pulse |parName=reloadpulse |parType=Pulse |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter |parOrder=3 |opFamily=TOP |parItems={{ParameterItem |opFamily=TOP |parName=playmode |itemName=locked |itemSummary=This mode locks the movie position to the timeline. Scrubbing or jumping in the timeline will change the movie position accordingly. The parameters Play, Reset, Speed, and Index are disabled in this mode since the timeline is directly tied to movie position. |itemLabel=Locked to Timeline }}{{ParameterItem |opFamily=TOP |parName=playmode |itemName=specify |itemSummary=This mode allows the user to specify a particular position in the movie using the Index parameter below. Use this mode for random access to any location in the movie. |itemLabel=Specify Index }}{{ParameterItem |opFamily=TOP |parName=playmode |itemName=sequential |itemSummary=This mode continually plays regardless of the timeline position (the Index parameter is disabled). Reset and Speed parameters below are enabled to allow some control. |itemLabel=Sequential }} |parName=playmode |opType=moviefilein |parLabel=Play Mode |parSummary=Specifies the method used to play the movie, there are 3 options. |parType=Menu |parReadOnly= }} {{Parameter |parSummary=Movie plays when 1, movie stops when 0. |opFamily=TOP |opType=moviefilein |parOrder=4 |parLabel=Play |parName=play |parType=Toggle |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter |parSummary=This is a speed multiplier which only works when Play Mode is ''Sequential''. A value of 1 is the default playback speed. A value of 2 is double speed, 0.5 is half speed and so on. Negative values will play the movie backwards. |opFamily=TOP |opType=moviefilein |parOrder=5 |parLabel=Speed |parName=speed |parType=Float |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter |parSummary=Jumps to Cue Point when set to 1. Only available when Play Mode is Sequential. |opFamily=TOP |opType=moviefilein |parOrder=6 |parLabel=Cue |parName=cue |parType=Toggle |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter |parSummary=Instantly jumps to the Cue Point position in the movie. |opFamily=TOP |opType=moviefilein |parOrder=7 |parLabel=Cue Pulse |parName=cuepulse |parType=Pulse |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter |parSummary=Set any index in the movie as a point to jump to. |opFamily=TOP |opType=moviefilein |parOrder=8 |parLabel=Cue Point |parName=cuepoint |parType=Float |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter |parOrder=9 |opFamily=TOP |parItems={{ParameterItem |opFamily=TOP |parName=cuepointunit |itemLabel=I |itemName=indices |itemSummary= }}{{ParameterItem |opFamily=TOP |parName=cuepointunit |itemLabel=F |itemName=frames |itemSummary= }}{{ParameterItem |opFamily=TOP |parName=cuepointunit |itemLabel=S |itemName=seconds |itemSummary= }}{{ParameterItem |opFamily=TOP |parName=cuepointunit |itemLabel=% |itemName=fraction |itemSummary= }} |parName=cuepointunit |opType=moviefilein |parLabel=Cue Point Unit |parSummary=Select the units for this parameter from Index, Frames, Seconds, and Fraction (percentage). |parType=Menu |parReadOnly= }} {{Parameter |parOrder=10 |opFamily=TOP |parItems={{ParameterItem |opFamily=TOP |parName=cuebehavior |itemName=repeat |itemSummary=When releasing the Cue parameter, immediately play the next frame. |itemLabel=On Release, Repeat Cued Frame }}{{ParameterItem |opFamily=TOP |parName=cuebehavior |itemName=play |itemSummary=When releasing the Cue parameter, first play the cued frame before continuing to play the next frame. |itemLabel=On Release, Play Next Frame }} |parName=cuebehavior |opType=moviefilein |parLabel=Cue Behavior |parSummary=Customize the Cue parameter's behavior. |parType=Menu |parReadOnly= }} {{Parameter |parSummary=This parameter explicitly sets the movie position when Play Mode is set to Specify Index. The units menu on the right lets you specify the index in the following units: Index, Frames, Seconds, and Fraction (percentage). For example, assume you have a movie that internally is 25 fps, and the timeline that is 60 fps. If you set Units to Index and the parameter value to 25, you get the image that is 1 second into the movie. If you set the Units to Frames and set the value to 60 you get the same image at 1 second into the movie. |opFamily=TOP |opType=moviefilein |parOrder=11 |parLabel=Index |parName=index |parType=Float |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter |parOrder=12 |opFamily=TOP |parItems={{ParameterItem |opFamily=TOP |parName=indexunit |itemLabel=I |itemName=indices |itemSummary= }}{{ParameterItem |opFamily=TOP |parName=indexunit |itemLabel=F |itemName=frames |itemSummary= }}{{ParameterItem |opFamily=TOP |parName=indexunit |itemLabel=S |itemName=seconds |itemSummary= }}{{ParameterItem |opFamily=TOP |parName=indexunit |itemLabel=% |itemName=fraction |itemSummary= }} |parName=indexunit |opType=moviefilein |parLabel=Index Unit |parSummary=Select the units for this parameter from Index, Frames, Seconds, and Fraction (percentage). |parType=Menu |parReadOnly= }} {{Parameter |parSummary=Crossfades the beginning and end of the movie together to create a smooth transition when looping. If the movie uses Trim options, it will crossfade Trim Start with Trim End positions. |opFamily=TOP |opType=moviefilein |parOrder=13 |parLabel=Loop Crossfade |parName=loopcrossfade |parType=Float |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter |parOrder=14 |opFamily=TOP |parItems={{ParameterItem |opFamily=TOP |parName=loopcrossfadeunit |itemLabel=I |itemName=indices |itemSummary= }}{{ParameterItem |opFamily=TOP |parName=loopcrossfadeunit |itemLabel=F |itemName=frames |itemSummary= }}{{ParameterItem |opFamily=TOP |parName=loopcrossfadeunit |itemLabel=S |itemName=seconds |itemSummary= }}{{ParameterItem |opFamily=TOP |parName=loopcrossfadeunit |itemLabel=% |itemName=fraction |itemSummary= }} |parName=loopcrossfadeunit |opType=moviefilein |parLabel=Loop Crossfade Unit |parSummary=Select the units for this parameter from Index, Frames, Seconds, and Fraction (percentage). |parType=Menu |parReadOnly= }} {{Parameter |parSummary=Sets how many frames to skip before displaying next frame. For example, a StepSize of 30 will display every 30th frame. This timing of movie playback does not change, so with a Step Size of 30 and a sample rate of 30, a new frame will be displayed every second. |opFamily=TOP |opType=moviefilein |parOrder=15 |parLabel=Step Size |parName=stepsize |parType=Int |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter |parOrder=16 |opFamily=TOP |parItems={{ParameterItem |opFamily=TOP |parName=audioloop |itemName=silence |itemSummary=Audio will go silent when movie ends. |itemLabel=Silence }}{{ParameterItem |opFamily=TOP |parName=audioloop |itemName=fade |itemSummary=Audio will fade out when movie ends. |itemLabel=Fade }}{{ParameterItem |opFamily=TOP |parName=audioloop |itemName=match |itemSummary= |itemLabel=Match Start to End }} |parName=audioloop |opType=moviefilein |parLabel=Audio Loop |parSummary=This menu helps you determine how to treat the audio as the end of a movie approaches. This is needed because of all the cases of playing a movie, like when driving with an index, the TOP will not know if you intend to loop it or not. |parType=Menu |parReadOnly= }} {{Parameter |parOrder=17 |opFamily=TOP |parItems={{ParameterItem |opFamily=TOP |parName=imageindexing |itemName=zero |itemSummary=Index the sequence of images starting at 0, after sorting them alphanumerically. |itemLabel=Zero Based }}{{ParameterItem |opFamily=TOP |parName=imageindexing |itemName=filename |itemSummary= Index the sequence of images using the numbers on the end of the filenames. I.e a file named flower400.tiff will be frame index 400, regardless of if there are other files in the directory before it. |itemLabel=Filename Based }} |parName=imageindexing |opType=moviefilein |parLabel=Image Sequence Indexing |parSummary=Determines how an image sequence is ordered. |parType=Menu |parReadOnly= }} }} {{ParameterPage |pageSummary= |pageName=Image |opFamily=TOP |items={{Parameter |parSummary=Interpolates between frames based based on exact time. For example, if the index (in frames) is 1.5, then frames 1 and 2 will be blended 50-50. If the index is 1.7 then 30% of frame 1 is blended with 70% of frame 2 and so on. |opFamily=TOP |opType=moviefilein |parOrder=0 |parLabel=Interpolate Frames |parName=interp |parType=Toggle |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter |parOrder=1 |opFamily=TOP |parItems={{ParameterItem |opFamily=TOP |parName=deinterlace |itemName=off |itemSummary=Output the movie images unchanged. |itemLabel=Off }}{{ParameterItem |opFamily=TOP |parName=deinterlace |itemName=even |itemSummary=Take only the even scanlines of the file's images and create the odd scanlines by interpolating between the even scanlines. (For historic reasons, scanline 0 is at the top of the images for the purpose of the deinterlacing.) |itemLabel=Even }}{{ParameterItem |opFamily=TOP |parName=deinterlace |itemName=odd |itemSummary= |itemLabel=Odd }}{{ParameterItem |opFamily=TOP |parName=deinterlace |itemName=bob |itemSummary= |itemLabel=Bob (Split) }} |parName=deinterlace |opType=moviefilein |parLabel=Deinterlace |parSummary=For movies that are stored as fields, where each image is made of two images interleaved together. A 30-frame per second movie would contain 60 fields per second. For each image, the even scanlines of the first field are interleaved with the odd scanlines of the second field. The Movie File In TOP has several ways of dealing with this: |parType=Menu |parReadOnly= }} {{Parameter |parOrder=2 |opFamily=TOP |parItems={{ParameterItem |opFamily=TOP |parName=precedence |itemName=even |itemSummary=When the disk files are fragmented. The Movie File In TOP will read frames of the movie into memory before they are used, this can eliminate pops or stutters in playback that occur from fragmented files, other resources accessing the hard drive, or movie looping. |itemLabel=Even }}{{ParameterItem |opFamily=TOP |parName=precedence |itemName=odd |itemSummary= |itemLabel=Odd }} |parName=precedence |opType=moviefilein |parLabel=Field Precedence |parSummary=Where fields are extracted one field at a time, this will extract the Even field first by default, otehrwise it will extract the odd field first. The video industry has not standardized on one or the other. |parType=Menu |parReadOnly= }} {{Parameter |parSummary=If enabled, the image/movie will have it's height halved, and the R channel from the pixels on the bottom half will be treated as if they were the alpha channel for the top half. Useful for cases where the image format does not support alpha natively. |opFamily=TOP |opType=moviefilein |parOrder=3 |parLabel=Bottom Half is Alpha (AAA) |parName=bottomhalfalpha |parType=Toggle |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter |parOrder=4 |opFamily=TOP |parItems={{ParameterItem |opFamily=TOP |parName=multalpha |itemName=off |itemSummary= |itemLabel=Off }}{{ParameterItem |opFamily=TOP |parName=multalpha |itemName=on |itemSummary= |itemLabel=On }}{{ParameterItem |opFamily=TOP |parName=multalpha |itemName=automatic |itemSummary= |itemLabel=Automatic }} |parName=multalpha |opType=moviefilein |parLabel=Multiply RGB by Alpha |parSummary=Premultiplies the image. |parType=Menu |parReadOnly= }} {{Parameter |parSummary=If the input image is 8-bit and [[sRGB]] color space, enable this to have treated as such. |opFamily=TOP |opType=moviefilein |parOrder=5 |parLabel=Input is sRGB |parName=inputsrgb |parType=Toggle |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter |parOrder=6 |opFamily=TOP |parItems={{ParameterItem |opFamily=TOP |parName=loadingerrorimage |itemName=coloredbottomright |itemSummary=Show a colored square in the bottom right. Red means failed to load, grey means still loading. |itemLabel=Colored Bottom Right Square }}{{ParameterItem |opFamily=TOP |parName=loadingerrorimage |itemName=zero |itemSummary=Show a blank frame. |itemLabel=Zero }} |parName=loadingerrorimage |opType=moviefilein |parLabel=Loading/Error Image |parSummary=When the file can not be loaded for some reason, select what to display instead. |parType=Menu |parReadOnly= }} }} {{ParameterPage |pageSummary= |pageName=Trim |opFamily=TOP |items={{Parameter |parSummary=Enables the parameters below to set trim in and out points. |opFamily=TOP |opType=moviefilein |parOrder=0 |parLabel=Trim |parName=trim |parType=Toggle |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter |parSummary=Trim the starting point of the movie. |opFamily=TOP |opType=moviefilein |parOrder=1 |parLabel=Trim Start |parName=tstart |parType=Float |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter |parOrder=2 |opFamily=TOP |parItems={{ParameterItem |opFamily=TOP |parName=tstartunit |itemLabel=I |itemName=indices |itemSummary= }}{{ParameterItem |opFamily=TOP |parName=tstartunit |itemLabel=F |itemName=frames |itemSummary= }}{{ParameterItem |opFamily=TOP |parName=tstartunit |itemLabel=S |itemName=seconds |itemSummary= }}{{ParameterItem |opFamily=TOP |parName=tstartunit |itemLabel=% |itemName=fraction |itemSummary= }} |parName=tstartunit |opType=moviefilein |parLabel=Trim Start Unit |parSummary=Select the units for this parameter from Index, Frames, Seconds, and Fraction (percentage). |parType=Menu |parReadOnly= }} {{Parameter |parSummary=Trim the ending point of the movie. |opFamily=TOP |opType=moviefilein |parOrder=3 |parLabel=Trim End |parName=tend |parType=Float |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter |parOrder=4 |opFamily=TOP |parItems={{ParameterItem |opFamily=TOP |parName=tendunit |itemLabel=I |itemName=indices |itemSummary= }}{{ParameterItem |opFamily=TOP |parName=tendunit |itemLabel=F |itemName=frames |itemSummary= }}{{ParameterItem |opFamily=TOP |parName=tendunit |itemLabel=S |itemName=seconds |itemSummary= }}{{ParameterItem |opFamily=TOP |parName=tendunit |itemLabel=% |itemName=fraction |itemSummary= }} |parName=tendunit |opType=moviefilein |parLabel=Trim End Unit |parSummary=Select the units for this parameter from Index, Frames, Seconds, and Fraction (percentage). |parType=Menu |parReadOnly= }} {{Parameter |parOrder=5 |opFamily=TOP |parItems={{ParameterItem |opFamily=TOP |parName=textendleft |itemName=hold |itemSummary=Displays the first frame in the movie range (the frame specified by Trim Start) for any position before Trim Start. |itemLabel=Hold }}{{ParameterItem |opFamily=TOP |parName=textendleft |itemName=cycle |itemSummary=Loops the movie range continuously. |itemLabel=Cycle }}{{ParameterItem |opFamily=TOP |parName=textendleft |itemName=mirror |itemSummary=Loops the movie range in a zig-zag pattern. For example, playing backwards from Trim Start the movie will index will climb towards Trim End, at which point is will decend down towards Trim Start again and continue to zig-zag (or mirror) the further the movie plays backwards. |itemLabel=Mirror }}{{ParameterItem |opFamily=TOP |parName=textendleft |itemName=black |itemSummary=Displays black frame for any movie position before Trim Start. |itemLabel=Black }}{{ParameterItem |opFamily=TOP |parName=textendleft |itemName=zero |itemSummary= |itemLabel=Zero }} |parName=textendleft |opType=moviefilein |parLabel=Extend Left |parSummary=Determines how the Movie File In TOP handles movie positions that lie before the Trim Start position. For example, if Trim Start is set to 1, and the movie's current index is -10, the Extend Left menu determines how the movie position is calculated. |parType=Menu |parReadOnly= }} {{Parameter |parOrder=6 |opFamily=TOP |parItems={{ParameterItem |opFamily=TOP |parName=textendright |itemName=hold |itemSummary=Displays the last frame in the movie range (the frame specified by Trim End) for any position after Trim End. |itemLabel=Hold }}{{ParameterItem |opFamily=TOP |parName=textendright |itemName=cycle |itemSummary=Loops the movie range continuously. |itemLabel=Cycle }}{{ParameterItem |opFamily=TOP |parName=textendright |itemName=mirror |itemSummary=Loops the movie range in a zig-zag pattern. For example, playing forwards from Trim End the movie will index will start decending towards Trim Start, at which point is will start climbing towards Trim End and continue to zig-zag (or mirror) the further the movie plays. |itemLabel=Mirror }}{{ParameterItem |opFamily=TOP |parName=textendright |itemName=black |itemSummary=Displays black frame for any movie position after Trim End. |itemLabel=Black }}{{ParameterItem |opFamily=TOP |parName=textendright |itemName=zero |itemSummary= |itemLabel=Zero }} |parName=textendright |opType=moviefilein |parLabel=Extend Right |parSummary=Determines how the Movie File In TOP handles movie positions that lie after the Trim End position. For example, if Trim End is set to 20, and the movie's current index is 25, the Extend Right menu determines how the movie position is calculated. |parType=Menu |parReadOnly= }} {{Parameter |parSummary=Turn On to change the sample rate of the movie. When loading an image sequence, use these parameters to set the playback speed for the sequence. |opFamily=TOP |opType=moviefilein |parOrder=7 |parLabel=Override Sample Rate |parName=overridesample |parType=Toggle |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter |parSummary=Set the sample rate for playback when 'Override Sample Rate' above is On. |opFamily=TOP |opType=moviefilein |parOrder=8 |parLabel=Sample Rate |parName=samplerate |parType=Float |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} }} {{ParameterPage |pageSummary= |pageName=Tune |opFamily=TOP |items={{Parameter |parSummary=Sets how many video frames TouchDesigner reads ahead and stores in memory. The Movie File In TOP will read and decode frames of the movie into CPU memory before they are used, this can eliminate pops or stutters in playback that occur from some frames taking too long to decode, other resources accessing the hard drive, or movie looping. When reading a sequence of image, having more Pre Read Frames will allow multiple images to be decode at the same time. This allows playback of heavy file formats such as .exr in real-time, assuming the machine has enough CPU cores. |opFamily=TOP |opType=moviefilein |parOrder=0 |parLabel=Pre-Read Frames |parName=prereadframes |parType=Int |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter |parSummary=The time (in milliseconds) TouchDesigner will wait for a frame from the hard drive before giving up. If the Disk Read Timeout time is reached, that frame is simply skipped. This also works for network files that are downloaded via http://. |opFamily=TOP |opType=moviefilein |parOrder=1 |parLabel=Frame Read Timeout |parName=frametimeout |parType=Int |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter |opFamily=TOP |opType=moviefileinTOP |parLabel=Frame Timeout Strategy |parName=frametimeoutstrat |parType=Menu |parReadOnly= |parOrder=2 |parSummary=When on, if the Disk Read Timeout is reached TouchDesigner will use the latest available frame in place of the skipped frame. |parItems={{ParameterItem |opFamily=TOP |parName=frametimeoutstrat |itemLabel=Keep Frame |itemName=keep |itemSummary=Keep showing the same frame that is currently being output. }}{{ParameterItem |opFamily=TOP |parName=frametimeoutstrat |itemLabel=Best for Playback |itemName=playback |itemSummary=Try to pick the best frame for playback. This may be a newer frame that what is shown, but not quite the frame that is requested. }}{{ParameterItem |opFamily=TOP |parName=frametimeoutstrat |itemLabel=Best for Seeking |itemName=seeking |itemSummary=Try to show any frame, either before or after the target frame. Good for when seeking the movie via a shuttle widget in a UI. }} }} {{Parameter |parSummary=If this parameter is turned on, then for the first loaded frame the Frame Read Timeout will be ignored, and it will always wait for the first frame to ensure the node always starts up with a valid image. |opFamily=TOP |opType=moviefilein |parOrder=3 |parLabel=Always Load Initial Frame |parName=alwaysloadinitial |parType=Toggle |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter |parSummary=The time (in milliseconds) TouchDesigner will wait for a movie to open. If the Disk Open Timout is reached, the Movie File In TOP will stop waiting and make its image all black, with a grey square in the bottom right corner. If the file still isn't opened the next time the TOP cooks, it'll wait again, and do the same. It'll keep doing this until the file is opened, or the open fails. |opFamily=TOP |opType=moviefilein |parOrder=4 |parLabel=File Open Timeout |parName=opentimeout |parType=Int |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter |parSummary=When on, if the Disk Read Timeout is reached TouchDesigner will use the latest available frame in place of the skipped frame. |opFamily=TOP |opType=moviefilein |parOrder=4 |parLabel=On Timeout, use Latest Avail |parName=uselatestontimeout |parType=Menu |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter |parSummary=When enabled, this will use OpenGL features to upload movie images to the GPU asynchronously. This will reduce the cook time of the Movie File In TOP considerably (in the performance monitor the lines that say "Uploading Image to GPU" will go down to almost nothing). There is a GPU memory cost to using this feature however. It uses up another (Width * Height * 4 * Read Ahead Size) bytes of GPU memory. If you are having poor results with this feature, make sure your graphics drivers are up to date. |opFamily=TOP |opType=moviefilein |parOrder=5 |parLabel=Async Upload to GPU |parName=asyncupload |parType=Toggle |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter |parSummary=Image will not update when set to 0. Movie index will continue to move forward but the output image will not update. This is useful when you are using a Movie Audio CHOP to get audio from the movie, but you don't care about the video. |opFamily=TOP |opType=moviefilein |parOrder=6 |parLabel=Update Image |parName=updateimage |parType=Toggle |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter |parSummary=Limit the maximum number of CPUs that will be used to decode certain video codecs that are capable of multi-CPU decoding, such as H264/H265 and Cineform. Note that this does not affect multi-threaded decoding for image sequence playback, which is instead controlled by increasing the Pre-Read Frame parameter. |opFamily=TOP |opType=moviefilein |parOrder=7 |parLabel=Max Decode CPUs |parName=maxdecodecpus |parType=Int |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter |parSummary=This option should be used when playing back files that require very high SSD read speeds such as high resolution (4K+) HAP Q files. It greatly improves read performance in those cases. It should not be used for low resolution or low data rate files such as 1080p H264 files. This mode uses what is known as unbuffered reading, which reads directly from the disk into CPU memory owned by TouchDesigner, bypassing a cached memory area owned by the OS. When this option is on, ever read from the file will access the drive. When this option is off it's possible a previous read to the disk may be still reside in the cached memory owned by the OS, and avoid the disk access. |opFamily=TOP |opType=moviefilein |parOrder=8 |parLabel=High Performance Read |parName=highperfread |parType=Toggle |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter |parSummary=When doing high performance reads, this parameter controls the size of the read operations that are done on disk. Whatever the largest operation the codec asks to be done, this is multiplied by the read factor and all subsequent reads will read that much data instead. This can result in higher throughput depending on the drives. For example if a request is made to read 1MB and the factor is set to 3, then instead the operations will read 3MB from the disk and the extra 2MB read will be ready for the next frame and will likely already have the next 2 frames available in CPU RAM. |opFamily=TOP |opType=moviefilein |parOrder=9 |parLabel=High Performance Read Factor |parName=highperfreadfactor |parType=Float |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter |opFamily=TOP |opType=moviefileinTOP |parLabel=Hardware Decode |parName=hwdecode |parType=Toggle |parReadOnly= |parOrder=10 |parSummary=Controls if this node should use hardware decoding via the Nvidia hardware decoder chip. You can check if hardware decoding is being used using the Info CHOP, 'hardware_decode' channel. This parameter does nothing for Hap and NotchLC codecs, which are always hardware decoded. |parItems= }} }} [[Category:OP Help Common Pages]]{{:TOP Generator Common Page}} {{InfoCHOPChannels |opFamily=TOP |opLabel=Movie File In |infoChannels= {{InfoChannel| chanName=index| chanSummary=The current frame index being shown. This is in the FPS of the movie file, not in timeline frames. }}{{InfoChannel| chanName=true_index| chanSummary=When the movie has a Trim applied to it, this will show the actually frame index within the movie being shown. }}{{InfoChannel| chanName=index_fraction| chanSummary=Normalized index value going from 0-1 from start to the end of the movie. }}{{InfoChannel| chanName=file_resx| chanSummary=The width of the movie in pixels. }}{{InfoChannel| chanName=file_resy| chanSummary=The height of the movie in pixels. }}{{InfoChannel| chanName=start| chanSummary=Unused currently. }}{{InfoChannel |chanName=length |chanSummary=The length of the movie, in movie frames. }}{{InfoChannel |chanName=sample_rate |chanSummary=The FPS of the movie. }}{{InfoChannel |chanName=last_index_uploaded |chanSummary=The last movie frame uploaded to the GPU. }}{{InfoChannel |chanName=mv_has_audio |chanSummary=1 if the movie has an audio track, 0 if not. }}{{InfoChannel |chanName=preloading |chanSummary=1 if the movie is currently preloading via the preload() Python method. }}{{InfoChannel |chanName=odd_field |chanSummary=When deinterlacing using Bob (split), 1 means the odd field is being shown, 0 means the even field is being shown. }}{{InfoChannel |chanName=last_frame |chanSummary=1 if the last frame of the movie is currently being shown, 0 if not. Note that if a frame is dropped the last frame may never get shown, if the movie is looping. }}{{InfoChannel |chanName=loop_frame |chanSummary=1 if the movie has just looped. }}{{InfoChannel |chanName=pre_read_misses |chanSummary=Counts how many times the node wanted to show a frame, but that frame wasn't already ready in the Pre-Read Cache. }}{{InfoChannel |chanName=last_pre_read_miss_wait |chanSummary=The amount of time the node last waited for a pre_read_misses frame to be read, in milliseconds. }}{{InfoChannel |chanName=hard_drive_timeouts |chanSummary=The number of times the node gave up reading a frame due to it not reading fast enough. The amount of time it will wait is controlled by the 'Frame Read Timeout' parameter. }}{{InfoChannel |chanName=num_pre_read_frames |chanSummary=The number of frames that have been pre-read, decoded, and are ready to be shown. }}{{InfoChannel |chanName=first_index_to_read |chanSummary=The frame index of the first index in the Pre-Read cache. }}{{InfoChannel |chanName=last_frame_hd_read_time |chanSummary=The amount of time spent reading the last frame from the hard-drive, in milliseconds. }}{{InfoChannel |chanName=last_frame_decode_time |chanSummary=The amount of time spent decoding/decompression the last frame on the CPU, in milliseconds. This does not account for time spent decoding on the GPU for codecs such as NotchLC, or Hardware Decoded codecs. }}{{InfoChannel |chanName=open |chanSummary=1 if the movie's file is open. }}{{InfoChannel |chanName=opening |chanSummary=1 if the movie's file is in the process of opening, but not open yet. }}{{InfoChannel |chanName=open_failed |chanSummary=1 if opening the movie failed. }}{{InfoChannel |chanName=fully_pre_read |chanSummary=1 if the Pre-Read Cache of the movie is filled with already decoded frames. }}{{InfoChannel |chanName=true_length |chanSummary=The true length of the movie, ignoring any trimming. }}{{InfoChannel |chanName=hardware_yuv_to_rgb |chanSummary=1 if the YUV format the movie was encoded in is being converted to RGB on the GPU. }}{{InfoChannel |chanName=has_non_av_track |chanSummary=1 if the movie file has a track that is not video or audio, such as a subtitle track. }}{{InfoChannel |chanName=pre_read_fails |chanSummary=The number of times pre-reading a frame failed. }}{{InfoChannel |chanName=disk_read_mbit_rate |chanSummary=The amount of data being read per second off of the hard drive, in mega-bits. }}{{InfoChannel |chanName=has_decode_errors |chanSummary=1 if the file is suffering from decode errors. }}{{InfoChannel |chanName=num_decode_chunks |chanSummary=For Hap codecs, how many chunks the file was encoded as. }}{{InfoChannel |chanName=hardrware_decode |chanSummary=If the Hardware Decode parameter is on, this will be 1 if the GPU is able to hardware decode the movie's codec. }}}} {{History }} {{TOPNavBox |opFamily=TOP }} {{#invoke:Category|list|TOPs}}

{{Summary |opClass=moviefileinTOP_Class |opLabel=Movie File In |opFamily=TOP |opLicense=Non-Commercial |opType=moviefilein |opFilter=False |long=The Movie File In TOP loads movies, still images, or a sequence of still images into TOPs. It will read images in .jpg, .gif, .tif, or .bmp format. It will read movies in QuickTime's .mov format, .mp4, .mpg, .mpeg, .avi, .wmv, .dpx, [[GoPro Cineform|Cineform]] and [[Hap]] Q formats (including Hap Q with Alpha). It also supports the [[NotchLC]] codec, [[EXR]] files (.exr) and some .swf and .flv Flash files as well as DXT1/3/5 and RG compressed .dds files. Images and movies can also be fetched from the web by using http:// to specify a URL. Access the hardware decoder on Nvidia GPUs with the Hardware Decode parameter on the 'Tune' page. This supports 10 and 12-bit H264/H265s and YUV 444 files on supporting hardware, converted into 16-bit pixel channels. Other codecs that this also decodes include VP8, VP9, JPEG, AV1, VC1. More information [https://developer.nvidia.com/video-encode-and-decode-gpu-support-matrix-new here.] When reading file formats that support higher bit depths such as 10-bit/16-bit/32-bit, an appropriate pixel format will be automatically used as long as the 'Pixel Format' menu on the Common page is left as 'Use Input'. i.e. a 16-bit file will cause each pixel to have 16-bits per color channel automatically. For a complete list, see [[File Types]]. Examine the state of a Movie File In TOP by attaching an [[Info CHOP]] to it (see below on Info CHOP). This will show info like movie length, resolution, the number of images per second (the sample_rate channel), and whether there is audio in the file. It also shows dynamic information like movie open status, current frame, readahead frames and queue size, dropped frame count, CPU decode time and GPU upload time. Note that a movie's "images per second" (sample_rate) may be different than the timeline's frames per second. When referring to the movie's "index", it's in reference to the sequence of images in the movie file, not related to the global project frame rate. See also the page on Movie File In TOP optimizations [[Movie Playback]], plus [[Hap]], [[Movie File Out TOP]] and [[GoPro Cineform|Cineform]]. |short=The Movie File In TOP loads movies, still images, or a sequence of still images into TOPs. |opCategories= }} {{ParameterPage |pageSummary= |pageName=Play |opFamily=TOP |items={{Parameter |parSummary=The path and name of the image or movie file to load. Image and movie formats are those found in [[File Types]]. You can specify files on the internet using http:// ... To treat a folder of images as if they are one movie, specify the folder containing the images instead of a filename. All the files must be the same resolution. It will treat all stills/movies in that folder as if each is a frame in one movie. The order of the images is the alphanumeric. By default the first image has an index of 0, second is 1, etc, regardless of their file names. Overriding the sample rate on the Trim parameter page will let you playback the image sequence at any frame rate. Using an info.xml file in the directory containing a sequence of images allows you to specify the frames per second and an audio file to be used with the sequence of images. Example xml file: URLs can be used to fetch images and movies. The image or movie is downloaded to the user's Derivative temp directory and is read into the Movie File In TOP. |opFamily=TOP |opType=moviefilein |parOrder=0 |parLabel=File |parName=file |parType=File |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter |parSummary=Change from 0 to 1 to force the image to reload, useful when the file changes or did not exist at first. |opFamily=TOP |opType=moviefilein |parOrder=1 |parLabel=Reload |parName=reload |parType=Toggle |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter |parSummary=Instantly reloads the file. |opFamily=TOP |opType=moviefilein |parOrder=2 |parLabel=Reload Pulse |parName=reloadpulse |parType=Pulse |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter |parOrder=3 |opFamily=TOP |parItems={{ParameterItem |opFamily=TOP |parName=playmode |itemName=locked |itemSummary=This mode locks the movie position to the timeline. Scrubbing or jumping in the timeline will change the movie position accordingly. The parameters Play, Reset, Speed, and Index are disabled in this mode since the timeline is directly tied to movie position. |itemLabel=Locked to Timeline }}{{ParameterItem |opFamily=TOP |parName=playmode |itemName=specify |itemSummary=This mode allows the user to specify a particular position in the movie using the Index parameter below. Use this mode for random access to any location in the movie. |itemLabel=Specify Index }}{{ParameterItem |opFamily=TOP |parName=playmode |itemName=sequential |itemSummary=This mode continually plays regardless of the timeline position (the Index parameter is disabled). Reset and Speed parameters below are enabled to allow some control. |itemLabel=Sequential }}{{ParameterItem |opFamily=TOP |parName=playmode |itemName=timecodeop |itemSummary=This mode allows the user to set the movie index by reference to a timecode in the form of either a CHOP, DAT, or [[Timecode Class]] object. |itemLabel=Timecode Object/CHOP/DAT }} |parName=playmode |opType=moviefilein |parLabel=Play Mode |parSummary=Specifies the method used to play the movie, there are 3 options. |parType=Menu |parReadOnly= }} {{Parameter |parSummary=Movie plays when 1, movie stops when 0. |opFamily=TOP |opType=moviefilein |parOrder=4 |parLabel=Play |parName=play |parType=Toggle |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter |parSummary=This is a speed multiplier which only works when Play Mode is ''Sequential''. A value of 1 is the default playback speed. A value of 2 is double speed, 0.5 is half speed and so on. Negative values will play the movie backwards. |opFamily=TOP |opType=moviefilein |parOrder=5 |parLabel=Speed |parName=speed |parType=Float |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter |parSummary=Jumps to Cue Point when set to 1. Only available when Play Mode is Sequential. |opFamily=TOP |opType=moviefilein |parOrder=6 |parLabel=Cue |parName=cue |parType=Toggle |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter |parSummary=Instantly jumps to the Cue Point position in the movie. |opFamily=TOP |opType=moviefilein |parOrder=7 |parLabel=Cue Pulse |parName=cuepulse |parType=Pulse |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter |parSummary=Set any index in the movie as a point to jump to. |opFamily=TOP |opType=moviefilein |parOrder=8 |parLabel=Cue Point |parName=cuepoint |parType=Float |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter |parOrder=9 |opFamily=TOP |parItems={{ParameterItem |opFamily=TOP |parName=cuepointunit |itemLabel=I |itemName=indices |itemSummary= }}{{ParameterItem |opFamily=TOP |parName=cuepointunit |itemLabel=F |itemName=frames |itemSummary= }}{{ParameterItem |opFamily=TOP |parName=cuepointunit |itemLabel=S |itemName=seconds |itemSummary= }}{{ParameterItem |opFamily=TOP |parName=cuepointunit |itemLabel=% |itemName=fraction |itemSummary= }} |parName=cuepointunit |opType=moviefilein |parLabel=Cue Point Unit |parSummary=Select the units for this parameter from Index, Frames, Seconds, and Fraction (percentage). |parType=Menu |parReadOnly= }} {{Parameter |parOrder=10 |opFamily=TOP |parItems={{ParameterItem |opFamily=TOP |parName=cuebehavior |itemName=repeat |itemSummary=When releasing the Cue parameter, immediately play the next frame. |itemLabel=On Release, Repeat Cued Frame }}{{ParameterItem |opFamily=TOP |parName=cuebehavior |itemName=play |itemSummary=When releasing the Cue parameter, first play the cued frame before continuing to play the next frame. |itemLabel=On Release, Play Next Frame }} |parName=cuebehavior |opType=moviefilein |parLabel=Cue Behavior |parSummary=Customize the Cue parameter's behavior. |parType=Menu |parReadOnly= }} {{Parameter |parSummary=This parameter explicitly sets the movie position when Play Mode is set to Specify Index. The units menu on the right lets you specify the index in the following units: Index, Frames, Seconds, and Fraction (percentage). For example, assume you have a movie that internally is 25 fps, and the timeline that is 60 fps. If you set Units to Index and the parameter value to 25, you get the image that is 1 second into the movie. If you set the Units to Frames and set the value to 60 you get the same image at 1 second into the movie. |opFamily=TOP |opType=moviefilein |parOrder=11 |parLabel=Index |parName=index |parType=Float |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter |parOrder=12 |opFamily=TOP |parItems={{ParameterItem |opFamily=TOP |parName=indexunit |itemLabel=I |itemName=indices |itemSummary= }}{{ParameterItem |opFamily=TOP |parName=indexunit |itemLabel=F |itemName=frames |itemSummary= }}{{ParameterItem |opFamily=TOP |parName=indexunit |itemLabel=S |itemName=seconds |itemSummary= }}{{ParameterItem |opFamily=TOP |parName=indexunit |itemLabel=% |itemName=fraction |itemSummary= }} |parName=indexunit |opType=moviefilein |parLabel=Index Unit |parSummary=Select the units for this parameter from Index, Frames, Seconds, and Fraction (percentage). |parType=Menu |parReadOnly= }} {{Parameter |parSummary=Crossfades the beginning and end of the movie together to create a smooth transition when looping. If the movie uses Trim options, it will crossfade Trim Start with Trim End positions. |opFamily=TOP |opType=moviefilein |parOrder=13 |parLabel=Loop Crossfade |parName=loopcrossfade |parType=Float |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter |parOrder=14 |opFamily=TOP |parItems={{ParameterItem |opFamily=TOP |parName=loopcrossfadeunit |itemLabel=I |itemName=indices |itemSummary= }}{{ParameterItem |opFamily=TOP |parName=loopcrossfadeunit |itemLabel=F |itemName=frames |itemSummary= }}{{ParameterItem |opFamily=TOP |parName=loopcrossfadeunit |itemLabel=S |itemName=seconds |itemSummary= }}{{ParameterItem |opFamily=TOP |parName=loopcrossfadeunit |itemLabel=% |itemName=fraction |itemSummary= }} |parName=loopcrossfadeunit |opType=moviefilein |parLabel=Loop Crossfade Unit |parSummary=Select the units for this parameter from Index, Frames, Seconds, and Fraction (percentage). |parType=Menu |parReadOnly= }} {{Parameter |parSummary=Sets how many frames to skip before displaying next frame. For example, a StepSize of 30 will display every 30th frame. This timing of movie playback does not change, so with a Step Size of 30 and a sample rate of 30, a new frame will be displayed every second. |opFamily=TOP |opType=moviefilein |parOrder=15 |parLabel=Step Size |parName=stepsize |parType=Int |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter |parOrder=16 |opFamily=TOP |parItems={{ParameterItem |opFamily=TOP |parName=audioloop |itemName=silence |itemSummary=Audio will go silent when movie ends. |itemLabel=Silence }}{{ParameterItem |opFamily=TOP |parName=audioloop |itemName=fade |itemSummary=Audio will fade out when movie ends. |itemLabel=Fade }}{{ParameterItem |opFamily=TOP |parName=audioloop |itemName=match |itemSummary= |itemLabel=Match Start to End }} |parName=audioloop |opType=moviefilein |parLabel=Audio Loop |parSummary=This menu helps you determine how to treat the audio as the end of a movie approaches. This is needed because of all the cases of playing a movie, like when driving with an index, the TOP will not know if you intend to loop it or not. |parType=Menu |parReadOnly= }} {{Parameter |parOrder=17 |opFamily=TOP |parItems={{ParameterItem |opFamily=TOP |parName=imageindexing |itemName=zero |itemSummary=Index the sequence of images starting at 0, after sorting them alphanumerically. |itemLabel=Zero Based }}{{ParameterItem |opFamily=TOP |parName=imageindexing |itemName=filename |itemSummary= Index the sequence of images using the numbers on the end of the filenames. I.e a file named flower400.tiff will be frame index 400, regardless of if there are other files in the directory before it. |itemLabel=Filename Based }} |parName=imageindexing |opType=moviefilein |parLabel=Image Sequence Indexing |parSummary=Determines how an image sequence is ordered. |parType=Menu |parReadOnly= }}{{Parameter |opFamily=TOP |opType=moviefilein |parLabel=Timecode Object/CHOP/DAT |parName=timecodeop |parType=Str |parReadOnly= |parOrder=1 |parSummary=Set the movie index with a reference to a timecode. Should be a reference to either a CHOP with channels 'hour', 'second', 'minute', 'frame', a DAT with a timecode string in its first cell, or a [[Timecode Class]] object. |parItems= }} }} {{ParameterPage |pageSummary= |pageName=Image |opFamily=TOP |items={{Parameter |parSummary=Interpolates between frames based based on exact time. For example, if the index (in frames) is 1.5, then frames 1 and 2 will be blended 50-50. If the index is 1.7 then 30% of frame 1 is blended with 70% of frame 2 and so on. |opFamily=TOP |opType=moviefilein |parOrder=0 |parLabel=Interpolate Frames |parName=interp |parType=Toggle |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter |parOrder=1 |opFamily=TOP |parItems={{ParameterItem |opFamily=TOP |parName=deinterlace |itemName=off |itemSummary=Output the movie images unchanged. |itemLabel=Off }}{{ParameterItem |opFamily=TOP |parName=deinterlace |itemName=even |itemSummary=Take only the even scanlines of the file's images and create the odd scanlines by interpolating between the even scanlines. (For historic reasons, scanline 0 is at the top of the images for the purpose of the deinterlacing.) |itemLabel=Even }}{{ParameterItem |opFamily=TOP |parName=deinterlace |itemName=odd |itemSummary= |itemLabel=Odd }}{{ParameterItem |opFamily=TOP |parName=deinterlace |itemName=bob |itemSummary= |itemLabel=Bob (Split) }} |parName=deinterlace |opType=moviefilein |parLabel=Deinterlace |parSummary=For movies that are stored as fields, where each image is made of two images interleaved together. A 30-frame per second movie would contain 60 fields per second. For each image, the even scanlines of the first field are interleaved with the odd scanlines of the second field. The Movie File In TOP has several ways of dealing with this: |parType=Menu |parReadOnly= }} {{Parameter |parOrder=2 |opFamily=TOP |parItems={{ParameterItem |opFamily=TOP |parName=precedence |itemName=even |itemSummary=When the disk files are fragmented. The Movie File In TOP will read frames of the movie into memory before they are used, this can eliminate pops or stutters in playback that occur from fragmented files, other resources accessing the hard drive, or movie looping. |itemLabel=Even }}{{ParameterItem |opFamily=TOP |parName=precedence |itemName=odd |itemSummary= |itemLabel=Odd }} |parName=precedence |opType=moviefilein |parLabel=Field Precedence |parSummary=Where fields are extracted one field at a time, this will extract the Even field first by default, otehrwise it will extract the odd field first. The video industry has not standardized on one or the other. |parType=Menu |parReadOnly= }} {{Parameter |parSummary=If enabled, the image/movie will have it's height halved, and the R channel from the pixels on the bottom half will be treated as if they were the alpha channel for the top half. Useful for cases where the image format does not support alpha natively. |opFamily=TOP |opType=moviefilein |parOrder=3 |parLabel=Bottom Half is Alpha (AAA) |parName=bottomhalfalpha |parType=Toggle |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter |parOrder=4 |opFamily=TOP |parItems={{ParameterItem |opFamily=TOP |parName=multalpha |itemName=off |itemSummary= |itemLabel=Off }}{{ParameterItem |opFamily=TOP |parName=multalpha |itemName=on |itemSummary= |itemLabel=On }}{{ParameterItem |opFamily=TOP |parName=multalpha |itemName=automatic |itemSummary= |itemLabel=Automatic }} |parName=multalpha |opType=moviefilein |parLabel=Multiply RGB by Alpha |parSummary=Premultiplies the image. |parType=Menu |parReadOnly= }} {{Parameter |parSummary=If the input image is 8-bit and [[sRGB]] color space, enable this to have treated as such. |opFamily=TOP |opType=moviefilein |parOrder=5 |parLabel=Input is sRGB |parName=inputsrgb |parType=Toggle |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter |parOrder=6 |opFamily=TOP |parItems={{ParameterItem |opFamily=TOP |parName=loadingerrorimage |itemName=coloredbottomright |itemSummary=Show a colored square in the bottom right. Red means failed to load, grey means still loading. |itemLabel=Colored Bottom Right Square }}{{ParameterItem |opFamily=TOP |parName=loadingerrorimage |itemName=zero |itemSummary=Show a blank frame. |itemLabel=Zero }} |parName=loadingerrorimage |opType=moviefilein |parLabel=Loading/Error Image |parSummary=When the file can not be loaded for some reason, select what to display instead. |parType=Menu |parReadOnly= }} }} {{ParameterPage |pageSummary= |pageName=Trim |opFamily=TOP |items={{Parameter |parSummary=Enables the parameters below to set trim in and out points. |opFamily=TOP |parOrder=1 |parLabel=Trim Start |parName=tstart |parType=Float |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter |parOrder=2 |opFamily=TOP |parItems={{ParameterItem |opFamily=TOP |parName=tstartunit |itemLabel=S |itemName=seconds |itemSummary= }}{{ParameterItem |opFamily=TOP |parName=tstartunit |itemLabel=% |itemName=fraction |itemSummary= }} |parName=tstartunit |opType=moviefilein |parLabel=Trim Start Unit |parSummary=Select the units for this parameter from Index, Frames, Seconds, and Fraction (percentage). |parType=Menu |parReadOnly= }} {{Parameter |parSummary=Trim the ending point of the movie. |opFamily=TOP |opType=moviefilein |parOrder=3 |parLabel=Trim End |parName=tend |parType=Float |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter |parOrder=4 |opFamily=TOP |parItems={{ParameterItem |opFamily=TOP |parName=tendunit |itemLabel=I |itemName=indices |itemSummary= }}{{ParameterItem |opFamily=TOP |parName=tendunit |itemLabel=F |itemName=frames |itemSummary= }}{{ParameterItem |opFamily=TOP |parName=tendunit |itemLabel=S |itemName=seconds |itemSummary= }}{{ParameterItem |opFamily=TOP |parName=tendunit |itemLabel=% |itemName=fraction |itemSummary= }} |parName=tendunit |opType=moviefilein |parLabel=Trim End Unit |parSummary=Select the units for this parameter from Index, Frames, Seconds, and Fraction (percentage). |parType=Menu |parReadOnly= }} {{Parameter |parOrder=5 |opFamily=TOP |parItems={{ParameterItem |opFamily=TOP |parName=textendleft |itemName=hold |itemSummary=Displays the first frame in the movie range (the frame specified by Trim Start) for any position before Trim Start. |itemLabel=Hold }}{{ParameterItem |opFamily=TOP |parName=textendleft |itemName=cycle |itemSummary=Loops the movie range continuously. |itemLabel=Cycle }}{{ParameterItem |opFamily=TOP |parName=textendleft |itemName=mirror |itemSummary=Loops the movie range in a zig-zag pattern. For example, playing backwards from Trim Start the movie will index will climb towards Trim End, at which point is will decend down towards Trim Start again and continue to zig-zag (or mirror) the further the movie plays backwards. |itemLabel=Mirror }}{{ParameterItem |opFamily=TOP |parName=textendleft |itemName=black |itemSummary=Displays black frame for any movie position before Trim Start. |itemLabel=Black }}{{ParameterItem |opFamily=TOP |parName=textendleft |itemName=zero |itemSummary= |itemLabel=Zero }} |parName=textendleft |opType=moviefilein |parLabel=Extend Left |parSummary=Determines how the Movie File In TOP handles movie positions that lie before the Trim Start position. For example, if Trim Start is set to 1, and the movie's current index is -10, the Extend Left menu determines how the movie position is calculated. |parType=Menu |parReadOnly= }} {{Parameter |parOrder=6 |opFamily=TOP |parItems={{ParameterItem |opFamily=TOP |parName=textendright |itemName=hold |itemSummary=Displays the last frame in the movie range (the frame specified by Trim End) for any position after Trim End. |itemLabel=Hold }}{{ParameterItem |opFamily=TOP |parName=textendright |itemName=cycle |itemSummary=Loops the movie range continuously. |itemLabel=Cycle }}{{ParameterItem |opFamily=TOP |parName=textendright |itemName=mirror |itemSummary=Loops the movie range in a zig-zag pattern. For example, playing forwards from Trim End the movie will index will start decending towards Trim Start, at which point is will start climbing towards Trim End and continue to zig-zag (or mirror) the further the movie plays. |itemLabel=Mirror }}{{ParameterItem |opFamily=TOP |parName=textendright |itemName=black |itemSummary=Displays black frame for any movie position after Trim End. |itemLabel=Black }}{{ParameterItem |opFamily=TOP |parName=textendright |itemName=zero |itemSummary= |itemLabel=Zero }} |parName=textendright |opType=moviefilein |parLabel=Extend Right |parSummary=Determines how the Movie File In TOP handles movie positions that lie after the Trim End position. For example, if Trim End is set to 20, and the movie's current index is 25, the Extend Right menu determines how the movie position is calculated. |parType=Menu |parReadOnly= }} {{Parameter |parSummary=Turn On to change the sample rate of the movie. When loading an image sequence, use these parameters to set the playback speed for the sequence. |opFamily=TOP |opType=moviefilein |parOrder=7 |parLabel=Override Sample Rate |parName=overridesample |parType=Toggle |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter |parSummary=Set the sample rate for playback when 'Override Sample Rate' above is On. |opFamily=TOP |opType=moviefilein |parOrder=8 |parLabel=Sample Rate |parName=samplerate |parType=Float |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} }} {{ParameterPage |pageSummary= |pageName=Tune |opFamily=TOP |items={{Parameter |parSummary=Sets how many video frames TouchDesigner reads ahead and stores in memory. The Movie File In TOP will read and decode frames of the movie into CPU memory before they are used, this can eliminate pops or stutters in playback that occur from some frames taking too long to decode, other resources accessing the hard drive, or movie looping. When reading a sequence of image, having more Pre Read Frames will allow multiple images to be decode at the same time. This allows playback of heavy file formats such as .exr in real-time, assuming the machine has enough CPU cores. |opFamily=TOP |opType=moviefilein |parOrder=0 |parLabel=Pre-Read Frames |parName=prereadframes |parType=Int |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter |parSummary=The time (in milliseconds) TouchDesigner will wait for a frame from the hard drive before giving up. If the Disk Read Timeout time is reached, that frame is simply skipped. This also works for network files that are downloaded via http://. |opFamily=TOP |opType=moviefilein |parOrder=1 |parLabel=Frame Read Timeout |parName=frametimeout |parType=Int |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter |opFamily=TOP |opType=moviefileinTOP |parLabel=Frame Timeout Strategy |parName=frametimeoutstrat |parType=Menu |parReadOnly= |parOrder=2 |parSummary=When on, if the Disk Read Timeout is reached TouchDesigner will use the latest available frame in place of the skipped frame. |parItems={{ParameterItem |opFamily=TOP |parName=frametimeoutstrat |itemLabel=Keep Frame |itemName=keep |itemSummary=Keep showing the same frame that is currently being output. }}{{ParameterItem |opFamily=TOP |parName=frametimeoutstrat |itemLabel=Best for Playback |itemName=playback |itemSummary=Try to pick the best frame for playback. This may be a newer frame that what is shown, but not quite the frame that is requested. }}{{ParameterItem |opFamily=TOP |parName=frametimeoutstrat |itemLabel=Best for Seeking |itemName=seeking |itemSummary=Try to show any frame, either before or after the target frame. Good for when seeking the movie via a shuttle widget in a UI. }} }} {{Parameter |parSummary=If this parameter is turned on, then for the first loaded frame the Frame Read Timeout will be ignored, and it will always wait for the first frame to ensure the node always starts up with a valid image. |opFamily=TOP |opType=moviefilein |parOrder=3 |parLabel=Always Load Initial Frame |parName=alwaysloadinitial |parType=Toggle |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter |parSummary=The time (in milliseconds) TouchDesigner will wait for a movie to open. If the Disk Open Timout is reached, the Movie File In TOP will stop waiting and make its image all black, with a grey square in the bottom right corner. If the file still isn't opened the next time the TOP cooks, it'll wait again, and do the same. It'll keep doing this until the file is opened, or the open fails. |opFamily=TOP |opType=moviefilein |parOrder=4 |parLabel=File Open Timeout |parName=opentimeout |parType=Int |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter |parSummary=When on, if the Disk Read Timeout is reached TouchDesigner will use the latest available frame in place of the skipped frame. |opFamily=TOP |opType=moviefilein |parOrder=4 |parLabel=On Timeout, use Latest Avail |parName=uselatestontimeout |parType=Menu |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter |parSummary=When enabled, this will use OpenGL features to upload movie images to the GPU asynchronously. This will reduce the cook time of the Movie File In TOP considerably (in the performance monitor the lines that say "Uploading Image to GPU" will go down to almost nothing). There is a GPU memory cost to using this feature however. It uses up another (Width * Height * 4 * Read Ahead Size) bytes of GPU memory. If you are having poor results with this feature, make sure your graphics drivers are up to date. |opFamily=TOP |opType=moviefilein |parOrder=5 |parLabel=Async Upload to GPU |parName=asyncupload |parType=Toggle |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter |parSummary=Image will not update when set to 0. Movie index will continue to move forward but the output image will not update. This is useful when you are using a Movie Audio CHOP to get audio from the movie, but you don't care about the video. |opFamily=TOP |opType=moviefilein |parOrder=6 |parLabel=Update Image |parName=updateimage |parType=Toggle |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter |parSummary=Limit the maximum number of CPUs that will be used to decode certain video codecs that are capable of multi-CPU decoding, such as H264/H265 and Cineform. Note that this does not affect multi-threaded decoding for image sequence playback, which is instead controlled by increasing the Pre-Read Frame parameter. |opFamily=TOP |opType=moviefilein |parOrder=7 |parLabel=Max Decode CPUs |parName=maxdecodecpus |parType=Int |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter |parSummary=This option should be used when playing back files that require very high SSD read speeds such as high resolution (4K+) HAP Q files. It greatly improves read performance in those cases. It should not be used for low resolution or low data rate files such as 1080p H264 files. |opFamily=TOP |opType=moviefilein |parOrder=8 |parLabel=High Performance Read |parName=highperfread |parType=Toggle |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter |parSummary=When doing high performance reads, this parameter controls the size of the read operations that are done on disk. Whatever the largest operation the codec asks to be done, this is multiplied by the read factor and all subsequent reads will read that much data instead. This can result in higher throughput depending on the drives. For example if a request is made to read 1MB and the factor is set to 3, then instead the operations will read 3MB from the disk and the extra 2MB read will be ready for the next frame and will likely already have the next 2 frames available in CPU RAM. |opFamily=TOP |opType=moviefilein |parOrder=9 |parLabel=High Performance Read Factor |parName=highperfreadfactor |parType=Float |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter |opFamily=TOP |opType=moviefileinTOP |parLabel=Hardware Decode |parName=hwdecode |parType=Toggle |parReadOnly= |parOrder=10 |parSummary=Controls if this node should use hardware decoding via the Nvidia hardware decoder chip. You can check if hardware decoding is being used using the Info CHOP, 'hardware_decode' channel. This parameter does nothing for Hap and NotchLC codecs, which are always hardware decoded. |parItems= }} }} [[Category:OP Help Common Pages]]{{:TOP Generator Common Page}} {{InfoCHOPChannels |opFamily=TOP |opLabel=Movie File In |infoChannels= {{InfoChannel| chanName=index| chanSummary=The current frame index being shown. This is in the FPS of the movie file, not in timeline frames. }}{{InfoChannel| chanName=true_index| chanSummary=When the movie has a Trim applied to it, this will show the actually frame index within the movie being shown. }}{{InfoChannel| chanName=index_fraction| chanSummary=Normalized index value going from 0-1 from start to the end of the movie. }}{{InfoChannel| chanName=file_resx| chanSummary=The width of the movie in pixels. }}{{InfoChannel| chanName=file_resy| chanSummary=The height of the movie in pixels. }}{{InfoChannel| chanName=start| chanSummary=Unused currently. }}{{InfoChannel |chanName=length |chanSummary=The length of the movie, in movie frames. }}{{InfoChannel |chanName=sample_rate |chanSummary=The FPS of the movie. }}{{InfoChannel |chanName=last_index_uploaded |chanSummary=The last movie frame uploaded to the GPU. }}{{InfoChannel |chanName=mv_has_audio |chanSummary=1 if the movie has an audio track, 0 if not. }}{{InfoChannel |chanName=preloading |chanSummary=1 if the movie is currently preloading via the preload() Python method. }}{{InfoChannel |chanName=odd_field |chanSummary=When deinterlacing using Bob (split), 1 means the odd field is being shown, 0 means the even field is being shown. }}{{InfoChannel |chanName=last_frame |chanSummary=1 if the last frame of the movie is currently being shown, 0 if not. Note that if a frame is dropped the last frame may never get shown, if the movie is looping. }}{{InfoChannel |chanName=loop_frame |chanSummary=1 if the movie has just looped. }}{{InfoChannel |chanName=pre_read_misses |chanSummary=Counts how many times the node wanted to show a frame, but that frame wasn't already ready in the Pre-Read Cache. }}{{InfoChannel |chanName=last_pre_read_miss_wait |chanSummary=The amount of time the node last waited for a pre_read_misses frame to be read, in milliseconds. }}{{InfoChannel |chanName=hard_drive_timeouts |chanSummary=The number of times the node gave up reading a frame due to it not reading fast enough. The amount of time it will wait is controlled by the 'Frame Read Timeout' parameter. }}{{InfoChannel |chanName=num_pre_read_frames |chanSummary=The number of frames that have been pre-read, decoded, and are ready to be shown. }}{{InfoChannel |chanName=first_index_to_read |chanSummary=The frame index of the first index in the Pre-Read cache. }}{{InfoChannel |chanName=last_frame_hd_read_time |chanSummary=The amount of time spent reading the last frame from the hard-drive, in milliseconds. }}{{InfoChannel |chanName=last_frame_decode_time |chanSummary=The amount of time spent decoding/decompression the last frame on the CPU, in milliseconds. This does not account for time spent decoding on the GPU for codecs such as NotchLC, or Hardware Decoded codecs. }}{{InfoChannel |chanName=open |chanSummary=1 if the movie's file is open. }}{{InfoChannel |chanName=opening |chanSummary=1 if the movie's file is in the process of opening, but not open yet. }}{{InfoChannel |chanName=open_failed |chanSummary=1 if opening the movie failed. }}{{InfoChannel |chanName=fully_pre_read |chanSummary=1 if the Pre-Read Cache of the movie is filled with already decoded frames. }}{{InfoChannel |chanName=true_length |chanSummary=The true length of the movie, ignoring any trimming. }}{{InfoChannel |chanName=hardware_yuv_to_rgb |chanSummary=1 if the YUV format the movie was encoded in is being converted to RGB on the GPU. }}{{InfoChannel |chanName=has_non_av_track |chanSummary=1 if the movie file has a track that is not video or audio, such as a subtitle track. }}{{InfoChannel |chanName=pre_read_fails |chanSummary=The number of times pre-reading a frame failed. }}{{InfoChannel |chanName=disk_read_mbit_rate |chanSummary=The amount of data being read per second off of the hard drive, in mega-bits. }}{{InfoChannel |chanName=has_decode_errors |chanSummary=1 if the file is suffering from decode errors. }}{{InfoChannel |chanName=num_decode_chunks |chanSummary=For Hap codecs, how many chunks the file was encoded as. }}{{InfoChannel |chanName=hardrware_decode |chanSummary=If the Hardware Decode parameter is on, this will be 1 if the GPU is able to hardware decode the movie's codec. }}}} {{History }} {{TOPNavBox |opFamily=TOP }} {{#invoke:Category|list|TOPs}}

{{Summary
	|opFamily=TOP
	|opType=flowTOP
	|opLabel=Nvidia Flow
	|opClass=flowTOP_Class
	|opFilter=False
	|opLicense=Non-Commercial
    |os=Microsoft Windows
    |hardware=This operator only works with '''Nvidia GPUs'''.
	|short=The Nvidia Flow TOP calculates the Flow simulation and renders it.
	|long=NVIDIA Flow is a volumetric fluid based simulation of a burning gas system. The user controls the 3 main factors of temperature, fuel, and smoke to create fire and smoke simulations. 

The Nvidia Flow TOP calculates the Flow simulation and renders it. It requires a [[Nvidia Flow Emitter COMP]] to emit gas into the Flow simulation. 

See also [[Nvidia Flow Emitter COMP]], [[Nvidia Flow]].

Read more here [https://docs.nvidia.com/gameworks/content/artisttools/Flow/index.html Nvidia Flow Artist Tools]
	|opCategories=
	}}

	|short=The Nvidia Upscaler TOP upscales the resolution of an input video.
	|long=The Nvidia Upscaler TOP upscales the resolution of an input video. It can run either the [https://docs.nvidia.com/deeplearning/maxine/vfx-sdk-programming-guide/index.html#upscale-filter Upscale Filter] or [https://docs.nvidia.com/deeplearning/maxine/vfx-sdk-programming-guide/index.html#super-res-filter Super-Resolution Filter]. The Upscale Filter is faster and offers a Strength parameter. The Super Resolution mode is higher quality and doesn't offer a Strength parameter, but it does have an optional Artifact Reduction toggle. Refer to the Table [https://docs.nvidia.com/deeplearning/maxine/vfx-sdk-programming-guide/index.html#upscale-filter Scale and Resolution Support for Input Videos] for the requirements of the input resolution.
