{{Summary |opFilter=False |long=The Noise CHOP makes an irregular wave that never repeats, with values approximately in the range -1 to +1. It generates both smooth curves and noise that is random each sample. It uses the same math as the [[Noise SOP]]. You can create several curves with different shapes, and you can adjust period, amplitude, harmonics and more. Optionally, an input can be connected. It is assumed that the input contains 1 to 3 channels representing X, Y and Z coordinates of points in space, and are used to sample anywhere in 3D noise space. One index in the input produces one sample in the output. All noise functions work identically with [[Time Slicing]] on and off, with the exception of Harmonic Summation and Brownian whose methods cannot be limited to 1 in Time Slice mode. When the [[Timeline]] wraps around to frame 1, the noise functions will continue uninterrupted. |opLicense=Non-Commercial |opClass=noiseCHOP_Class |opLabel=Noise |opFamily=CHOP |opType=noise |short=The Noise CHOP makes an irregular wave that never repeats, with values approximately in the range -1 to +1. |opCategories= }} {{ParameterPage |opFamily=CHOP |pageName=Noise |items= {{Parameter|parName=type |parItems= {{ParameterItem|itemName=sparse |opFamily=CHOP |parName=type |itemLabel=Sparse |itemSummary=Produces high quality, continuous noise based on Sparse Convolution. }}{{ParameterItem|itemName=hermite |opFamily=CHOP |parName=type |itemLabel=Hermite |itemSummary=Quicker than Sparse, but produces lower quality noise. }}{{ParameterItem|itemName=harmonic |opFamily=CHOP |parName=type |itemLabel=Harmomic Summation |itemSummary=Sparse noise with the ability to control the frequency step of the harmonics. Slowest type. }}{{ParameterItem|itemName=brownian |opFamily=CHOP |parName=type |itemLabel=Brownian |itemSummary=Works like a bug in random flight. With Num of Integrals at 2, its acceleration is changed randomly every frame. }}{{ParameterItem|itemName=random |opFamily=CHOP |parName=type |itemLabel=Random |itemSummary=(White Noise) Every sample is random and unrelated to any other sample. It is the same as "white noise" in audio. }}{{ParameterItem|itemName=alligator |opFamily=CHOP |parName=type |itemLabel=Alligator |itemSummary=Cell Noise. }} |parOrder=0 |parLabel=Type |opFamily=CHOP |opType=noise |parSummary=The noise function used to generate noise. The functions available are: |parType=Menu |parReadOnly= }} {{Parameter|parName=seed |parOrder=1 |parLabel=Seed |opFamily=CHOP |opType=noise |parSummary=Any number, integer or non-integer, which starts the random number generator. Each number gives completely different noise patterns, but with similar characteristics. |parType=Float |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|parName=period |parOrder=2 |parLabel=Period |opFamily=CHOP |opType=noise |parSummary=The approximate separation between peaks of a noise cycle. It is expressed in Units. Increasing the period stretches the noise pattern out. Period is the opposite of frequency. If the period is 2 seconds, the base frequency is 0.5 cycles per second, or 0.5Hz for short. Hz refers to Hertz, the electrical and audio engineer of the 19th century, not the car guy. If the Type is set to Random, setting this to zero will produce completely random noise. Otherwise, the period should be greater than zero. |parType=Float |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|parName=periodunit |parItems= |parOrder=3 |parLabel=Period Unit |opFamily=CHOP |opType=noise |parSummary=Select the units to use for this parameter, Samples, Frames, Seconds, or Fraction. |parType=Menu |parReadOnly= }} {{Parameter|parName=harmon |parOrder=4 |parLabel=Harmonics |opFamily=CHOP |opType=noise |parSummary=The number of higher frequency components to layer on top of the base frequency. The higher this number, the bumpier the noise will be (as long as roughness is not set to zero). 0 harmonics give the base shape. Harmonics with a base frequency of 0.1Hz will by default produce harmonics at 0.2Hz, 0.4Hz, 0.8Hz, etc. (up to the number of harmonics specified by the Harmonics parameter). |parType=Int |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|parName=spread |parOrder=5 |parLabel=Harmonic Spread |opFamily=CHOP |opType=noise |parSummary=The factor by which the frequency of the harmonics are increased. It is normally 2. A spread of 3 and a base frequency of 0.1Hz will produce harmonics at 0.3Hz, 0.9Hz, 2.7Hz, etc. This parameter is only valid for the Harmonic Summation type. |parType=Float |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|parName=rough |parOrder=6 |parLabel=Roughness |opFamily=CHOP |opType=noise |parSummary=Controls the effect of the higher frequency noise. When roughness is zero, all harmonics above the base frequency have no effect. At one, all harmonics are equal in amplitude to the base frequency. When roughness is between one and zero, the amplitude of higher harmonics drops off exponentially from the base frequency. The default roughness is 0.5. This means the amplitude of the first harmonic is 0.5 of the base frequency, the second is 0.25, the third is 0.125. The harmonics are added to the base to give the final shape. The Harmonics parameter and the Roughness parameter must both be non-zero to see the harmonic effects. |parType=Float |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|parName=exp |parOrder=7 |parLabel=Exponent |opFamily=CHOP |opType=noise |parSummary=Pushes the noise values toward 0, or +1 and -1. (It raises the value to the power of the exponent.) Exponents greater than one will pull the channel toward zero, and powers less than one will pull peaks towards +1 and -1. It is used to reshape the channels. |parType=Float |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|parName=numint |parOrder=8 |parLabel=Num of Integrals |opFamily=CHOP |opType=noise |parSummary=Defines the number of times to integrate (see the Area CHOP p. 114) the Brownian noise. Higher values produce smoother curves with fewer features. Values beyond 4 produce somewhat identical curves. This parameter is only valid for the Random noise type. |parType=Int |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|parName=amp |parOrder=9 |parLabel=Amplitude |opFamily=CHOP |opType=noise |parSummary=Defines the noise value's amplitude (a scale on the values output). |parType=Float |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|parName=reset |parOrder=10 |parLabel=Reset |opFamily=CHOP |opType=noise |parSummary=Only available if operator's Time Slice Parameter is on. Toggling this parameter will reset the noise calculation and hold the value until the parameter is released again. |parType=Toggle |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|parName=resetpulse |parOrder=11 |parLabel=Reset Pulse |opFamily=CHOP |opType=noise |parSummary=Only available if operator's Time Slice Parameter is on. Pulsing this parameter will reset the noise calculation. |parType=Pulse |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} |pageSummary= }} {{ParameterPage |opFamily=CHOP |pageName=Transform |items= {{Parameter|parName=xord |parItems= {{ParameterItem|itemName=srt |opFamily=CHOP |parName=xord |itemLabel=Scale Rotate Translate |itemSummary= }}{{ParameterItem|itemName=str |opFamily=CHOP |parName=xord |itemLabel=Scale Translate Rotate |itemSummary= }}{{ParameterItem|itemName=rst |opFamily=CHOP |parName=xord |itemLabel=Rotate Scale Translate |itemSummary= }}{{ParameterItem|itemName=rts |opFamily=CHOP |parName=xord |itemLabel=Rotate Translate Scale |itemSummary= }}{{ParameterItem|itemName=tsr |opFamily=CHOP |parName=xord |itemLabel=Translate Scale Rotate |itemSummary= }}{{ParameterItem|itemName=trs |opFamily=CHOP |parName=xord |itemLabel=Translate Rotate Scale |itemSummary= }} |parOrder=0 |parLabel=Transform Order |opFamily=CHOP |opType=noise |parSummary=Changing the Transform Order will change where things go much the same way as going a block and turning east gets you to a different place than turning east and then going a block. In matrix math terms, if we use the 'multiply vector on the right' (column vector) convention, a transform order of Scale, Rotate, Translate would be written as T * R * S * Position |parType=Menu |parReadOnly= }} {{Parameter|parName=rord |parItems= {{ParameterItem|itemName=xyz |opFamily=CHOP |parName=rord |itemLabel=Rx Ry Rz |itemSummary= }}{{ParameterItem|itemName=xzy |opFamily=CHOP |parName=rord |itemLabel=Rx Rz Ry |itemSummary= }}{{ParameterItem|itemName=yxz |opFamily=CHOP |parName=rord |itemLabel=Ry Rx Rz |itemSummary= }}{{ParameterItem|itemName=yzx |opFamily=CHOP |parName=rord |itemLabel=Ry Rz Rx |itemSummary= }}{{ParameterItem|itemName=zxy |opFamily=CHOP |parName=rord |itemLabel=Rz Rx Ry |itemSummary= }}{{ParameterItem|itemName=zyx |opFamily=CHOP |parName=rord |itemLabel=Rz Ry Rx |itemSummary= }} |parOrder=1 |parLabel=Rotate Order |opFamily=CHOP |opType=noise |parSummary=As with transform order (above), changing the order in which the rotations take place will alter the final position and orientation. A Rotation order of Rx Ry Rz would create the final rotation matrix as follows R = Rz * Ry * Rx |parType=Menu |parReadOnly= }} {{Parameter|parName=t |parItems= {{ParameterItem|itemName=tx |opFamily=CHOP |parName=t |itemLabel=X |itemSummary= }}{{ParameterItem|itemName=ty |opFamily=CHOP |parName=t |itemLabel=Y |itemSummary= }}{{ParameterItem|itemName=tz |opFamily=CHOP |parName=t |itemLabel=Z |itemSummary= }} |parOrder=2 |parLabel=Translate |opFamily=CHOP |opType=noise |parSummary=XYZ translation values. |parType=XYZ |parReadOnly= }} {{Parameter|parName=r |parItems= {{ParameterItem|itemName=rx |opFamily=CHOP |parName=r |itemLabel=X |itemSummary= }}{{ParameterItem|itemName=ry |opFamily=CHOP |parName=r |itemLabel=Y |itemSummary= }}{{ParameterItem|itemName=rz |opFamily=CHOP |parName=r |itemLabel=Z |itemSummary= }} |parOrder=3 |parLabel=Rotate |opFamily=CHOP |opType=noise |parSummary=XYZ rotation, in degrees. |parType=XYZ |parReadOnly= }} {{Parameter|parName=s |parItems= {{ParameterItem|itemName=sx |opFamily=CHOP |parName=s |itemLabel=X |itemSummary= }}{{ParameterItem|itemName=sy |opFamily=CHOP |parName=s |itemLabel=Y |itemSummary= }}{{ParameterItem|itemName=sz |opFamily=CHOP |parName=s |itemLabel=Z |itemSummary= }} |parOrder=4 |parLabel=Scale |opFamily=CHOP |opType=noise |parSummary=XYZ scale to shrink or enlarge the transform. |parType=XYZ |parReadOnly= }} {{Parameter|parName=p |parItems= {{ParameterItem|itemName=px |opFamily=CHOP |parName=p |itemLabel=X |itemSummary= }}{{ParameterItem|itemName=py |opFamily=CHOP |parName=p |itemLabel=Y |itemSummary= }}{{ParameterItem|itemName=pz |opFamily=CHOP |parName=p |itemLabel=Z |itemSummary= }} |parOrder=5 |parLabel=Pivot |opFamily=CHOP |opType=noise |parSummary=XYZ pivot to apply the above operations around. |parType=XYZ |parReadOnly= }} |pageSummary=The Translate, Rotate, Scale and Pivot parameters let you sample in a different part of the 3D noise space. Imagine a different noise value for every XYZ point in space. Normally, the Noise CHOP samples the noise space from (0,0,0) along the X-axis in steps of 2/period. /tx /ty /tz /rx /ry /rx /sx /sy /sz /px /py /pz : By changing the transform, you are translating, rotating and scaling the line along which the Noise CHOPs samples the noise space. A slight Y-rotation is like walking in a straight path in the mountains, recording your altitude along the way, then re-starting from the same initial location, walking in a slightly different direction. Your altitude starts off being similar but then diverges. }} {{ParameterPage |opFamily=CHOP |pageName=Constraints |items= {{Parameter|parName=constraint |parItems= {{ParameterItem|itemName=none |opFamily=CHOP |parName=constraint |itemLabel=None |itemSummary=No constraints set. }}{{ParameterItem|itemName=start |opFamily=CHOP |parName=constraint |itemLabel=Start Value |itemSummary=Sets the noise starting position to the value set in 'Starting Value' parameter below. }}{{ParameterItem|itemName=end |opFamily=CHOP |parName=constraint |itemLabel=End Value |itemSummary=Sets the noise ending position to the value set in 'Ending Value' parameter below. }}{{ParameterItem|itemName=offset |opFamily=CHOP |parName=constraint |itemLabel=Mean Value |itemSummary=Sets the noise mean position to the value set in the 'Mean Value' parameter below. }}{{ParameterItem|itemName=endpoints |opFamily=CHOP |parName=constraint |itemLabel=Start/End Values |itemSummary=Set the starting and ending position of the noise separately using the parameters below. }} |parOrder=0 |parLabel=Constraint |opFamily=CHOP |opType=noise |parSummary=Constraint and its parameters allows the noise curve to start and/or end at selected values. The mean value may also be enforced. '''Note:''' This only works when Time Slice is Off because time slicing has no pre-determined start/end. |parType=Menu |parReadOnly= }} {{Parameter|parName=constrstart |parOrder=1 |parLabel=Starting Value |opFamily=CHOP |opType=noise |parSummary=Value for the starting position. |parType=Float |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|parName=constrend |parOrder=2 |parLabel=Ending Value |opFamily=CHOP |opType=noise |parSummary=Value for the ending position. |parType=Float |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|parName=constrmean |parOrder=3 |parLabel=Mean Value |opFamily=CHOP |opType=noise |parSummary=Value for the mean value of the noise. |parType=Float |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|parName=normal |parOrder=4 |parLabel=Normalize |opFamily=CHOP |opType=noise |parSummary=Ensures that all noise curves fall between -1 and 1. Applied before the Amplitude parameter. Only valid for Random and Harmonic Summation noise types, since Hermite and Sparse noise are always normalized. Normalizing random noise occurs between integrations, producing a more controlled curve. '''Note:''' This only works when Time Slice is Off because time slicing has no pre-determined start/end. |parType=Toggle |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} |pageSummary= }} {{ParameterPage |opFamily=CHOP |pageName=Channel |items= {{Parameter|parName=channelname |parOrder=0 |parLabel=Channel Names |opFamily=CHOP |opType=noise |parSummary=You can creates many channels with simple patterns like "chan[1-20]", which generates 20 channels from chan1 to chan20. See the section, Common CHOP Parameters for a description of this and all Options. See [[CHOP Common Page#Scope|Scope and Channel Name Matching]] Options. Each channel has a unique seed, so all channels will be different with the same parameter settings. |parType=Str |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|parName=start |parOrder=1 |parLabel=Start |opFamily=CHOP |opType=noise |parSummary=Start of the interval, expressed in Units (seconds, frames or samples). |parType=Float |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|parName=startunit |parItems= |parOrder=2 |parLabel=Start Unit |opFamily=CHOP |opType=noise |parSummary=Select the units to use for this parameter, Samples, Frames, or Seconds. |parType=Menu |parReadOnly= }} {{Parameter|parName=end |parOrder=3 |parLabel=End |opFamily=CHOP |opType=noise |parSummary=End of the interval, expressed in Units (seconds, frames or samples). |parType=Float |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|parName=endunit |parItems= |parOrder=4 |parLabel=End Unit |opFamily=CHOP |opType=noise |parSummary=Select the units to use for this parameter, Samples, Frames, or Seconds. |parType=Menu |parReadOnly= }} {{Parameter|parName=rate |parOrder=5 |parLabel=Sample Rate |opFamily=CHOP |opType=noise |parSummary=The sample rate of the channels, in samples per second. {{Summary			
	|opLicense=Non-Commercial		
	|opClass=nullCHOP_Class		
	|opFamily=CHOP		
	|long=The Null CHOP is used as a place-holder and does not alter the data coming in.		
			
It is often used to [[Export]] channels to parameters, which allows you to experiment with the CHOPs that feed into the Null without having to un-export from one CHOP and re-export from another.			
			
The Null CHOP also has options to force-cook nodes downstream from it, or the opposite, to stop cooking nodes downstream if its inputs are not changing.			
			
[[Image:NullCHOP.jpg]]			
	|short=The Null CHOP is used as a place-holder and does not alter the data coming in.		
	|opFilter=True		
	|opType=null		
	|opLabel=Null		
|opCategories=		
	}}			
{{ParameterPage			
	|items=		
	{{Parameter|parLabel=Cook Type	
		|opFamily=CHOP	
		|parItems=	
		{{ParameterItem|itemLabel=Automatic
			|opFamily=CHOP
			|itemSummary=Downstream nodes are triggered for recooking normally.
			|itemName=auto
			|parName=cooktype
		}}<!--
-->{{ParameterItem|itemLabel=Always
			|opFamily=CHOP
			|itemSummary=This node and dirty upstream nodes will cook every frame. Downstream nodes will recook every frame their data is requested.
			|itemName=always
			|parName=cooktype
		}}<!--
-->{{ParameterItem|itemLabel=Selective
			|opFamily=CHOP
			|itemSummary=Select which criteria will cause downstream nodes to require recooking, using the parameters below. This option can optimize your network by reducing the number of cooks downstream if the upstream CHOP has inputs that are time dependent or changes often, but output is mostly static (e.g. a Math CHOP rounding a constantly changing float to 0 or 1). The downside is that the nodes upstream of the Null will cook whenever something changes, even if no data is requested downstream. See [[Cook]] for more information on when data is requested.
			|itemName=selective
			|parName=cooktype
		}}	
			
		|parSummary=This controls how nodes downstream from the Null CHOP are triggered for recooking when the Null CHOP output changes. See also: [[Cook]]	
		|parOrder=0	
		|opType=null	
		|parName=cooktype	
	|parType=Menu
	|parReadOnly=	
		}}		
	{{Parameter|parLabel=Check Values	
		|parOrder=1	
		|parSummary=Recook when the Null CHOP values change.	
		|opFamily=CHOP	
		|opType=null	
		|parName=checkvalues	
	|parType=Toggle
	|parReadOnly=	
		|parItems=	
		}}		
	{{Parameter|parLabel=Check Names	
		|parOrder=2	
		|parSummary=Recook when the Null CHOP channel names change.	
		|opFamily=CHOP	
		|opType=null	
		|parName=checknames	
	|parType=Toggle
	|parReadOnly=	
		|parItems=	
		}}		
	{{Parameter|parLabel=Check Range	
		|parOrder=3	
		|parSummary=Recook when the Null CHOP channel range changes.	
			
Please note that downstream cooks may also cook for a variety of reasons including viewing the contents of the data while editing nodes, etc.			
		|opFamily=CHOP	
		|opType=null	
		|parName=checkrange	
	|parType=Toggle
	|parReadOnly=	
		|parItems=}}		
			
	|pageName=Null		
	|pageSummary=		
	|opFamily=CHOP		
}}

{{Summary |opFamily=CHOP |opType=oakdeviceCHOP |opLabel=OAK Device |opClass=oakdeviceCHOP_Class |opFilter=False |opLicense=Non-Commercial |opCategories= |short=The OAK Device CHOP serves as the main interface to an OAK camera. |long=The OAK Device CHOP serves as the main interface to an OAK camera. It also implements many of the features of the Timer CHOP such as timer counters, pulses, and custom Python callbacks.{{OPSubSection |opFamily=CHOP |sectionName=Basic Usage |sectionSummary=Before starting TouchDesigner, connect any OAK Devices to the computer via USB or Power over Ethernet (PoE). If you connect any devices while TouchDesigner is running, you should pulse the Refresh Device List parameter on the OAK Device CHOP. Next, customize the Python createPipeline callback and pulse the start parameter to start the camera. It's ok if you save a project while a camera is running. The camera will know to automatically start when the project opens next time.}}{{OPSubSection |opFamily=CHOP |sectionName=Resolution and ISP Scale |sectionSummary=The depthai python module has an enum for RGB resolution: [https://docs.luxonis.com/projects/api/en/latest/references/python/?highlight=dai.ColorCameraProperties.SensorResolution#depthai.ColorCameraProperties.SensorResolution dai.ColorCameraProperties.SensorResolution]. This enum currently includes THE_1080_P, THE_1200_P, THE_4_K, and many others. These options may not necessarily be compatible with your OAK hardware. The most commonly available RGB resolution is 1080p. You can save on bandwidth by selecting a lower resolution via the ISP scale. Selecting (2, 3) with THE_1080_P will result in a 1280x720 image.}}{{OPSubSection |opFamily=CHOP |sectionName=Configs |sectionSummary=The DepthaiTestSuite.toe project includes several base components which help control settings of an OAK camera by sending messages via an OAK Device CHOP. For example, the oakDeviceConfig base enables the user to set the XLinkChunkSize, logging level, and infrared laser settings of a device. The oakCameraControl base helps control RGB camera settings. The oakStereoDepthConfig base helps control stereo depth settings. It is possible to use these configs while the camera is running.}}{{OPSubSection |opFamily=CHOP |sectionName=Optimizing Latency and FPS |sectionSummary=Luxonis has a tutorial on [https://docs.luxonis.com/projects/api/en/latest/tutorials/low-latency/ low latency]. In some cases such as streaming 4K video, you'll want to set [https://docs.luxonis.com/projects/api/en/latest/references/python/?highlight=xlinkchunksize#depthai.GlobalProperties.xlinkChunkSize:~:text=disables%20consistent%20timesyncing-,setXLinkChunkSize,-(self%3A XLinkChunkSize] to zero. This can be done with the oakDeviceConfig. When creating depthai pipelines, it's possible to set FPS targets for various nodes such as the [https://docs.luxonis.com/projects/api/en/latest/components/nodes/color_camera/ ColorCamera] node. In general, the FPS cannot be changed after the pipeline has been loaded on the camera. You should pick high FPS values, but keep in mind that if you push these numbers too high, you may see the effective FPS as shown by an Info CHOP begin to fall.}} See Also: [[OAK-D]], [[OAK Select CHOP]], [[OAK Select TOP]]}} {{ParameterPage |opFamily=CHOP |pageName=OAK |pageSummary= |items={{Parameter |opFamily=CHOP |opType=oakdeviceCHOP |parLabel=Active |parName=active |parType=Toggle |parReadOnly= |parOrder=0 |parSummary= |parItems= }} {{Parameter |opFamily=CHOP |opType=oakdeviceCHOP |parLabel=Sensor |parName=sensor |parType=StrMenu |parReadOnly= |parOrder=1 |parSummary=Select the available OAK Device from the dropdown. |parItems= }} {{Parameter |opFamily=CHOP |opType=oakdeviceCHOP |parLabel=Refresh Sensor List |parName=refreshpulse |parType=Pulse |parReadOnly= |parOrder=2 |parSummary=Refresh the list of available Sensors. |parItems= }} {{Parameter |opFamily=CHOP |opType=oakdeviceCHOP |parLabel=Initialize |parName=initialize |parType=Pulse |parReadOnly= |parOrder=3 |parSummary=Initialize is the signal to get the OAK Device into a ready state: The onInitialize() callback is run and on succesfully concluding will run the createPipeline() callback. It indicates that its ready by turning the ready channel on. |parItems= }} {{Parameter |opFamily=CHOP |opType=oakdeviceCHOP |parLabel=Start |parName=start |parType=Pulse |parReadOnly= |parOrder=4 |parSummary= |parItems= }} {{Parameter |opFamily=CHOP |opType=oakdeviceCHOP |parLabel=Play |parName=play |parType=Toggle |parReadOnly= |parOrder=5 |parSummary=The built-in Play parameter can toggle whether or not TouchDesigner processes the new messages it receives from the camera. For example, suppose multiple OAK Select CHOPs or TOPs are connected to the same OAK Device CHOP. By toggling play off, you will make all the OAK Select operators continue to receive whatever their most recently received message was, ignoring any new messages. |parItems= }} {{Parameter |opFamily=CHOP |opType=oakdeviceCHOP |parLabel=Go to Done |parName=gotodone |parType=Pulse |parReadOnly= |parOrder=6 |parSummary= |parItems= }} {{Parameter |opFamily=CHOP |opType=oakdeviceCHOP |parLabel=Callbacks DAT |parName=callbacks |parType=DAT |parReadOnly= |parOrder=7 |parSummary=The path to the DAT containing callbacks for this OAK Device CHOP. |parItems= }} }} {{ParameterPage |opFamily=CHOP |pageName=Stream In |pageSummary=The built-in page named Stream In helps with sending RGBA 8-bit images from TouchDesigner to an OAK camera. You can specify a TOP, a stream name, and a sending frequency in Hertz. If the stream name is blank, nothing will be sent. When sending images to the OAK, TouchDesigner will convert the input image to BGR format. This is convenient because most of the neural networks which can be run on the OAK camera expect the input images to be BGR format. If you require the image to be something else, you should use the [https://docs.luxonis.com/projects/api/en/latest/components/nodes/image_manip/ ImageManip] node in your depthai pipeline to change the format. |items={{Parameter |opFamily=CHOP |opType=oakdeviceCHOP |parLabel=Stream Name 0 |parName=streamname0 |parType=Str |parReadOnly= |parOrder=0 |parSummary=Specify the name of the stream that can receive textures. The stream needs to be created in the depthai pipeline by creating a XLinkIn node: pipeline.create(dai.node.XLinkIn) |parItems= }} {{Parameter |opFamily=CHOP |opType=oakdeviceCHOP |parLabel=Stream Frequency (Hz) |parName=streamfrequency0 |parType=Float |parReadOnly= |parOrder=1 |parSummary=Specify the frequency at which a texture is being send to the OAK device. |parItems= }} {{Parameter |opFamily=CHOP |opType=oakdeviceCHOP |parLabel=TOP |parName=top0 |parType=TOP |parReadOnly= |parOrder=2 |parSummary=Specify the TOP operator that contains the texture to be send to the stream. |parItems= }} }} {{ParameterPage |opFamily=CHOP |pageName=Outputs |pageSummary= |items={{Parameter |opFamily=CHOP |opType=oakdeviceCHOP |parLabel=Initializing |parName=outinit |parType=Toggle |parReadOnly= |parOrder=0 |parSummary=Outputs channel initializing = 1 while the OAK Device is initalizing (i.e. while the callback onInitialize() returns non-zero). |parItems= }} {{Parameter |opFamily=CHOP |opType=oakdeviceCHOP |parLabel=Initialize Fail |parName=outinitfail |parType=Toggle |parReadOnly= |parOrder=1 |parSummary=Outputs channel initialize_fail = 1 if the OAK Device ran into an error while initializing or creating the pipeline. |parItems= }} {{Parameter |opFamily=CHOP |opType=oakdeviceCHOP |parLabel=Ready |parName=outready |parType=Toggle |parReadOnly= |parOrder=2 |parSummary=Outputs channel ready which is 1 after an Initialize and before a Start. |parItems= }} {{Parameter |opFamily=CHOP |opType=oakdeviceCHOP |parLabel=Running |parName=outrunning |parType=Toggle |parReadOnly= |parOrder=3 |parSummary=Outputs channel running which is 1 after a Start and before the Done. |parItems= }} {{Parameter |opFamily=CHOP |opType=oakdeviceCHOP |parLabel=Done |parName=outdone |parType=Toggle |parReadOnly= |parOrder=4 |parSummary=Outputs channel done = 1 when done or complete. |parItems= }} {{Parameter |opFamily=CHOP |opType=oakdeviceCHOP |parLabel=Timer Count |parName=outtimercount |parType=Menu |parReadOnly= |parOrder=5 |parSummary= |parItems={{ParameterItem |opFamily=CHOP |parName=outtimercount |itemLabel=Off |itemName=off |itemSummary= }}{{ParameterItem |opFamily=CHOP |parName=outtimercount |itemLabel=Seconds |itemName=seconds |itemSummary= }}{{ParameterItem |opFamily=CHOP |parName=outtimercount |itemLabel=Frames |itemName=frames |itemSummary= }}{{ParameterItem |opFamily=CHOP |parName=outtimercount |itemLabel=Samples |itemName=samples |itemSummary= }}{{ParameterItem |opFamily=CHOP |parName=outtimercount |itemLabel=All |itemName=all |itemSummary= }} }} {{Parameter |opFamily=CHOP |opType=oakdeviceCHOP |parLabel=Running Time Count |parName=outrunningcount |parType=Menu |parReadOnly= |parOrder=6 |parSummary=Outputs the "wall-clock" time since Start occurred, no matter if the device's Play parameter was turned off or not. Will stop counting when the Done state has been reached. |parItems={{ParameterItem |opFamily=CHOP |parName=outrunningcount |itemLabel=Off |itemName=off |itemSummary= }}{{ParameterItem |opFamily=CHOP |parName=outrunningcount |itemLabel=Seconds |itemName=seconds |itemSummary= }}{{ParameterItem |opFamily=CHOP |parName=outrunningcount |itemLabel=Frames |itemName=frames |itemSummary= }}{{ParameterItem |opFamily=CHOP |parName=outrunningcount |itemLabel=Samples |itemName=samples |itemSummary= }}{{ParameterItem |opFamily=CHOP |parName=outrunningcount |itemLabel=All |itemName=all |itemSummary= }} }} }} {{:CHOP Generator Common Page}} {{InfoCHOPChannels |opFamily=CHOP |opLabel=oakdevice |infoChannels= }} {{SeeAlso |opFamily=CHOP |items=OAK-D, OAK Select CHOP, OAK Select TOP }} {{History}} {{NavBox |Category=CHOPs }} {{#invoke:Category|list|CHOPs}}

{{Summary |opFamily=CHOP |opType=oakselectCHOP |opLabel=OAK Select |opClass=oakselectCHOP_Class |opFilter=False |opLicense=Non-Commercial |opCategories= |short=Access a stream of the [[OAK Device CHOP]] |long=The OAK Select CHOP is like a [[Script CHOP]] combined with a [[Select CHOP]], and any of the other hardware-specific CHOPs. The basic operation involves providing an [[OAK Device CHOP]] and a stream name. In the simplest case, the stream's data will show up as well-named channels. For example, [https://docs.luxonis.com/projects/api/en/latest/components/messages/img_detections/ ImgDetections] messages indicating the 2D coordinates and labels of detected objects will show up as CHOP channels without any manual coding. In more complex cases such as hand landmark tracking, the stream may be of [https://docs.luxonis.com/projects/api/en/latest/components/messages/nn_data/ NNData] or [https://docs.luxonis.com/projects/api/en/latest/components/messages/buffer/ Buffer] type, requiring the user to implement a callback and parse the data. }} {{ParameterPage |opFamily=CHOP |pageName=OAK |pageSummary= |items={{Parameter |opFamily=CHOP |opType=oakselectCHOP |parLabel=Active |parName=active |parType=Toggle |parReadOnly= |parOrder=0 |parSummary=Toggle whether the OAK Select CHOP cooks. |parItems= }} {{Parameter |opFamily=CHOP |opType=oakselectCHOP |parLabel=OAK Device CHOP |parName=chop |parType=CHOP |parReadOnly= |parOrder=1 |parSummary=An OAK Device CHOP running a depthai pipeline. |parItems= }} {{Parameter |opFamily=CHOP |opType=oakselectCHOP |parLabel=Stream |parName=stream |parType=StrMenu |parReadOnly= |parOrder=2 |parSummary=The name of the stream to be received. |parItems= }} {{Parameter |opFamily=CHOP |opType=oakselectCHOP |parLabel=Queue Size |parName=queuesize |parType=Int |parReadOnly= |parOrder=3 |parSummary=For memory efficiency, this parameter controls the number of messages TouchDesigner reuses when receiving messages from OAK. See "Queue Size" below. |parItems= }} {{Parameter |opFamily=CHOP |opType=oakselectCHOP |parLabel=Max Items |parName=maxitems |parType=Int |parReadOnly= |parOrder=4 |parSummary=This parameter helps the OAK Select CHOP output a consistent number of channels. When running an image detection pipeline, the number of detected items will vary from frame to frame, but we want TouchDesigner to output a consistent number of channels. |parItems= }} {{Parameter |opFamily=CHOP |opType=oakselectCHOP |parLabel=Output Format |parName=outputformat |parType=Menu |parReadOnly= |parOrder=5 |parSummary=The default option "Items As Separate Channels" enables time-slicing while "Items as Separate Samples" does not. If the stream is one which automatically fills in the CHOP, then "Items as Separate Samples" is a useful way to make the CHOP output '''Max Items''' samples consistently. |parItems={{ParameterItem |opFamily=CHOP |parName=outputformat |itemLabel=Items As Separate Channels |itemName=itemsaschannels |itemSummary= }}{{ParameterItem |opFamily=CHOP |parName=outputformat |itemLabel=Items As Separate Samples |itemName=itemsassamples |itemSummary= }} }} {{Parameter |opFamily=CHOP |opType=oakselectCHOP |parLabel=Use First Sample Only |parName=firstsample |parType=Toggle |parReadOnly= |parOrder=6 |parSummary=Only use the most recently received message with the OAK Select CHOP. For example, for an IMU stream which is sending very high-frame rate data, toggling this parameter will only show the latest sample. |parItems= }} {{Parameter |opFamily=CHOP |opType=oakselectCHOP |parLabel=Sample Rate |parName=rate |parType=Float |parReadOnly= |parOrder=7 |parSummary=The sample rate of the CHOP. The default sample rate is me.time.rate. |parItems= }} {{Parameter |opFamily=CHOP |opType=oakselectCHOP |parLabel=Callbacks DAT |parName=callbacks |parType=DAT |parReadOnly= |parOrder=8 |parSummary=Specifies the DAT which holds the callbacks. |parItems= }} {{Parameter |opFamily=CHOP |opType=oakselectCHOP |parLabel=Setup Parameters |parName=setuppars |parType=Pulse |parReadOnly= |parOrder=9 |parSummary=Clicking the button runs the setupParameters() callback function. |parItems= }} }} {{:CHOP Generator Common Page}} {{InputsPage |opFamily=CHOP |opInputs=}} {{InfoCHOPChannels |opFamily=CHOP |opLabel=oakselect |infoChannels=}} {{SeeAlso |opFamily=CHOP |items=}} {{History}} {{NavBox |Category=CHOPs}} {{#invoke:Category|list|CHOPs}} ===Script CHOP Functionality=== The OAK Select CHOP mimics the [[Script CHOP]] in several ways. There's a callback for onSetupParameters, where custom parameters can be added. Also, in the other callbacks such as onReceiveNNData, onReceiveBuffer, and onReceiveSystemInformation it's possible to append channels and write data. When implementing a custom callback like below, if you want to disable time-slicing or set the number of output samples, the '''Output Format''' parameter should be "Items as Separate Samples". import depthai as dai def onReceiveNNData(oakSelectOp, oakNnData: dai.NNData): oakSelectOp.clear() oakSelectOp.appendChan('foo') oakSelectOp.numSamples = 1 # Output Format must be "Items as Separate Samples" oakSelectOp['foo'][0] = 42 return ===Queue Size=== The Queue Size parameter helps TouchDesigner avoid holding onto too many messages while also re-using memory for a minimum number of messages. For example, picking 2 is a good choice because TouchDesigner can show 1 message to the user while 1 remaining message can asynchronously be written to with new data. However, if the stream is meant to be high frame-rate, such as [https://docs.luxonis.com/projects/api/en/latest/components/messages/imu_data/ IMU] data, then the queue size should be at least double the number of messages you expect to receive in a single TouchDesigner frame. If TouchDesigner were to drop a video frame, then the next cook would want to use two times the number of messages that would have normally be shown, requiring the queue size to be at least twice as large. ===Max Items=== Some messages can be described as items. For example, [https://docs.luxonis.com/projects/api/en/latest/components/messages/img_detections/ ImgDetections] can be grouped into item0's channels, item1's channels, item2's channels and so on. For these kinds of streams, it can be helpful to have a constant number of channels in the OAK Select CHOP, regardless of whether an item exists in the most recent message. ===Output Format=== The default Output Format is "Items as Separate Channels". For example, when receiving [https://docs.luxonis.com/projects/api/en/latest/components/messages/img_detections/ ImgDetections] from MobileNet, each detection would require 6 channels ("confidence", "label", "xmin", "xmax", "ymin", "ymax"). The total number of channels would be 6 times the '''Max Items''' built-in parameter. In this situation, time-slicing is enabled, so the number of samples will vary according to time-slicing. If you're willing to sacrifice time-slicing, you can set the output format to "Items as Separate Samples". This will shuffle the latest messages into 6 channels by '''Max Items''' samples. In other words, each ImgDetection item will correspond to a CHOP sample. Another reason to use "Items as Separate Samples" is if you're implementing a callback such as onReceiveNNData and need to set the number of samples (oakSelectOp.numSamples = 1). ===Use First Sample Only=== Like the [[Shuffle CHOP]], the '''Use First Sample Only''' parameter makes it easy to only use the most recently received message with the OAK Select CHOP. For example, an IMU stream might be sending very high-frame rate data, and toggling this parameter on would be like using a [[Trim CHOP]] in "Absolute" value mode to only show the latest sample. ===Info CHOP=== When an [[OAK Select CHOP]] is connected to an [[Info CHOP]], in addition to the regular cook-related channels, there will be a few OAK-specific ones: * sequence_num: (see "sequenceNum" in the depthai [https://docs.luxonis.com/projects/api/en/latest/components/messages/img_detections/ documentation]) * messages_received: the total number of messages received with stream name set on the OAK Select CHOP * fps: The effective frames-per-second of this stream, i.e., how quickly TouchDesigner is receiving messages. This is not the target FPS of the stream. ===See Also=== * [[OAK-D]] * [[OAK Device CHOP]] * [[OAK Select TOP]]

{{Summary |opLicense=Non-Commercial |opClass=objectCHOP_Class |opFamily=CHOP |long=The Object CHOP compares two objects and outputs channels containing their raw or relative positions and orientations. The information that can be output is: * Position of one object relative to another * Rotation of one object relative to another * Bearing of one object relative to another * Single Bearing Angle between two objects * Distance between the origin of two objects * Inverse Square of the Distance between two objects The optional two inputs allow you to compare X,Y,Z points in world space with objects or each other. The inputs are expected to have three channels containing XYZ points (three channels with the suffix x, y and z). Alternatively, they can be in the standard transform formats as described by the [[Transform CHOP]] help. These inputs replace the target and/or reference objects. Object and points can be compared with each other, but "Rotation" mode will always return zero. See also the [[SOP to CHOP]] and the [[Parameter CHOP]]. They retrieve other information from [[object]]s and [[SOP]]s. |short=The Object CHOP compares two objects and outputs channels containing their raw or relative positions and orientations. |opFilter=False |opType=object |opLabel=Object |opCategories= }} {{ParameterPage |items= {{Parameter|parLabel=DAT Table |parOrder=0 |parSummary=Uses a [[Table DAT]] to specify the target and reference objects to use. The first column will be the target objects while the second column will be the reference objects. No headers are used. |opFamily=CHOP |opType=object |parName=dat |parType=DAT |parReadOnly= |parItems=}} {{Parameter|parLabel=Target Object |parOrder=1 |parSummary=The object that is being compared to the position of the reference object. The Target Object can be expressed as a text string. This can be useful when the object name needs to be a variable - it allows you to type in a name which may include expressions or variables. |opFamily=CHOP |opType=object |parName=target |parType=Object |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|parLabel=Reference Object |parOrder=2 |parSummary=The object that acts as the origin of the comparison. The Reference Object can be expressed as a text string. |opFamily=CHOP |opType=object |parName=reference |parType=Object |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|parLabel=Swap Target/Reference |parOrder=3 |parSummary=Swap the objects defined above in the Target Object and Reference Object parameters. |opFamily=CHOP |opType=object |parName=swaptargetreference |parType=Toggle |parReadOnly= |parItems=}} |pageName=Object |pageSummary= |opFamily=CHOP }} {{ParameterPage |items= {{Parameter |opFamily=CHOP |opType=objectCHOP |parLabel=Compute |parName=compute |parType=Menu |parReadOnly= |parOrder=0 |parSummary=Specify the information to output from the objects as described in the parameters below. Except for 'measurements', these match the standard transform formats as described by the [[Transform CHOP]]. |parItems={{ParameterItem |opFamily=CHOP |parName=compute |itemLabel=Transform (Euler) |itemName=transform |itemSummary=A transform using euler (rx ry rz) for the rotation. }}{{ParameterItem |opFamily=CHOP |parName=compute |itemLabel=Transform (Quaternion) |itemName=transformquat |itemSummary=A transform using quaternion (qx qy qz qw) for the rotation. }}{{ParameterItem |opFamily=CHOP |parName=compute |itemLabel=4x4 Matrix |itemName=mat |itemSummary=A 4x4 transform matrix. }}{{ParameterItem |opFamily=CHOP |parName=compute |itemLabel=3x3 Matrix |itemName=mat3 |itemSummary=A 3x3 transform matrix. This includes scale/rotation but no translation. }}{{ParameterItem |opFamily=CHOP |parName=compute |itemLabel=Measurements |itemName=measure |itemSummary=Enables the toggles below to select what to measure. That is, you get the XYZ of the target object's origin as if you were at the 0,0,0 location (origin) of the Reference Object, looking down the Reference Object's Z-axis. }} }} {{Parameter |opFamily=CHOP |opType=objectCHOP |parLabel=Position |parName=translate |parType=Toggle |parReadOnly= |parOrder=1 |parSummary=The displacement from the reference object to the target object. |parItems= }} {{Parameter |opFamily=CHOP |opType=objectCHOP |parLabel=Rotation |parName=rotate |parType=Toggle |parReadOnly= |parOrder=2 |parSummary=The orientation difference from the reference object to the target object. |parItems= }} {{Parameter |opFamily=CHOP |opType=objectCHOP |parLabel=Scale |parName=scale |parType=Toggle |parReadOnly= |parOrder=3 |parSummary=The scale difference from reference object to the target object. |parItems= }} {{Parameter |opFamily=CHOP |opType=objectCHOP |parLabel=Quaternion |parName=quat |parType=Toggle |parReadOnly= |parOrder=4 |parSummary=The quaternion from reference object to the target object. |parItems= }} {{Parameter |opFamily=CHOP |opType=objectCHOP |parLabel=Bearing |parName=bear |parType=Toggle |parReadOnly= |parOrder=5 |parSummary=The rotation necessary for the reference object to be facing the target object. |parItems= }} {{Parameter |opFamily=CHOP |opType=objectCHOP |parLabel=Single Bearing Angle |parName=singlebear |parType=Toggle |parReadOnly= |parOrder=6 |parSummary=An angle representing where the target object is relative to the reference object. Zero degrees is directly in front, 90 degrees is beside and 180 degrees is behind. |parItems= }} {{Parameter |opFamily=CHOP |opType=objectCHOP |parLabel=Distance |parName=distance |parType=Toggle {{Summary			
	|opFilter=False		
	|long=The Oculus Rift CHOP connects to an [[Oculus Rift]] device and outputs several useful sets of channels that can be used to integrate the Oculus Rift into projects.		
			
You can view the detected orientation of the device and put the rotation values directly into other operators. To help decrease latency, prediction can be used to guess what the orientation will be at some point in the future.			
			
The raw sensor data is also available, with options for both sensor acceleration and angular velocity.			
			
The devices calibration parameters are another option. These can be used to generate the projection matrices and distortion shaders, although both of these are already available (see below and [[Oculus Rift TOP]]). This data is constant, but may differ on future devices.			
			
The last two things the Oculus Rift CHOP can output are the left and right eye projection matrices. These can be (and will need to be) passed into a camera's "Custom Projection" parameter in order to provide a proper 3D experience with the Oculus Rift. For convenience, the channels are aligned to be passed in directly by reference.			
			
Without an Oculus Rift device connected the CHOP uses default values and will output channels corresponding to the Oculus Rift Developer Kit device. This allows you to design something for the Oculus Rift without actually having one.			
			
See also [[Oculus Rift]]			
	|opLicense=Non-Commercial		
	|opClass=oculusriftCHOP_Class		
	|opLabel=Oculus Rift

	|opType=oculusrift
    |os=Microsoft Windows
	|short=The Oculus Rift CHOP connects to an [[Oculus Rift]] device and outputs several useful sets of channels that can be used to integrate the Oculus Rift into projects.		
|opCategories=		
	}}

{{Summary
	|opFilter=False
	|long=The OpenVR CHOP receives positional data, frame rendering info, and action data from the [[OpenVR]] SDK. Each CHOP can output in one of 5 modes: Sensors, Projection Matrices, Trackers, Frame Timings, Actions and Skeletons.

=== Actions ===

Actions are described in more details in [[OpenVR Actions]].
			
=== Getting Sensor Data at Higher Rates ===			
			
By default when running a VR system the file will be throttled to the speed of the VR devices refresh rate by the OpenVR SDK. This helps ensure the low latency output required for a good VR experience. If only controllers/Vive trackers are being used for tracking in a non-VR situation, the file can run and sample those devices at a higher sample rate as long as no [[OpenVR TOP]] in the project. If an [[OpenVR TOP]] is present anywhere in the project, then playback will be throttled to the VR devices refresh rate.			
			
See also [[OpenVR]], [[OpenVR TOP]], [[OpenVR SOP]], [[Audio Render CHOP]]

{{Summary |opFilter=False |long=The OSC In CHOP is used to accept Open Sound Control Messages. OSC In can be used to accept messages from either a 3rd party application which adheres to the Open Sound Control specification (http://www.cnmat.berkeley.edu/OpenSoundControl/). OSC In is based on a connection-less system, meaning that it can accept multiple messages for any number of sources at the same time. The user must specify a port number which OSC In will look for incoming messages. This port must not have anything running on it before OSC In attempts to use it. OSC CHOPs in TouchDesigner use the UDP transport protocol. See also [[OSC_In_DAT|OSC In DAT]], [[OSC Out CHOP]], [[iOS and OSC]], [[Touch In CHOP]]. There are options which allow the user to adjust the default message queuing system to optimize it for their specific network conditions and usage needs. The Min/Max Target size specifies a range which the queue attempts to keep the buffer size at in seconds. Increasing the Queue Adjust Time will determine how long the queue can be outside that range before it tries to correct it. If the user wishes to use OSC In to detect when messages are arriving, there is a Pulse Mode toggle which will read a single sample of any incoming message when it arrives and displays the pulse reset values any other time. This is useful for syncing beats between TouchDesigner and another applications. '''NOTE for Windows OS - If experiencing connection issues make sure Windows Firewall is disabled.''' |opLicense=Non-Commercial |opClass=oscinCHOP_Class |opLabel=OSC In |opFamily=CHOP |opType=oscin |short=The OSC In CHOP is used to accept Open Sound Control Messages. |opCategories= }} {{ParameterPage |opFamily=CHOP |pageName=OSC In |items= {{Parameter|parName=active |parOrder=3 |parLabel=Active |opFamily=CHOP |opType=oscin |parSummary=While on, the CHOP receives information sent to the network port. While Off, no updating occurs. Data sent to the port is lost. |parType=Toggle |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|parName=protocol |parItems= {{ParameterItem|itemName=msging |opFamily=CHOP |parName=protocol |itemLabel=Messaging (UDP) |itemSummary= }}{{ParameterItem|itemName=multicastmsging |opFamily=CHOP |parName=protocol |itemLabel=Multi-Cast Messaging (UDP) |itemSummary= }} |parOrder=0 |parLabel=Protocol |opFamily=CHOP |opType=oscin |parSummary=The network protocol to use. Refer to the [[Network Protocols]] article for more information. |parType=Menu |parReadOnly= }} {{Parameter|parName=netaddress |parOrder=1 |parLabel=Network Address |opFamily=CHOP |opType=oscin |parSummary=When using Multicast, this is the address that OSC In will listen for packets on. |parType=Str |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|parName=port |parOrder=2 |parLabel=Network Port |opFamily=CHOP |opType=oscin |parSummary=The port which OSC-In will accept packets on. |parType=Int |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|opFamily=CHOP |parName=localaddress |parLabel=Local Address |parOrder=3 |opType=oscin |parSummary=Specify an IP address to receive on, useful when the system has mulitple NICs (Network Interface Card) and you want to select which one to use. |parType=StrMenu |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|parName=oscaddressscope |parOrder=4 |parLabel=OSC Address Scope |opFamily=CHOP |opType=oscin |parSummary=To reduce which channels are generated, you can use channel name patterns to include or exclude channels. For example, ^*accel* will exclude accelerometer channels coming in from an iPhone or iOS app like mrmr. See [[Pattern Matching]] for the syntax of the possible channel name patterns. |parType=Str |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|parName=useglobalrate |parOrder=5 |parLabel=Use Global Rate |opFamily=CHOP |opType=oscin |parSummary=When on, the CHOP will sample at the ''global'' sample rate specified by TouchDesigner. |parType=Toggle |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|parName=samplerate |parOrder=6 |parLabel=Default Sample Rate |opFamily=CHOP |opType=oscin |parSummary=When Use Global Rate is off, this parameter is used to determine the sample rate of this CHOP. |parType=Int |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|parName=queued |parOrder=7 |parLabel=Queued |opFamily=CHOP |opType=oscin |parSummary=Turn this on to enable queuing to help avoid lost messages. Use the parameters below to setup the queue behavior. |parType=Toggle |parReadOnly= |p {{Parameter|parSummary=The target queue length the CHOP will attempt to maintain. |opFamily=CHOP |parName=queuetarget |parOrder=4 |opType=touchin |parLabel=Queue Target |parType=Float |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|parOrder=5 |parSummary=Choose between using Samples, Frames, or Seconds as the units for this parameter. |opFamily=CHOP |parName=queuetargetunit |parItems= |opType=touchin |parLabel=Queue Target Unit |parType=Menu |parReadOnly=}} |parItems=}} {{Parameter|parSummary=The range around the Queue Target that's acceptable. If the queue's length is within the target and variance range, the CHOP will not bother to adjust the queue length. |opFamily=CHOP |parName=queuevariance |parOrder=6 |opType=touchin |parLabel=Queue Variance |parType=Float |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|parOrder=7 |parSummary=Choose between using Samples, Frames, or Seconds as the units for this parameter. |opFamily=CHOP |parName=queuevarianceunit |parItems= |opType=touchin |parLabel=Queue Variance Unit |parType=Menu |parReadOnly=}} {{Parameter|parSummary=The maximum size of the queue when full. Incoming samples will be dropped if the maximum queue is reached. |opFamily=CHOP |parName=maxqueue |parOrder=8 |opType=touchin |parLabel=Maximum Queue |parType= |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|parOrder=9 |parSummary=Choose between using Samples, Frames, or Seconds as the units for this parameter. |opFamily=CHOP |parName=maxqueueunit |parItems= |opType=touchin |parLabel=Max Queue Unit |parType= |parReadOnly=}} {{Parameter|parSummary=Specifies how often to repeat/drop a samples in order to get closer to the queue target range. If the value = 1 and the units = seconds, then it will try to repeat/drop a sample once per second to maintain the queue target set in the Minimum Target and Maximum Target parameters above. |opFamily=CHOP |parName=adjusttime |parOrder=10 |opType=touchin |parLabel=Queue Adjust Time |parType=Float |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|parOrder=11 |parSummary=Choose between using Samples, Frames, or Seconds as the units for this parameter. |opFamily=CHOP |parName=adjusttimeunit |parItems= |opType=touchin |parLabel=Adjust Unit |parType=Menu |parReadOnly=}} {{Parameter|parName=stripsegments |parOrder=15 |parLabel=Strip Prefix Segments |opFamily=CHOP |opType=oscin |parSummary=Strip a number of prefixes from the incoming address. {{Summary |opFilter=True |long=TheOSC Out CHOP sends all input channels to a specified network address and port. Each channel name and associated data is transmitted together to the specified location. TouchDesigner time stamps all outgoing Open Sound Control messages with the time of the outgoing frame relative to the system time when the first message was sent. OSC CHOPs in TouchDesigner use the UDP transport protocol. OSC Out will either send all the channels each cook or it will only send each channel depending on if it has changed at all since the last time it was sent. This is determined by the Send Events Every Cook flag. OSC bundles allows you to send a group of messages in a single command rather than as separate, individual messages. The[[OSC Out DAT]] has a sendOSC() function that will accept a list of messages and send as a bundle. See also [[OSC In CHOP]], [[OSC Out DAT]], [[OSC In DAT]], [[iOS and OSC]], [[Touch Out CHOP]], [[UDP Out DAT]], [[TCP/IP DAT]]. '''NOTE for Windows OS - If experiencing connection issues make sure Windows Firewall is disabled.''' |opLicense=Non-Commercial |opClass=oscoutCHOP_Class |opLabel=OSC Out |opFamily=CHOP |opType=oscout |short=The OSC Out CHOP sends all input channels to a specified network address and port. |opCategories= }} {{ParameterPage |opFamily=CHOP |pageName=OSC Out |items= {{Parameter|parName=active |parOrder=3 |parLabel=Active |opFamily=CHOP |opType=oscout |parSummary=While On, the CHOP sends information to the network port. When Off, data is not sent. |parType=Toggle |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|parName=protocol |parItems= {{ParameterItem|itemName=msging |opFamily=CHOP |parName=protocol |itemLabel=Messaging (UDP) |itemSummary= }}{{ParameterItem|itemName=multicastmsging |opFamily=CHOP |parName=protocol |itemLabel=Multi-Cast Messaging (UDP) |itemSummary= }}{{ParameterItem|itemName=reliablemsging |opFamily=CHOP |parName=protocol |itemLabel=Reliable Messaging (UDT Library) |itemSummary= }} |parOrder=0 |parLabel=Protocol |opFamily=CHOP |opType=oscout |parSummary=Selects the network protocol to use. Refer to the [[Network Protocols]] article for more information. |parType=Menu |parReadOnly= }} {{Parameter|parName=netaddress |parOrder=1 |parLabel=Network Address |opFamily=CHOP |opType=oscout |parSummary=The network address of the server computer. This address is a standard WWW address, such as 'foo' or 'foo.bar.com'. You can put an IP address (e.g. 100.123.45.78). If you put "localhost", it means the other end of the pipe is on the same computer. |parType=Str |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|parName=port |parOrder=2 |parLabel=Network Port |opFamily=CHOP |opType=oscout |parSummary=The port which OSC Out will send packets to. |parType=Int |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|parName=localaddress |parOrder=2 |parLabel=Local Address |opFamily=CHOP |opType=oscout |parSummary=Specify an IP address to send from, useful when the system has mulitple NICs (Network Interface Card) and you want to select which one to use. |parType=StrMenu |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|parName=maxsize |parOrder=4 |parLabel=Max Queue Size |opFamily=CHOP |opType=oscout |parSummary=Specifies the maximum number of messages OSC Out will try to send at a single time. |parType=Float |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|parName=maxsizeunit |parItems= |parOrder=5 |parLabel=Max Queue Size Unit |opFamily=CHOP |opType=oscout |parSummary=Select the units to use for this parameter, Samples, Frames, or Seconds |parType=Menu |parReadOnly= }} {{Parameter|parName=cookalways |parOrder=6 |parLabel=Cook Every Frame |opFamily=CHOP |opType=oscout |parSummary=Specifies that this CHOP should be cooked every frame regardless of CHOPs below it are cooking. |parType=Toggle |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|parName=numericformat |parItems= {{ParameterItem|itemName=int |opFamily=CHOP |parName=numericformat |itemLabel=Int (32 bit) |itemSummary= }}{{ParameterItem|itemName=float |opFamily=CHOP |parName=numericformat |itemLabel=Float (32 bit) |itemSummary= }}{{ParameterItem|itemName=double |opFamily=CHOP |parName=numericformat |itemLabel=Double (64 bit) |itemSummary= }} |parOrder=7 |parLabel=Numeric Format |opFamily=CHOP {{Summary |opFilter=True |long=The Override CHOP lets you take inputs from several CHOP sources, and uses the most-recently changed input channels to determine the output. For example, if a 16-channel CHOP comes from one MIDI device, and another 16-channel CHOP comes from another place like another device or a preset, then Override selects the most recently-changed channels and outputs those values. The Override CHOP outputs the same channels as the first input. If subsequent inputs have more or less channels than the first input, the missing/extra channels are ignored. The output defaults to the channel values of the first input, but when a value changes in any monitored channel, that value will become the new output for the corresponding channel name or number. If the same channel name or number is changing in two or more inputs at the same time, precedence is given by input order. The Override CHOP output is reset to the default each time the number of inputs to the CHOP changes or the method of matching (by number or by name) changes. The CHOP length is the length of the first input. From frame to frame, if all values are the same, the output is unchanged. An optional channel can be created that will tell you which input has the most recently changed channel. |opLicense=Non-Commercial |opClass=overrideCHOP_Class |opLabel=Override |opFamily=CHOP |opType=override |short=The Override CHOP lets you take inputs from several CHOP sources, and uses the most-recently changed input channels to determine the output. |opCategories= }} {{ParameterPage |opFamily=CHOP |pageName=Override |items= {{Parameter|parName=match |parItems= {{ParameterItem|itemName=index |opFamily=CHOP |parName=match |itemLabel=Channel Number |itemSummary=Matches channels by their order number. }}{{ParameterItem|itemName=name |opFamily=CHOP |parName=match |itemLabel=Channel Name |itemSummary=Matches channels by their name. }} |parOrder=0 |parLabel=Match by |opFamily=CHOP |opType=override |parSummary=Monitors the channels in each input and matches them according to this menu. |parType=Menu |parReadOnly= }} {{Parameter|parName=makeindex |parOrder=1 |parLabel=Create Input Index |opFamily=CHOP |opType=override |parSummary=Creates a channel (specified by the Channel Name parameter below) that is an index indicating which input has the most recently changed channel. |parType=Toggle |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|parName=indexname |parOrder=2 |parLabel=Channel Name |opFamily=CHOP |opType=override |parSummary=Specifies the name of the index channel. Only used if the Create Input Index checkbox is selected. |parType=Str |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|parName=cookmonitor |parOrder=3 |parLabel=Monitor on Input Cooks |opFamily=CHOP |opType=override |parSummary=Deprecated. |parType=Toggle |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} |pageSummary= }} {{:CHOP Filter Common Page }} {{InputsPage |opFamily=CHOP |opInputs={{OPInput |opFamily=CHOP |inputIndex=0 |inputName= |inputSummary= }} }} {{InfoCHOPChannels |opFamily=CHOP |opLabel=Override |infoChannels=}} {{History }} {{CHOPNavBox |opFamily=CHOP }} {{#invoke:Category |list|CHOPs}}

{{Summary |opFilter=False |long=The Panel CHOP reads [[Panel Value]]s from [[Panel Component]]s into CHOP channels. Panel values can also be accessed by using the panel Member of the [[PanelCOMP Class]]. |opLicense=Non-Commercial |opClass=panelCHOP_Class |opLabel=Panel |opFamily=CHOP |opType=panel |short=The Panel CHOP reads [[Panel Value]]s from [[Panel Component]]s into CHOP channels. |opCategories= }} {{ParameterPage |opFamily=CHOP |pageName=Panel |items= {{Parameter|parName=component |parOrder=0 |parLabel=Component |opFamily=CHOP |opType=panel |parSummary=The path of the Component being referenced. |parType=PanelCOMP |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|parName=select |parItems= |parOrder=1 |parLabel=Select |opFamily=CHOP |opType=panel |parSummary=Specify which panel values to create channels for. Use * to select all panel values. Add individual values using the drop down menu on the right. |parType=StrMenu |parReadOnly= }} {{Parameter|parName=rename |parItems= |parOrder=2 |parLabel=Rename |opFamily=CHOP |opType=panel |parSummary=Rename the panel value channels selected with the Select parameter here. For example, if "u v" are selected in the Select parameter, you can rename these channels to horizontal and vertical by entering "horizontal vertical". |parType=StrMenu |parReadOnly= }} {{Parameter|parName=queue |parOrder=3 |parLabel=Queue Overlapping Events |opFamily=CHOP |opType=panel |parSummary=Queue all events that occur in a [[Time Slicing|time slice]]. Some [[Panel Value|panel values]], such as wheel or key, switches between a value and 0 in the same time slice and are considered instantaneous. When this parameter is off, only the last value in the time slice will be used, and changes could be missed. Turning this on will keep as many events as possible based on queue size. Each queued item will be released in the next time slice until the queue is empty, and value changes within the same time slice are synchronized. |parType=Toggle |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|parName=queuesize |parOrder=4 |parLabel=Queue Size |opFamily=CHOP |opType=panel |parSummary=Size of queue. If the number of events is larger than the queue size, earlier events will be discarded. |parType=Int |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} |pageSummary= }} {{:CHOP Generator Common Page }} {{InfoCHOPChannels |opFamily=CHOP |opLabel=Panel |infoChannels=}} {{History }} {{CHOPNavBox |opFamily=CHOP }} {{#invoke:Category |list|CHOPs}}

{{Summary
	|opFamily=CHOP
	|opType=pangolinCHOP
	|opLabel=Pangolin
	|opClass=pangolinCHOP_Class
	|opFilter=False
	|opLicense=Non-Commercial
    |os=Microsoft Windows
	|short=The Pangolin CHOP interfaces with Pangolin's Beyond.
	|long=The Pangolin CHOP interfaces with Pangolin's [https://pangolin.com/collections/beyond-software Beyond]. Beyond is a professional laser and multimedia show control application. When Beyond is running, the Pangolin CHOP will send laser image frames to it. The image frames are created from either a SOP input or CHOP input.
    
The Pangolin CHOP should work with any version of Beyond but it is recommended to use at least Beyond v5.1.
    
'''TouchDesigner Non-commercial will only work with the demo version of Beyond. TouchDesigner Commercial or Pro is required to interface with licensed versions of Beyond.'''
    
See also: [[Laser CHOP]].
	|opCategories=
	}}
{{OPSection
	|opFamily=CHOP
    |sectionName=Usage
    |sectionSummary=Beyond must be open to use the Pangolin CHOP. 

The Pangolin CHOP will construct a laser image from the points of a SOP or samples of a CHOP and send it to Beyond. With Beyond open and the Pangolin CHOP active (with input) the laser image can immediately be seen in its respective zone in the zone viewer of Beyond. See below an example of sending a circle to zone 1 in Beyond from the Pangolin CHOP.


[[File:PangolinTDZone.PNG|640px|frameless]]

}}

{{Summary |opFilter=False |long=The Pattern CHOP generates a sequence of samples in a channel. Unlike the [[Wave CHOP]] its purpose is generating arrays of samples that have no reference to time (seconds or frames). It is useful for curve generation like lookup tables, simple shapes that can be converted to SOPs, generating channels that are passed to the [[Geometry COMP]] to generate instances, and other non-time-based curve-generation, with as little need to make expressions in Python. All defaults are in samples, not seconds or frames (though like all CHOPs, it carries with it a sample rate). There is no start-end, just Length in samples. '''Tip''': To display a CHOP viewer in the units of samples, make the [[Viewer Active]] and change [[Mouse Click|RMB]] -> Units to be Samples. The Pattern CHOP optionally takes one input CHOP to match the length and sample rate, and, choosing via the Combine Channels menu, Appends or Inserts the new channel(s), Replaces the incoming channels, Adds to the incoming channels or Multiplies the incoming channels. The Pattern CHOP defaults to one cycle of the curve over the length of the CHOP, no matter how many samples long. '''Tip: Customizing each channel:''' The python object for the Pattern CHOP has a chanIndex member, so if Pattern generates three channels you can put something like [1, 3, 7][me.chanIndex] in any parameter to customize its value for each channel. {{Summary |opFilter=False |long=The Pattern CHOP generates a sequence of samples in a channel. Unlike the [[Wave CHOP]] its purpose is generating arrays of samples that have no reference to time (seconds or frames). It is useful for curve generation like lookup tables, simple shapes that can be converted to SOPs, generating channels that are passed to the [[Geometry COMP]] to generate instances, and other non-time-based curve-generation, with as little need to make expressions in Python. All defaults are in samples, not seconds or frames (though like all CHOPs, it carries with it a sample rate). There is no start-end, just Length in samples. '''Tip''': To display a CHOP viewer in the units of samples, make the [[Viewer Active]] and change [[Mouse Click|RMB]] -> Units to be Samples. The Pattern CHOP optionally takes one input CHOP to match the length and sample rate, and, choosing via the Combine Channels menu, Appends or Inserts the new channel(s), Replaces the incoming channels, Adds to the incoming channels or Multiplies the incoming channels. The Pattern CHOP defaults to one cycle of the curve over the length of the CHOP, no matter how many samples long. '''Tip: Customizing each channel:''' The python object for the Pattern CHOP has a chanIndex member, so if Pattern generates three channels you can put something like [1, 3, 7][me.chanIndex] in any parameter to customize its value for each channel. For example, in the Type parameter, put the expression ['sin', 'cos', 'ramp'][me.chanIndex] to get 3 different curve types. |opLicense=Non-Commercial |opClass=patternCHOP_Class |opLabel=Pattern |opFamily=CHOP |opType=pattern |short=The Pattern CHOP generates a sequence of samples in a channel. |opCategories= }} {{ParameterPage |opFamily=CHOP |pageName=Pattern |items={{Parameter |parName=wavetype |parItems={{ParameterItem |itemName=const |opFamily=CHOP |parName=wavetype |itemLabel=Constant |itemSummary=(1) }}{{ParameterItem |itemName=sin |opFamily=CHOP |parName=wavetype |itemLabel=Sine |itemSummary=(-1 to 1) }}{{ParameterItem |itemName=cos |opFamily=CHOP |parName=wavetype |itemLabel=Cosine |itemSummary=(-1 to 1) }}{{ParameterItem |itemName=tri |opFamily=CHOP |parName=wavetype |itemLabel=Triangle |itemSummary=(-1 to 1) }}{{ParameterItem |itemName=ramp |opFamily=CHOP |parName=wavetype |itemLabel=Ramp |itemSummary=(0-1) }}{{ParameterItem |itemName=rampsamples |opFamily=CHOP |parName=wavetype |itemLabel=Ramp Samples |itemSummary=(0 to numSamples-1) }}{{ParameterItem |itemName=square |opFamily=CHOP |parName=wavetype |itemLabel=Square |itemSummary=(-1 to -1) }}{{ParameterItem |itemName=pulse |opFamily=CHOP |parName=wavetype |itemLabel=Pulse |itemSummary=(0-1) }}{{ParameterItem |itemName=random |opFamily=CHOP |parName=wavetype |itemLabel=Random |itemSummary=(0-1) }}{{ParameterItem |itemName=randomcycle |opFamily=CHOP |parName=wavetype |itemLabel=Random per Cycle |itemSummary=All samples in a cycle will have the same randomly generated value. }}{{ParameterItem |itemName=randomnonrepint |opFamily=CHOP |parName=wavetype |itemLabel=Random Non-Repeating Integers |itemSummary=This wave type is used in conjunction with the Randomize pulse. {{Summary |opFilter=False |long=The Perform CHOP outputs many channels like frames-per-second, describing the current state of the TouchDesigner process. As channels they can be manipulated into user interfaces and calculations to adjust real-time self-tuning of the process. It outputs the "cook time" of the prior frame that was drawn, which is a reflection of how many frames TouchDesigner cooked in the prior second. The cook '''Tip''': Put a Trail CHOP after the Perform CHOP to watch its progress. channel, when sent to a Trail CHOP shows which frames were cooked and which were skipped, useful in optimizing your work to reach a desired frame rate. The Built-in Variables found on Dialogs -> Variables -> Built-in include more useful data on your running system. See also the Built-in Variables section of the [[Variables]] page. |opLicense=Non-Commercial |opClass=performCHOP_Class |opLabel=Perform |opFamily=CHOP |opType=perform |short=The Perform CHOP outputs many channels like frames-per-second, describing the current state of the TouchDesigner process. |opCategories= }} {{ParameterPage |opFamily=CHOP |pageName=Perform |items= {{Parameter|parName=fps |parOrder=0 |parLabel=Frames per Second |opFamily=CHOP |opType=perform |parSummary=The number of frames rendered in the last second. |parType=Toggle |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|parName=msec |parOrder=1 |parLabel=Frame Time |opFamily=CHOP |opType=perform |parSummary=Amount of time each frame takes to cook in msec. |parType=Toggle |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|parName=cook |parOrder=2 |parLabel=Cook |opFamily=CHOP |opType=perform |parSummary=Is equal to 1 when a frame is cooked and equal to 0 when a frame is skipped. It is often useful to view this channel in a [[Trail CHOP]] to see when frames are skipped (dropped). |parType=Toggle |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|parName=droppedframes |parOrder=3 |parLabel=Dropped Frames |opFamily=CHOP |opType=perform |parSummary=The number of frames dropped between the last frame and the current frame. |parType=Toggle |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} Read Ahead frames. |parType=Toggle |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|parName=gpumemused |parOrder=5 |parLabel=GPU Mem Used (MB) |opFamily=CHOP |opType=perform |parSummary=Amount of GPU memory {{Summary
	|opFamily=CHOP
	|opType=phaserCHOP
	|opLabel=Phaser
	|opClass=phaserCHOP_Class
	|opFilter=True
	|opLicense=Non-Commercial
	|short=The Phaser CHOP does staggered (time-offset) animation interpolation. Phaser outputs one channel with multi-samples. Each sample animates from 0 to 1 over a cycle, but each sample value rises from 0 and arrives at 1 at different times.
	|long=The Phaser CHOP does staggered (time-offset) animation interpolation. Phaser outputs one channel with multi-samples. Each sample animates from 0 to 1 over a cycle, but each sample value rises from 0 and arrives at 1 at different times.
    
For example, you may have a set of N objects that you want to animate from a start position to an end position. You set Num Samples to N, which will make the Phaser CHOP output one channel with N samples that will animate the samples from 0 to 1 and be interpolated with an easing function. In the Phaser CHOP the start-to-end cycle is controlled by the first input of the CHOP, which is expected to be one channel with value between 0 to 1. 

The 0-1 values can be used with the [[Lookup CHOP]] to animate groups of channels.

By default the timing is staggered uniformly.  If you want to stagger their transitions irregularly, you use the second input, a set of values in one CHOP channel (typically N samples) that are between 0 and 1. The phase value specifies the object's timing relationship with the rest of those in the CHOP. A phase value of 1 corresponds to an animated object thats "ahead of the pack" (ie. it will start animating before the others). A value of 0 corresponds to an object that is late (ie. it will be the last to start easing/animating). If a phase input is not provided then the phase will simply be i/N where N is the total number of objects (ie. samples), and i is the index of the current sample.
    
There is also a notion of an "Edge" in the Phaser, which describes the cohesiveness of the group of animated objects and how fast the samples rise. A small value will cause the objects to go through the animation very quickly or at high value, very slowly and in unison with other samples.

Look at David Braun's '''[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=S4PQW4f34c8 TouchDesigner Summit Talk]''' to see the background of the Phaser CHOP. Its functionality draws heavily from David's research and development in quantitative easing. 

See also the [[OP Snippets]].
	|opCategories=
	}}

	|parSummary=The separation edge of the phasing between two states. A smaller edge corresponds to sharper separation according to differences in phase. Edge Parameter will not be used if there is an Edge Input.

{{Summary |opLicense=Non-Commercial |opFamily=CHOP |short=The Pipe In CHOP allows users to input from custom devices into CHOPs. It is implemented as a TCP/IP network connection. |opType=pipein |opFilter=False |opClass=pipeinCHOP_Class |opLabel=Pipe In |long=The Pipe In CHOP allows users to input from custom devices into CHOPs. It is implemented as a TCP/IP network connection. The connection can be from a user-written program that outputs to the Pipe In CHOP's port, or from another TouchDesigner process, where the data is coming from a [[Pipe Out CHOP]]. Regular channel data sent to Pipe In outputs has CHOP channels (channel names with floating point values every frame). Mixed with it can be TouchDesigner scripting commands that get executed when they arrive. '''TIP:''' The [[TCP/IP DAT]] or [[UDP In DAT]] is the preferred way to send script commands and other data packets over the network. This node differs from the [[Touch In CHOP]] as it functions using a stream of commands, instead of a simple stream of channel data like the [[Touch In CHOP]]. Information comes in in various commands which are documented in the files located in your installation directory C:/Program Files/Derivative/TouchDesigner*/touch/docs/pipe. To receive network data from another "server" computer (e.g. from a TouchDesigner Pipe Out CHOP running remotely), a connection must be established between the server and the Pipe In CHOP before data is sent. You must supply the Server Address and Port from which to receive incoming data to a channel. The server should be listening for connections on the port that this CHOP is using. '''NOTE for Windows OS - If experiencing connection issues make sure Windows Firewall is disabled.''' See also [[Shared Mem In CHOP]]. |opCategories= }} {{ParameterPage |opFamily=CHOP |pageName=PipeIn |pageSummary= |items= {{Parameter|opFamily=CHOP |parName=mode |opType=pipein |parSummary=Set operation as server or client. |parOrder=0 |parLabel=Connection Mode |parItems= {{ParameterItem|opFamily=CHOP |parName=mode |itemName=client |itemSummary= |itemLabel=This Operator is Client }}{{ParameterItem|opFamily=CHOP |parName=mode |itemName=server |itemSummary= |itemLabel=This Operator is Server }} |parType=Menu |parReadOnly= }} {{Parameter|opFamily=CHOP |parName=address |opType=pipein |parSummary=The network address of the server computer. This address is a standard WWW address, such as 'foo' or 'foo.bar.com'. You can use an IP address (e.g. 100.123.45.78) or the computer's network name can be entered. If you put "localhost", it means the other end of the pipe is on the same computer. |parOrder=1 |parLabel=Server Address |parType=Str |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|opFamily=CHOP |parName=port |opType=pipein |parSummary=The network port of the server. |parOrder=2 |parLabel=Server Port |parType=Int |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|opFamily=CHOP |parName=active |opType=pipein |parSummary=While On, the CHOP receives information from the pipe or server. While Off, no updating occurs. Data sent by a server is lost, but a pipe will store the data until Active is turned on again. If in Network mode, turning this parameter on initiates a connection, and turning it off breaks the connection. |parOrder=3 |parLabel=Active |parType=Toggle |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|opFamily=CHOP |parName=queued |opType=pipein |parSummary=When checked on, the network queuing is enabled. See the following parameters. |parOrder=4 |parLabel=Queued |parType=Toggle |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|opFamily=CHOP |parName=mintarget |opType=pipein |parSummary=The lower end of the queue target range. The Pipe In CHOP will try to maintain a queue length greater than or equal to this value. |parOrder=5 |parLabel=Minimum Target |parType=Float |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|opFamily=CHOP |parName=mintargetunit |opType=pipein |parSummary=Select the units to use for this parameter, Samples, Frames, or Seconds. |parOrder=6 |parLabel=Min Unit |parItems= |parType=Menu |parReadOnly= }} {{Parameter|opFamily=CHOP |parName=maxtarget |opType=pipein |parSummary=The upper end of the queue target range. The Pipe In CHOP will try to maintain a queue length less than or equal to this value. |parOrder=7 |parLabel=Maximum Target |parType=Float |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|opFamily=CHOP |parName=maxtargetunit |opType=pipein |parSummary=Select the units to use for this parameter, Samples, Frames, or Seconds. |parOrder=8 |parLabel=Max Unit |parItems= |parType=Menu |parReadOnly= }} {{Parameter|opFamily=CHOP |parName=maxqueue |opType=pipein |parSummary=The maximum size of the queue when full. Incoming samples will be dropped if the maximum queue is reached. '''This also affects the maximum number of script commands that can be queued up before they start gettting dropped.''' |parOrder=9 |parLabel=Maximum Queue |parType=Float |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|opFamily=CHOP |parName=maxqueueunit |opType=pipein |parSummary=Select the units to use for this parameter, Samples, Frames, or Seconds. |parOrder=10 |parLabel=Max Queue Unit |parItems= |parType=Menu |parReadOnly= }} {{Parameter|opFamily=CHOP |parName=adjusttime |opType=pipein |parSummary=Specifies how often to repeat/drop a samples in order to get closer to the queue target range. If the value = 1 and the units = seconds, then it will try to repeat/drop a sample once per second to maintain the queue target set in the Minimum Target and Maximum Target parameters above. |parOrder=11 |parLabel=Queue Adjust Time |parType=Float |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|opFamily=CHOP |parName=adjusttimeunit |opType=pipein |parSummary=Select the units to use for this parameter, Samples, Frames, or Seconds. |parOrder=12 |parLabel=Adjust Unit |parItems= |parType=Menu |parReadOnly= }} {{Parameter|opFamily=CHOP |parName=reset |opType=pipein |parSummary=Discards and clears all channels and incoming data. |parOrder=13 |parLabel=Reset Channels |parType=Pulse |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|opFamily=CHOP |parName=allowscripts |opType=pipein |parSummary=Incoming script commands will be ignored unless this parameter is turned On. Turning it Off is more secure. |parOrder=14 |parLabel=Allow Incoming Scripts |parType=Toggle |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|opFamily=CHOP |parName=echo |opType=pipein |parSummary=Print all incoming commands (not channel data) to the Console which can be opened from the Dialogs menu. A good way to test a connection is to put "echo X" commands in the incoming stream. |parOrder=15 |parLabel=Echo Messages to Console |parItems= {{ParameterItem|opFamily=CHOP |parName=echo |itemName=off |itemSummary= |itemLabel=Off }}{{ParameterItem|opFamily=CHOP |parName=echo |itemName=on |itemSummary= |itemLabel=Full Messages to Console }}{{ParameterItem|opFamily=CHOP |parName=echo |itemName=raw |itemSummary= |itemLabel=All Events to Console }} |parType=Menu |parReadOnly= }} {{Parameter|opFamily=CHOP |parName=callbacks |opType=pipein |parSummary=Path to a DAT containing callbacks for each event received.
