{{Summary |opClass=bridgeSOP_Class |opType=bridge |short=The Bridge SOP is useful for skinning trimmed surfaces, holes, creating highly controllable joins between arms and body, branches or tube intersections. |opFilter=True |opLabel=Bridge |long=The Bridge SOP is useful for skinning trimmed surfaces, holes, creating highly controllable joins between arms and body, branches or tube intersections. The Bridge SOP is similar to the Skin SOP but with much greater control over the resulting surface. Given a set of profiles (i.e. curves on surface) and/or spatial faces, the Bridge SOP builds a NURBS skin with specified tangent and curvature characteristics. The precision of the resulting surface is highly dependent on the number of required cross-sections and on the quality of the profile extraction. High precisions will generate a very dense surface with, potentially, many multiple knots. In general, the higher the order of the curve, the better the fit the Bridge SOP will be able to provide. However, it is generally better to stick to cubics (order 4) curves, as the software is optimized for cubics. Because the Bridge SOP can join both a set of spatial curves and trim curves, it can be used much like the Skin SOP and/or the Fillet SOP. However, bridging trimmed surfaces is more expensive than bridging carved surfaces. You will usually need a Trim, Bridge, or Profile SOP after a Project SOP. * Use a Trim SOP to cut a hole in the projected surface * Use a Bridge SOPto skin the profile curve to another profile curve. * Use a Profile SOP to extract the curve on surface or remap it's position. '''Note:''' To texture-map the resulting skin, use an Orthographic projection rather than a Spline-based projection. This results in better continuity across the surfaces. |opFamily=SOP |opLicense=Non-Commercial |opCategories= }} {{ParameterPage |pageName= |opFamily=SOP |pageSummary= |items= {{Parameter|parOrder=0 |parName=group |parLabel=Group |parSummary=The Group edit field allows you to enter profile groups for profiles and/or faces to bridge. This is optional if you have regular geometric curves or surfaces, however, you must enter something here in order for Bridge to work with profile curves. For example *.0 will Bridge the 0th (first) profiles of all incoming primitives. '''Note:''' Always specify the curves on surface if you want the Bridge SOP bridge curves on surfaces; otherwise it will attempt to bridge free-floating curves. |parItems= |opFamily=SOP |opType=bridge |parType=StrMenu |parReadOnly=}} {{Parameter|parOrder=1 |parName=bridge |parLabel=Bridge |parSummary=Allows bridging of subgroups of N primitives or patterns of primitives. |parItems= {{ParameterItem|itemLabel=All Primitives |itemName=all |itemSummary= |parName=bridge |opFamily=SOP }}{{ParameterItem|itemLabel=Groups of N Primitives |itemName=group |itemSummary= |parName=bridge |opFamily=SOP }}{{ParameterItem|itemLabel=Skip Every Nth Primitive |itemName=skip |itemSummary= |parName=bridge |opFamily=SOP }} |opFamily=SOP |opType=bridge |parType=Menu |parReadOnly= }} {{Parameter|parName=inc |parLabel=N |parSummary=Determines the pattern of primitives to bridge using this SOP. |parOrder=2 |opFamily=SOP |opType=bridge |parType=Int |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|parName=order |parLabel=Order |parSummary=Sets the spline order for both profile extraction and skinning operations. |parOrder=3 |opFamily=SOP |opType=bridge |parType=Int |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} }} {{ParameterPage |items= {{Parameter|parName=isodivs |parLabel=Min X-Sections |parSummary=The minimum number of cross-sections in the resulting skin. If you create a high-density surface, TouchDesigner's level of detail may display the surface less smoothly than it actually is. You can increase the level of detail by adjusting the viewdisplay options (e.g. viewdisplay -l 1.5 SOPmain.persp1 ) for the Viewport. '''Production Tip:''' If, in generating a smooth surface, you create an extremely complex surface, some of the complexity can be removed without damaging the appearance of the surface by appending a Refine SOP, and using its '''Unrefine''' option. In the Refine SOP, set the '''First U''' parameter to zero and, in the '''Unrefine''' option's parameters, set the '''U''' value close to the order of the surface created in the Bridge SOP. |parOrder=0 |opFamily=SOP |opType=bridge |parType=Int |parReadOnly= |parItems=}} {{Parameter|parOrder=1 |parName=frenet |parLabel=Use |parSummary=Specifies the type of normal to use for computing direction: |parItems= {{ParameterItem|itemLabel=The Frenet Frame of the Face |itemName=frenet |itemSummary=The Frenet Frame of the face. This option uses a local coordinate system on the curve to compute the direction. |parName=frenet |opFamily=SOP }}{{ParameterItem|itemLabel=The Normal of the Face |itemName=normal |itemSummary=The Normal of the face. |parName=frenet |opFamily=SOP }} |opFamily=SOP |opType=bridge |parType=Menu |parReadOnly= }} {{Parameter|parName=circular |parLabel=Circular Arc Fillet |parSummary=Tells TouchDesigner to try to generate a round fillet rather than a free-form fillet. Only the sign (positive or negative) of the tangent scales is used; the scale magnitude is ignored when building a circular fillet. The radius of the fillet is computed automatically and adjusted according to the distance between the rails (curves and/or profiles) and their tangents. |parOrder=2 |opFamily=SOP |opType=bridge |parType=Toggle |parReadOnly= |parItems=}} {{Parameter|parOrder=3 |parName=rotatet |parLabel=Rotate Tangents |parSummary=The scaling and rotation parameters contain three fields. The rotation fields (degrees) apply further rotation to the tangents, while the scale parameter further scales the tangents. |parItems= {{ParameterItem|itemLabel="" |itemName=rotatet1 |itemSummary=Applies to the first face in the input. |parName=rotatet |opFamily=SOP }}{{ParameterItem|itemLabel="" |itemName=rotatet2 |itemSummary=Applies to all intermediate faces. |parName=rotatet |opFamily=SOP }}{{ParameterItem|itemLabel="" |itemName=rotatet3 |itemSummary=Applies to the last face in the input. |parName=rotatet |opFamily=SOP }} |opFamily=SOP |opType=bridge |parType=Float |parReadOnly=}} {{Parameter|parOrder=4 |parName=scalet |parLabel=Scale Tangents |parSummary=The scaling and rotation parameters contain three fields. The rotation fields (degrees) apply further rotation to the tangents, while the scale parameter further scales the tangents. |parItems= {{ParameterItem|itemLabel="" |itemName=scalet1 |itemSummary=Applies to the first face in the input. |parName=scalet |opFamily=SOP }}{{ParameterItem|itemLabel="" |itemName=scalet2 |itemSummary=Applies to all intermediate faces. |parName=scalet |opFamily=SOP }}{{ParameterItem|itemLabel="" |itemName=scalet3 |itemSummary=Applies to the last face in the input. |parName=scalet |opFamily=SOP }} |opFamily=SOP |opType=bridge |parType=Float |parReadOnly=}} {{Parameter|parName=curvature |parLabel=Use Curvature |parSummary=Takes curvature into consideration as well. |parOrder=5 |opFamily=SOP |opType=bridge |parType=Toggle |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|parOrder=6 |parName=scalec |parLabel=Scale Curvatures |parSummary=Further scaling of the curvature. '''Note:''' If the resulting skin bulges too greatly, you can achieve a smooth resulting transition between surfaces by disabling the Preserve Tangent & Preserve Curvature Magnitude parameters, and manually tweaking the Tangent Scales and the Curvature Scales. In general, avoid tweaking the Rotations of the Tangents unless you wish to deform the resulting surface. If the bridge bulges on one side but not the other, try increasing the Min. Number of Cross sections in the bridge. |parItems= {{ParameterItem|itemLabel="" |itemName=scalec1 |itemSummary= |parName=scalec |opFamily=SOP }}{{ParameterItem|itemLabel="" |itemName=scalec2 |itemSummary= |parName=scalec |opFamily=SOP }}{{ParameterItem|itemLabel="" |itemName=scalec3 |itemSummary= |parName=scalec |opFamily=SOP }} |opFamily=SOP |opType=bridge |parType=Float |parReadOnly=}} |pageSummary= |opFamily=SOP |pageName=Surface Properties }} {{ParameterPage |items= {{Parameter|parName=sdivs |parLabel=Divisions per Span |parSummary=Number of 2-D points evaluated in each span. |parOrder=0 |opFamily=SOP |opType=bridge |parType=Int |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|parName=tolerance |parLabel=Tolerance |parSummary=Precision of 2-D fitting algorithm. |parOrder=1 |opFamily=SOP |opType=bridge |parType=Float |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|parName=csharp |parLabel=Preserve Sharp Corners |parSummary=Enables or disables fitting of sharp turns. If cracks appear in the resulting skin, Preserve Sharp Corners is usually a good solution; however, it may add additional knots which can create undesirable "ripples" in some cases. If this option is disabled, fewer isoparms are generated and the surface may not follow the contours of the profile curves perfectly unless the profile curves were built using the Preserve Sharp Corners option. |parOrder=2 |opFamily=SOP |opType=bridge |parType=Toggle |parReadOnly= |parItems=}} |pageSummary=This page's parameters are similar to those found in the Fit and Project SOPs. |opFamily=SOP |pageName=Profile Extraction }} {{OPSection |sectionName=Example |sectionSummary=# Place a Circle SOP. Primitive Type: NURBS; Radius = 0.2, 0.2 # Place a Grid SOP. Primitive Type: NURBS. # Feed both the Circle and Grid SOPs into a Project SOP. Make it the display SOP. You notice the projected circle on the grid - our trim curve. # Append a Trim SOP and make it the display SOP. Turn on Gouraud shading for the Viewport - you now see the trimmed holes in the surface of the grid. # Append a Copy SOP. Number of Copies: 2; Translation Z: 1.0; Rotation X: 30. Make it the display SOP. Now we have two grids with trimmed holes in them. # Append a Bridge SOP, and make it the display SOP. Scale Tangents: 0, 0, 0; Use Curvature: On; Preserve Curvature Magnitudes: Off; Scale Curvatures: 3, 3, 3 . Nothing happens. Why? # We need to specify which profile curves to skin. Turn on Profile Numbers in the Viewport options (click M at the bottom-right of Viewport, and enable the icon). We can see the profile numbers of the two trim curves are 0.0 and 1.0 - meaning the 0th profile of the 0th primitive and the 0th profile of the 1st primitive). The strange numbering is because primitive numbers start at 0 instead of 1. # In the Bridge SOP's Group field enter: .0 - this means to include the 0th (first) curve from all (the ''*'' wildcard character) primitives in the skin. You now see the resulting bridge between the two trim curves. The skin bulges outwards. # We can control the bulge by playing with the Scale Curvatures and the Tangent Magnitudes. Set the Scale Curvatures to: -3, -3, -3 . Now we have an inward-bulging tube connecting the two holes.
[[Image:BridgeSOPExample.gif]]

# Experiment with moving the location and size of the holes (change the Translation and Radius in the Circle SOP). The Bridge SOP dynamically updates the geometry connecting the two surfaces. Setting the Scale Curvature to: 0, 0, 0 produces a straight-through connection between the two holes. |opFamily=SOP}} {{InputsPage |opFamily=SOP |opInputs={{OPInput |opFamily=SOP |inputIndex=0 |inputName= |inputSummary= }} }} {{InfoCHOPChannels |opFamily=SOP |opLabel=Bridge |infoChannels=}} {{History }} {{SOPNavBox |opFamily=SOP }} {{#invoke:Category |list|SOPs}}

{{Summary |opClass=cacheSOP_Class |opType=cache |short=The Cache SOP collects its input geometry in a cache for faster random-access playback of multiple SOPs. |opFilter=True |opLabel=Cache |long=The Cache SOP collects its input geometry in a cache for faster random-access playback of multiple SOPs. It should be used when cook times for a chain of SOPs is long and a quicker playback is needed. Once cached, the geometries can be accessed in any order. This is advantageous to a 2D flipbook or scene render since the geometry is still fully 3-Dimensional. The upshot being that you can scrub otherwise sluggish animations in real time because things are precomputed and stored in a cache. |opFamily=SOP |opLicense=Non-Commercial |opCategories= }} {{ParameterPage |pageName= |opFamily=SOP |pageSummary= |items= {{Parameter|parName=active |parLabel=Active |parSummary=While On, this node will cache a single snapshot of it's input's geometry each cook. |parOrder=0 |opFamily=SOP |opType=cache |parType=Toggle |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|parName=prefill |parLabel=Pre-Fill |parSummary=Cooks 'Cache Size' number of times to fill the Cache SOP with geometry. When set > 0, it will fill the cache. If set > 0 during playback, it will fill immediately. If set > 0 and saved out, then next time the file is opened the cache will pre-fill. While this is > 0, the node behaves as if the 'On' parameter is 0. If set to 0, then back > 0, it will clear the previous data, and pre-fill again. For more information refer to the [[Pre-Filling]] article. |parOrder=1 |opFamily=SOP |opType=cache |parType=Toggle |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|parName=cachesize |parLabel=Cache Size |parSummary=The size of the cache. |parOrder=2 |opFamily=SOP |opType=cache |parType=Int |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|parName=step |parLabel=Step Size |parSummary=The number of frames that the node will cook before it caches another geometry. When set to 1, it will cache every cook, when set to 2, it will cache every two cooks, etc. |parOrder=3 |opFamily=SOP |opType=cache |parType=Int |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|parName=outputindex |parLabel=Output Index |parSummary=Determines which cached geometry to output. 0 is the most recent cached geometry. Valid values are between 0 and cachesize - 1. |parOrder=4 |opFamily=SOP |opType=cache |parType=Float |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|parName=cachepoints |parLabel=Cache Points Only |parSummary=Store a single topology for the first cached geometry and only point data for the remaining geometries. |parOrder=5 |opFamily=SOP |opType=cache |parType=Toggle |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|parName=blendpos |parLabel=Blend Position |parSummary=Interpolate points between geometries. |parOrder=6 |opFamily=SOP |opType=cache |parType=Toggle |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|parName=reset |parLabel=Reset |parSummary=When On, clears out all of the cached geometry. |parOrder=7 |opFamily=SOP |opType=cache |parType=Toggle |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|parName=resetpulse |parLabel=Reset Pulse |parSummary=Instantly clears out all of the cached geometry. |parOrder=8 |opFamily=SOP |opType=cache |parType=Pulse |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} }} {{InputsPage |opFamily=SOP |opInputs={{OPInput |opFamily=SOP |inputIndex=0 |inputName= |inputSummary= }} }} {{InfoCHOPChannels |opFamily=SOP |opLabel=Cache |infoChannels=}} {{History }} {{SOPNavBox |opFamily=SOP }} {{#invoke:Category |list|SOPs}}

{{Summary |long=The Capture Region SOP defines capture region (cregion), which is a type of primitive which can be thought of as a modified tube primitive (a tube with half a sphere on either end). The hemispheres on the ends of the tubes are called "caps". Like any other primitive, each Capture Region has a primitive number and can be assigned primitive attributes. A Capture Region is simply a volume which is used to define the point capture weighting for a geometry. It is then animated to deform the geometry. Capture Regions are always shown in wireframe (even in shaded mode) so that you can focus on the geometry for which the region will act on. |opLabel=Capture Region |opLicense=Non-Commercial |opFamily=SOP |short=The Capture Region SOP defines capture region (cregion), which is a type of primitive which can be thought of as a modified tube primitive (a tube with half a sphere on either end). |opType=cregion |opFilter=False |opClass=captureregionSOP_Class |opCategories= }} {{ParameterPage |items= {{Parameter|parOrder=0 |parSummary=Defines the direction axis of the region. Use Z axis when the region is inside a bone object. [[Image:TouchGeometry46.gif]] |parLabel=Orientation |opType=cregion |opFamily=SOP |parItems= {{ParameterItem|itemSummary= |itemLabel=X Axis |opFamily=SOP |parName=orient |itemName=x }}{{ParameterItem|itemSummary= |itemLabel=Y Axis |opFamily=SOP |parName=orient |itemName=y }}{{ParameterItem|itemSummary= |itemLabel=Z Axis |opFamily=SOP |parName=orient |itemName=z }} |parName=orient |parType=Menu |parReadOnly=}} {{Parameter|parOrder=1 |parSummary=Position of the center of the region. |parLabel=Center |opType=cregion |opFamily=SOP |parItems= {{ParameterItem|itemSummary= |itemLabel=X |opFamily=SOP |parName=t |itemName=tx }}{{ParameterItem|itemSummary= |itemLabel=Y |opFamily=SOP |parName=t |itemName=ty }}{{ParameterItem|itemSummary= |itemLabel=Z |opFamily=SOP |parName=t |itemName=tz }} |parName=t |parType=XYZ |parReadOnly= }} {{Parameter|parOrder=2 |parSummary=Height of the region from the centre to the top cap. |parLabel=Top Height |opType=cregion |opFamily=SOP |parName=theight |parType=Float |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|parOrder=3 |parSummary=The X, Y, Z radii of the top/bottom hemisphere. |parLabel=Top Cap |opType=cregion |opFamily=SOP |parItems= {{ParameterItem|itemSummary= |itemLabel=X |opFamily=SOP |parName=tcap |itemName=tcapx }}{{ParameterItem|itemSummary= |itemLabel=Y |opFamily=SOP |parName=tcap |itemName=tcapy }}{{ParameterItem|itemSummary= |itemLabel=Z |opFamily=SOP |parName=tcap |itemName=tcapz }} |parName=tcap |parType=XYZ |parReadOnly= }} {{Parameter|parOrder=4 |parSummary=Height of the region from the centre to the top cap. |parLabel=Bottom Height |opType=cregion |opFamily=SOP |parName=bheight |parType=Float |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|parOrder=5 |parSummary=The X, Y, Z radii of the top/bottom hemisphere. |parLabel=Bottom Cap |opType=cregion |opFamily=SOP |parItems= {{ParameterItem|itemSummary= |itemLabel=X |opFamily=SOP |parName=bcap |itemName=bcapx }}{{ParameterItem|itemSummary= |itemLabel=Y |opFamily=SOP |parName=bcap |itemName=bcapy }}{{ParameterItem|itemSummary= |itemLabel=Z |opFamily=SOP |parName=bcap |itemName=bcapz }} |parName=bcap |parType=XYZ |parReadOnly= }} {{Parameter|parOrder=6 |parSummary=Defines the weight of a point exactly on the centre line and edge of the region respectively. Point weights in-between are blended. |parLabel=Max/Min Weight |opType=cregion |opFamily=SOP |parItems= {{ParameterItem|itemSummary= |itemLabel="" |opFamily=SOP |parName=weight |itemName=weight1 }}{{ParameterItem|itemSummary= |itemLabel="" |opFamily=SOP |parName=weight |itemName=weight2 }} |parName=weight |parType=Float |parReadOnly= }} |pageName=Region |pageSummary=There are parameters to control the size, shape and position of the capture region. There are separate controls for the top and bottom half of the region. This allows you to edit one side of the bone at a time as you work through your character. The Max/Min Weight parameter is used in the weighting of points. The closer a point is to the edge of the region, the smaller it's weight will be. By default the weight is 1 along the center axis of a region (more on this later), and 0 at the edge of the region. You can modify these weight extremities by through this parameter. |opFamily=SOP }} {{ParameterPage |items= {{Parameter|parOrder=0 |parSummary=The Capture Region SOP{{ParameterItem|itemSummary= |itemLabel=Green |opFamily=SOP |parName=color |itemName=colorg }}{{ParameterItem|itemSummary= |itemLabel=Blue |opFamily=SOP |parName=color |itemName=colorb }} |parName=color |parType=RGB |parReadOnly=}} |pageName=Display |pageSummary= |opFamily=SOP }} {{OPSection |sectionName=How Weighting is Calculated |sectionSummary=Weighting is based on distance to the center line of the region. The center line's length is the height of the tube and runs down its center. When viewed in cross-section, the distance is measured perpendicular to the center line for the tube section and radially for the hemisphere region. This scheme is shown below. The lines represent the distance of points along the edge of the region. This weighting scheme gives continuous deformations to NURBS surfaces when the end cap section of one region is sized so that it touches the middle section of the next region, as shown below.
[[Image:CaptureSOP-overlapCaps.gif]]
Capture regions shown with their containing bone objects.
[[Image:CaptureSOP-cregionWeighting.gif]]
|opFamily=SOP}} {{InfoCHOPChannels |opFamily=SOP |opLabel=Capture Region |infoChannels=}} {{History }} {{SOPNavBox |opFamily=SOP }} {{#invoke:Category |list|SOPs}}

{{Summary |opType=capture |opFilter=True |short=The Capture SOP is used to weight points in a geometry to capture regions. |opLicense=Non-Commercial |opClass=captureSOP_Class |opLabel=Capture |long=The Capture SOP is used to weight points in a geometry to capture regions. The weighting scheme is described in the next section, [[Capture Region SOP]]. The weights and the regions they correspond to are transferred down the SOP chain as point and detail attributes. The Capture SOP can take an optional second input to specify extra capture regions to use in the capture process. Any capture regions that are in this second input are processed after the capture regions that are in the object hierarchy specified by the Hierarchy parameter. You can also specify a second input and not specify a Parent Object at all. |opFamily=SOP |opCategories= }} {{ParameterPage |pageSummary= |pageName=Capture |items= {{Parameter|opType=capture |parName=group |parLabel=Group |parItems= |parOrder=0 |parSummary=Specify the point groups from the first input (input0) to operate on. |opFamily=SOP |parType=StrMenu |parReadOnly=}} {{Parameter|opType=capture |parLabel=Hierarchy |parName=rootbone |parOrder=0 |parSummary=An object hierarchy is traversed to find the Capture Regions with which to do the weighting. This parameter specifies the top of the traversal hierarchy. |opFamily=SOP |parType=Object |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|opType=capture |parName=weightfrom |parLabel=Weight from |parItems= {{ParameterItem|itemName=surface |parName=weightfrom |itemSummary=(default) Uses the surface to compute the weight of a point (or CV in the case of NURBS). This is very helpful for NURBS surfaces when the CV's may be far off the surface. By using Weight From Surface, each CV is weight based on the surface's location within a Capture Region. This is determined by calculating the CVs "most influenced point" on the NURBS surface and computing the weight of that position. |itemLabel=Surface |opFamily=SOP }}{{ParameterItem|itemName=cv |parName=weightfrom |itemSummary=Using the Weight From Points choice, the location of the point within the region is used for the weighting. |itemLabel=Points |opFamily=SOP }} |parOrder=1 |parSummary=Use this menu to specify where to get the weight from. |opFamily=SOP |parType=Menu |parReadOnly=}} {{Parameter|opType=capture |parLabel=Capture Frame |parName=captframe |parOrder=2 |parSummary=Specifies the frame number to do the capture computations. Every time TouchDesigner reaches this frame, the geometry will be re-captured. It is a common practice to set the Capture Frame to an frame outside of your animation range, -1 for example. Specifies the frame number to do the capture computations. Every time TouchDesigner reaches this frame, the geometry will be re-captured. It is a common practice to set the Capture Frame to an frame outside of your animation range, -1 for example. '''Note:''' When a .toe file is loaded, all of the associated capture regions are evaluated at the Capture Frame. Keyframes must be set to position the capture regions properly at the Capture Frame, otherwise the geometry will be weighted incorrectly upon the subsequent file loads. |opFamily=SOP |parType=Int |parReadOnly= |parItems=}} {{Parameter|opType=capture |parName=color |parLabel=Point Coloring |parItems= {{ParameterItem|itemName=coldefault |parName=color |itemSummary= |itemLabel=Default Source Color |opFamily=SOP }}{{ParameterItem|itemName=colregion |parName=color |itemSummary= |itemLabel=Color by Capture Region |opFamily=SOP }} |parOrder=3 |parSummary=This option colors each point by capture region (using point attributes) according to its capture weight. The points inherit their colors from the Capture Region(s) in which they lie. For example, if a point falls within a blue capture region and also a yellow capture region, the point will be colored green (more blue near if the blue weighting dominates, and more yellow if the yellow weight dominates). In addition, the points become darker as the weighting gets lighter. For example, near the edge of a blue region, a caught point will appear dark blue. Near the centre, it will appear bright blue. If a point is not caught by any region, it is colored bright red. |opFamily=SOP |parType=Menu |parReadOnly= }} {{Parameter|opType=capture |parLabel=Override File |parName=captfile |parOrder=4 |parSummary=The name of the capture override file (*.ocapt). This file is loaded after TouchDesigner completes its point weighting. Each line of the override file lists a point number, a region (path and primitive number) and a weight. The points on the geometry are modified to use these custom weights. '''Override File Format''' - Each line in the override file must have the following format: For example: 0 /obj/chain_bone1/cregion 0 0.0 0 /obj/chain_bone2/cregion 0 3.757989 0 /obj/chain_bone3/cregion 0 1.757989 This weights point 0 to three regions (actually only two because the first entry has a weight of zero). Remember that the Override File is read after TouchDesigner does it's own capture weight computation, so in this case, if point 0 was originally assigned to region /obj/chain_bone4/cregion 0, this part of its weighting would be unchanged. There is no upper limit to the number of regions that can be weighted to a point. If a point/region combination is in the file twice, the second one is used. For example: 0 /obj/chain_bone1/cregion 0 1.0 0 /obj/chain_bone1/cregion 0 2.0 This causes the first entry to be ignored (a weighting of 2.0 is used). The weight field is used to prescribe the relative amount of influence a region has on a point. It can be any number. The range of the weights computed by TouchDesigner are specified by the Inner/Outer Weight parameter of each Capture Region (please see [[Capture Region SOP]]). The easiest way to a capture Override File is to use the Save Override File button (see below) and start from the file produced by TouchDesigner. |opFamily=SOP |parType=File |parReadOnly= |parItems=}} |opFamily=SOP }} {{ParameterPage |pageSummary= |pageName=Override |items= {{Parameter|opType=capture |parLabel=Save File |parName=savefile |parOrder=0 |parSummary=The file specified here can be used as a "working file" to save the point weighting of all the points or a selected subset of points. The file format for the capture override files is fairly straight-forward (see above), so this is a good place to start if you need to do custom overriding. |opFamily=SOP |parType=File |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|opType=capture |parLabel=Increment Save File |parName=autoincr |parOrder=1 |parSummary=This increments the Save File name before saving. Be careful about turning this option off because there is no warning or confirm dialog to prevent you from overwriting an .ocapt file. |opFamily=SOP |parType=Toggle |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|opType=capture |parLabel=Save All Data to File |parName=savecaptfile |parOrder=2 |parSummary=This saves the point weighting of all points to the Save File. |opFamily=SOP |parType=Pulse |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|opType=capture |parLabel=Save Selected Points to File |parName=savesel |parOrder=3 |parSummary= This saves the point weighting only for the points that are selected in the viewport. Note: you must be editing this particular SOP in the Viewport for this selection to apply to this SOP. |opFamily=SOP |parType=Pulse |parReadOnly= |parItems=}} |opFamily=SOP }} {{InputsPage |opFamily=SOP |opInputs={{OPInput |opFamily=SOP |inputIndex=0 |inputName= |inputSummary= }}{{OPInput |opFamily=SOP |inputIndex=1 |inputName= |inputSummary= }} }} {{InfoCHOPChannels |opFamily=SOP |opLabel=Capture |infoChannels=}} {{History }} {{SOPNavBox |opFamily=SOP }} {{#invoke:Category |list|SOPs}}

{{Summary |opType=chopto |opFilter=False |short=The CHOP to SOP takes CHOP channels and generates 3D polygons in a SOP. |opLicense=Non-Commercial |opClass=choptoSOP_Class |opLabel=CHOP to |long=The CHOP to SOP takes CHOP channels and generates 3D polygons in a SOP. It reads sample data from a [[CHOP]] and converts it into point positions and point attributes. This makes it complementary to the [[SOP to CHOP]]. The Channels created by the [[SOP to CHOP]] can be modified and then re-inserted into the SOP network via a CHOP to SOP. By default, the SOP is a line from (-1 0 0) to (1 0 0) containing one point for every sample in the CHOP. It matches the input channels to the Channel Scope (tx ty tz) where possible. If tx or ty or tz don’t match anything, it just uses the value from the default line, and it only shows a Warning. The simplest thing to do is to send it a channel named ty, which will make a 3D curve that looks like the CHOP curve. This does what a [[Point SOP]] with a op('wave1')['chan1'].eval(0) function can do, but is much faster. By using point groups from the incoming SOP, the channels can be inserted only into the group's points. The CHOP to SOP also supports custom attributes. If the user maps a channel to an attribute that is not found, that attribute is added to the points. Currently, all custom attributes are floats and of size = 1. In its default state it will attempt to replace the point positions (P(0) P(1) P(2)) with the channels named tx ty and tz. The channel and attribute scope are first expanded into individual names and matched on a 1 to 1 basis. If you are filling P it doesn't matter if you specify t[xyz] or tx ty tz, both will replace P(0) P(1) P(2), which can be collapsed to P. For example: Add custom attributes "Scale", "Twist" or "Roll" to the backbone's points with a CHOP to SOP. If you connect a SOP to its input, it will use the SOP as a starting geometry versus the default line. |opFamily=SOP |opCategories= }} {{ParameterPage |pageName= |opFamily=SOP |pageSummary= |items= {{Parameter|opType=chopto |parName=group |parLabel=Group |parItems= |parOrder=0 |parSummary=Modify only the points within this point group. If blank, all points are modified. Accepts patterns, as described in: [[Pattern Matching]]. |opFamily=SOP |parType=StrMenu |parReadOnly= }} {{Parameter|opType=chopto |parLabel=CHOP |parName=chop |parOrder=1 |parSummary=Specifies which CHOP Network / CHOP contains the sample data to fetch. |opFamily=SOP |parType=CHOP |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|opType=chopto |parName=startpos |parLabel=Start Position |parItems= {{ParameterItem|itemName=startposx |parName=startpos |itemSummary= |itemLabel=X |opFamily=SOP }}{{ParameterItem|itemName=startposy |parName=startpos |itemSummary= |itemLabel=Y |opFamily=SOP }}{{ParameterItem|itemName=startposz |parName=startpos |itemSummary= |itemLabel=Z |opFamily=SOP }} |parOrder=2 |parSummary=Sets the bounds for positions that are not defined by a channel, ie. a channel is not set to one of the P attributes. |opFamily=SOP |parType=XYZ |parReadOnly=}} {{Parameter|opType=chopto |parName=endpos |parLabel=End Position |parItems= {{ParameterItem|itemName=endposx |parName=endpos |itemSummary= |itemLabel=X |opFamily=SOP }}{{ParameterItem|itemName=endposy |parName=endpos |itemSummary= |itemLabel=Y |opFamily=SOP }}{{ParameterItem|itemName=endposz |parName=endpos |itemSummary= |itemLabel=Z |opFamily=SOP }} |parOrder=3 |parSummary=Sets the bounds for positions that are not defined by a channel, ie. a channel is not set to one of the P attributes. |opFamily=SOP |parType=XYZ |parReadOnly=}} {{Parameter|opType=chopto |parName=method |parLabel=Method |parItems= {{ParameterItem|itemName=static |parName=method |itemSummary=Uses one channel for each attribute, and all points use this channel (the first point resides at index 0, the next at 1, and so on). The length of the channels should be at least the number of points modified. |itemLabel=Static |opFamily=SOP }}{{ParameterItem|itemName=animated |parName=method |itemSummary=Uses one channel per attribute per point. The channels show the animation of each point's position/attribute values. Your channels should be named with 0, 1, 2, 3, etc. at the end of the names to correspond to each point they will replace (e.g., tx0, ty0, tz0, tx1, ty1, tz1). Your CHOP should have (number of attributes * number of points) channels in it. |itemLabel=Animated |opFamily=SOP }} |parOrder=4 |parSummary=The sample data fetch method: |opFamily=SOP |parType= |parReadOnly= }} {{Parameter|opType=chopto |parName=chanscope |parLabel=Channel Scope |parItems= |parOrder=5 |parSummary= The names to use to modify the attributes. |opFamily=SOP |parType=StrMenu |parReadOnly=}} {{Parameter|opType=chopto |parName=attscope |parLabel=Attribute Scope |parItems= |parOrder=6 |parSummary=A string list of attributes to modify in the SOP. List of Common Attributes: * '''P''' - Point position (X, Y, Z) - 3 values * '''Pw''' - Point weight - 1 value * '''Cd''' - Point color (red, green, blue, alpha) - 4 values * '''N''' - Point normal (X, Y, Z) - 3 values * '''uv''' - Point texture coordinates (U, V, W) - 3 values See [[Attributes]] for a complete listing of attributes. |opFamily=SOP |parType=StrMenu |parReadOnly=}} {{Parameter|opType=chopto |parLabel=Organize by Attribute |parName=organize |parOrder=7 |parSummary=Instead of using the point index, use the value of this attribute as the index to use when looking up into the CHOP. |opFamily=SOP |parType= |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|opType=chopto |parName=mapping |parLabel=Mapping |parItems= {{ParameterItem|itemName=onetoone |parName=mapping |itemSummary=The samples are simply mapped 1-to-1, each sample is mapped to the next point in order. |itemLabel=One Sample to Each Point |opFamily=SOP }}{{ParameterItem|itemName=scale |parName=mapping |itemSummary=If there are more or less CHOP samples than points in the geometry, then the CHOP channels are resampled to interpolate values for all the geometry points. |itemLabel=Resample CHOP to Fit SOP |opFamily=SOP }} |parOrder=8 |parSummary=Determines how the CHOP samples are mapped to the geometry points. |opFamily=SOP |parType=Menu |parReadOnly= }} {{Parameter|opType=chopto |parLabel=Compute Normals |parName=compnml |parOrder=9 |parSummary=Creates normals on the geometry. |opFamily=SOP |parType=Toggle |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|opType=chopto |parLabel=Compute Tangents |parName=comptang |parOrder=10 |parSummary=Creates tangents on the geometry. |opFamily=SOP |parType=Toggle |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} }} {{InputsPage |opFamily=SOP |opInputs={{OPInput |opFamily=SOP |inputIndex=0 |inputName= |inputSummary= }} }} {{InfoCHOPChannels |opFamily=SOP |opLabel=CHOP to |infoChannels=}} {{History }} {{SOPNavBox |opFamily=SOP }} {{#invoke:Category |list|SOPs}}

{{Summary |opType=circle |opFilter=False |short=The Circle SOP creates open or closed arcs, circles and ellipses. |opLicense=Non-Commercial |opClass=circleSOP_Class |opLabel=Circle |long=The Circle SOP creates open or closed arcs, circles and ellipses. If two NURBS circles that are non-rational (i.e. their X and Y radii are unequal) are skinned, more isoparms may be generated than expected. This is because non-rational NURBS circles parameterise their knots based on chord length, and the Skin SOP must consolidate the total number of knots between the two circles before skinning. To remedy this, you may want to use a Refine SOP, and unrefine the resulting skin, or better yet - before unrefining, start with the same circle and use a Primitive or Transform SOP to deform the second copy before skinning. |opFamily=SOP |opCategories= }} {{ParameterPage |pageName= |opFamily=SOP |pageSummary= |items= {{Parameter|opType=circle |parName=type |parLabel=Primitive Type |parItems= {{ParameterItem|itemName=prim |parName=type |itemSummary= |itemLabel=Primitive |opFamily=SOP }}{{ParameterItem|itemName=poly |parName=type |itemSummary= |itemLabel=Polygon |opFamily=SOP }}{{ParameterItem|itemName=nurbs |parName=type |itemSummary= |itemLabel=NURBS Curve |opFamily=SOP }}{{ParameterItem|itemName=bezier |parName=type |itemSummary= |itemLabel=Bezier Curve |opFamily=SOP }} |parOrder=0 |parSummary=For information on the different types, see the [http://www.derivativeinc.com/Tools/Touch000/Manual/Guides/GeoTypesGuide/GeometryTypes.pdf Geometry Types Guide]. Depending on the primitive type chosen, some SOP options may not apply. |opFamily=SOP |parType=Menu |parReadOnly= }} {{Parameter|opType=circle |parName=orient |parLabel=Orientation |parItems= {{ParameterItem|itemName=xy |parName=orient |itemSummary= |itemLabel=XY Plane |opFamily=SOP }}{{ParameterItem|itemName=yz |parName=orient |itemSummary= |itemLabel=YZ Plane |opFamily=SOP }}{{ParameterItem|itemName=zx |parName=orient |itemSummary= |itemLabel=ZX Plane |opFamily=SOP }} |parOrder=1 |parSummary=The plane on which the circle lies. |opFamily=SOP |parType=Menu |parReadOnly= }} {{Parameter|opType=circle |parLabel=Modify Bounds |parName=modifybounds |parOrder=2 |parSummary=Available only when an input is connected to the Curcle SOP to set bounds for the sphere. When Modify Bounds = On the transform parameters below will further modify the radius and position of the bounds. |opFamily=SOP |parType=Toggle |parReadOnly= |parItems=}} {{Parameter|opType=circle |parName=rad |parLabel=Radius |parItems= {{ParameterItem|itemName=radx |parName=rad |itemSummary= |itemLabel=X |opFamily=SOP }}{{ParameterItem|itemName=rady |parName=rad |itemSummary= |itemLabel=Y |opFamily=SOP }} |parOrder=3 |parSummary=The Radius of the Circle in the X and Y directions. |opFamily=SOP |parType=XY |parReadOnly= }} {{Parameter|opType=circle |parName=t |parLabel=Center |parItems= {{ParameterItem|itemName=tx |parName=t |itemSummary= |itemLabel=X |opFamily=SOP }}{{ParameterItem|itemName=ty |parName=t |itemSummary= |itemLabel=Y |opFamily=SOP }}{{ParameterItem|itemName=tz |parName=t |itemSummary= |itemLabel=Z |opFamily=SOP }} |parOrder=4 |parSummary=The Center of the Circle in X, Y and Z. |opFamily=SOP |parType=XYZ |parReadOnly= }} {{Parameter|parName=reverseanchors |parLabel=Reverse Anchors |parSummary=Invert the direction of anchors. |parOrder=5 |opFamily=SOP |opType=box |parType=Toggle |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|parName=anchoru |parLabel=Anchor U |parSummary=Set the point in X about which the geometry is positioned, scaled and rotated. |parOrder=3 |opFamily=SOP |opType=box |parType=Float |parReadOnly= |parItems=}} {{Parameter|parName=anchorv |parLabel=Anchor V |parSummary=Set the point in Y about which the geometry is positioned, scaled and rotated. |parOrder=3 |opFamily=SOP |opType=box |parType=Float |parReadOnly= |parItems=}} {{Parameter|opType=circle |parLabel=Order |parName=order |parOrder=5 |parSummary=If a spline curve is selected, it is built at this order. |opFamily=SOP |parType=Int |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|opType=circle |parLabel=Divisions |parName=divs |parOrder=6 |parSummary=The number of edges (points +1) used to describe the circle. This option applies to polygons and imperfect splines. The more Divisions a circle has, the smoother it looks. Using three divisions makes a triangle, four divisions a diamond, five divisions a pentagon, and so on. Also, for open arc types, the number of points will equal Divisions + 1, and for closed arc types, Divisions + 2. |opFamily=SOP |parType=Int |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|opType=circle |parName=arc |parLabel=Arc Type |parItems= {{ParameterItem|itemName=closed |parName=arc |itemSummary=An enclosed curve. |itemLabel=Closed |opFamily=SOP }}{{ParameterItem|itemName=openarc |parName=arc |itemSummary=An open curve segment. |itemLabel=Open Arc |opFamily=SOP }}{{ParameterItem|itemName=closedarc |parName=arc |itemSummary= An Open Arc with connecting edges to the centre resembling a slice of pie. |itemLabel=Closed Arc |opFamily=SOP }}{{ParameterItem|itemName=slicedarc |parName=arc |itemSummary=Same as Closed Arc, but connects every single point to the center of the circle.Same as Closed Arc, but connects every single point to the center of the circle. Arc options are available for polygonal circles and some spline types. The difference between the choices: Open, Closed, and Slice are illustrated below for the polygonal case:
[[Image:TouchGeometry220.gif]]
|itemLabel=Sliced Arc |opFamily=SOP }} |parOrder=7 |parSummary=Determines how the circle should be drawn. Applies to polygons and imperfect splines only. |opFamily=SOP |parType=Menu |parReadOnly= }} {{Parameter|opType=circle |parName=angle |parLabel=Arc Angles |parItems= {{ParameterItem|itemName=beginangle |parName=angle |itemSummary= |itemLabel="" |opFamily=SOP }}{{ParameterItem|itemName=endangle |parName=angle |itemSummary= |itemLabel="" |opFamily=SOP }} |parOrder=8 |parSummary=The beginning and ending angles of the arc. An arc will start at the beginning angle, and proceed towards the ending angle. If beginning=0 and end=360 it will be a full circle. As a reference:
[[Image:TouchGeometry222.gif]]
'''Note:''' The total angle can exceed 360, making multiple wraps of the circle. |opFamily=SOP |parType=Float |parReadOnly=}} {{Parameter|opType=circle |parLabel=Imperfect |parName=imperfect |parOrder=9 |parSummary=This option applies only to Bezier and NURBS circles. If selected, the circles are approximated non-rational curves, otherwise they are perfect rational closed curves. |opFamily=SOP |parType=Toggle |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|opType=circle |parName=texture |parLabel=Texture Coordinates |parItems= {{ParameterItem|itemName=off |parName=texture |itemSummary=No texture coordinates are created. |itemLabel=Off |opFamily=SOP }}{{ParameterItem|itemName=face |parName=texture |itemSummary=Default texture coordinates are created. To modify texture coordinates, see [[Texture SOP]]. |itemLabel=Face |opFamily=SOP }} |parOrder=10 |parSummary=Option to include texture cooordinates or not. |opFamily=SOP |parType=Menu |parReadOnly=}} {{Parameter|opType=circle |parLabel=Compute Normals |parName=normals |parOrder=11 |parSummary=When On, normals are created for the surface. |opFamily=SOP |parType=Toggle |parReadOnly= |parItems=}} }} {{InputsPage |opFamily=SOP |opInputs={{OPInput |opFamily=SOP |inputIndex=0 |inputName= |inputSummary= }} }} {{InfoCHOPChannels |opFamily=SOP |opLabel=Circle |infoChannels=}} {{History }} {{SOPNavBox |opFamily=SOP }} {{#invoke:Category |list|SOPs}}

{{Summary |opType=clay |opFilter=True |short=The Clay SOP deforms faces and surfaces by pulling points that lie directly on them. |opLicense=Non-Commercial |opClass=claySOP_Class |opLabel=Clay |long=The Clay SOP deforms faces and surfaces by pulling points that lie directly on them. As opposed to the Point SOP or other SOPs that manipulate control points (CVs), the Clay SOP operates on the primitive contours themselves, providing a direct, intuitive, and unconstrained way of reshaping geometry. Thus, rather than translating CVs to change the aspect of the primitive, the Clay SOP takes the inverse approach of manipulating the primitive's skin to reposition the CVs. The point that defines the area to be modified is called a "target point" or "target" for short. It is expressed as a (u,v) pair in the parametric space of the primitive and ranges between 0 and 1 in both U and V. The image of the target point on the primitive is a 3D point which Clay can displace in several ways. Furthermore, if the primitive is a surface, there is are options to pull only the point or a whole isoparametric curve in either U or V. Clay does not refine the faces and surfaces unless asked to, so the complexity of the geometry does not increase. The area affected by the change varies with each primitive type and topology. In all cases it is possible to reduce to amount of change by inserting a Refine SOP before the Clay SOP and inserting detail around the target point. For other ways to increase the locality of the deformation as well as its sharpness, see U and V Sharpness below. If a second input is present, it is possible to snap the target (u,v) point to an (s,t) point on the first primitive of the second input. Without a second input, the primitives can be made to snap to themselves. Moreover, the Clay SOP is able to snap the target to arbitrary points in space. Both this SOP and the Align SOP can be used effectively as snapping tools and building blocks for curve networks. The main difference between the two SOPs is that Clay deforms the inputs partially, while Align translates and/or rotates the whole primitive. The Clay SOP accepts a mix of any combination of face and surface types. |opFamily=SOP |opCategories= }} {{ParameterPage |pageName=Clay |pageSummary= |items= |opFamily=SOP }} {{Parameter|opType=clay |parName=group |parLabel=Group |parItems= |parOrder=0 |parSummary=If there are input groups, specifying a group name in this field will cause this SOP to act only upon the group specified. Accepts patterns, as described in Pattern Matching in the [Scripting Guide]. |opFamily=SOP |parType=StrMenu |parReadOnly= }} {{Parameter|opType=clay |parName=method |parLabel=Warp Method |parItems= {{ParameterItem|itemName=mat |parName=method |itemSummary=The matrix method relocates the target point based on a transformation matrix. For a description of transforms, see the [[Transform SOP]]. |itemLabel=Matrix |opFamily=SOP }}{{ParameterItem|itemName=vec |parName=method |itemSummary=The vector method provides a distance and a vector to translate along. |itemLabel=Vector |opFamily=SOP }}{{ParameterItem|itemName=point |parName=method |itemSummary=The point method provides a 3D point in object space that the target point must snap to. |itemLabel=Point |opFamily=SOP }}{{ParameterItem|itemName=prim |parName=method |itemSummary=The primitive method allows the target point to be snapped to a point on another primitive. Any primitive type is allowed, including metaballs, all quadrics, and even particle systems. The point on the destination primitive is expressed parametrically as a (U, V) pair. If the Clay SOP has a second input, then the destination primitive is going to be the first primitive in that input. If there is no second input, the primitives in the first input will snap to themselves (each face or surface to itself). |itemLabel=Primitive |opFamily=SOP }} |parOrder=0 |parSummary=The following describe the four types of transformations the Clay SOP can apply to the target (U, V) points or isoparametric curves (U or V). All the transformations are exclusive, and all reduce to a signed translation along a direction. The difference between the various transformations is the way the translation and the direction are specified. |opFamily=SOP |parType=Menu |parReadOnly=}} {{Parameter|parItems= {{ParameterItem|itemName=srt |itemSummary= |itemLabel=Scale Rotate Translate |opFamily=SOP |parName=xord }}{{ParameterItem|itemName=str |itemSummary= |itemLabel=Scale Translate Rotate |opFamily=SOP |parName=xord }}{{ParameterItem|itemName=rst |itemSummary= |itemLabel=Rotate Scale Translate |opFamily=SOP |parName=xord }}{{ParameterItem|itemName=rts |itemSummary= |itemLabel=Rotate Translate Scale |opFamily=SOP |parName=xord }}{{ParameterItem|itemName=tsr |itemSummary= |itemLabel=Translate Scale Rotate |opFamily=SOP |parName=xord }}{{ParameterItem|itemName=trs |itemSummary= |itemLabel=Translate Rotate Scale |opFamily=SOP |parName=xord }} |parLabel=Transform Order |opType=clay |opFamily=SOP |parSummary=Sets the overall transform order for the transformations. The transform order determines the order in which transformations take place. Depending on the order, you can achieve different results using the exact same values. Choose the appropriate order from the menu. |parOrder=1 |parName=xord |parType=Menu |parReadOnly= }} {{Parameter|parItems= {{ParameterItem|itemName=xyz |itemSummary= |itemLabel=Rx Ry Rz |opFamily=SOP |parName=rord }}{{ParameterItem|itemName=xzy |itemSummary= |itemLabel=Rx Rz Ry |opFamily=SOP |parName=rord }}{{ParameterItem|itemName=yxz |itemSummary= |itemLabel=Ry Rx Rz |opFamily=SOP |parName=rord }}{{ParameterItem|itemName=yzx |itemSummary= |itemLabel=Ry Rz Rx |opFamily=SOP |parName=rord }}{{ParameterItem|itemName=zxy |itemSummary= |itemLabel=Rz Rx Ry |opFamily=SOP |parName=rord }}{{ParameterItem|itemName=zyx |itemSummary= |itemLabel=Rz Ry Rx |opFamily=SOP |parName=rord }} |parLabel=Rotate Order |opType=clay |opFamily=SOP |parSummary=Sets the order of the rotations within the overall transform order. |parOrder=2 |parName=rord |parType=Menu |parReadOnly= }} {{Parameter|parItems= {{ParameterItem|itemName=tx |itemSummary= |itemLabel=X |opFamily=SOP |parName=t }}{{ParameterItem|itemName=ty |itemSummary= |itemLabel=Y |opFamily=SOP |parName=t }}{{ParameterItem|itemName=tz |itemSummary= |itemLabel=Z |opFamily=SOP |parName=t }} |parLabel=Translate |opType=clay |opFamily=SOP |parSummary=These three fields move the Source geometry in the three axes. |parOrder=3 |parName=t |parType=XYZ |parReadOnly= }} {{Parameter|parItems= {{ParameterItem|itemName=rx |itemSummary= |itemLabel=X |opFamily=SOP |parName=r }}{{ParameterItem|itemName=ry |itemSummary= |itemLabel=Y |opFamily=SOP |parName=r }}{{ParameterItem|itemName=rz |itemSummary= |itemLabel=Z |opFamily=SOP |parName=r }} |parLabel=Rotate |opType=clay |opFamily=SOP |parSummary=These three fields rotate the Source geometry in the three axes. |parOrder=4 |parName=r |parType=XYZ |parReadOnly= }} {{Parameter|parItems= {{ParameterItem|itemName=sx |itemSummary= |itemLabel=X |opFamily=SOP |parName=s }}{{ParameterItem|itemName=sy |itemSummary= |itemLabel=Y |opFamily=SOP |parName=s }}{{ParameterItem|itemName=sz |itemSummary= |itemLabel=Z |opFamily=SOP |parName=s }} |parLabel=Scale |opType=clay |opFamily=SOP |parSummary=These three fields scale the Source geometry in the three axes. |parOrder=5 |parName=s |parType=XYZ |parReadOnly= }} {{Parameter |parItems={{ParameterItem|itemName=px |itemSummary= |itemLabel=X |opFamily=SOP |parName=p }}{{ParameterItem|itemName=py |itemSummary= |itemLabel=Y |opFamily=SOP |parName=p }}{{ParameterItem|itemName=pz |itemSummary= |itemLabel=Z |opFamily=SOP |parName=p }} |parLabel=Pivot |parName=p |opType=clay |opFamily=SOP |parType=XYZ |parSummary=The pivot point for the transformations (not the same as the pivot point in the pivot channels). The pivot point parameters allow you to define the point about which geometry scales and rotates. Altering the pivot point produces different results depending on the transformation performed on the object. For example, during a scaling operation, if the pivot point of an object is located at: -1, -1, 0 and you wanted to scale the object by 0.5 (reduce its size by 50%) the object would scale toward the pivot point and appear to slide down and to the left. [[Image:TouchGeometry91.gif]] In the example above, rotations performed on an object with different pivot points produce very different results.|parReadOnly=|parOrder=}} {{Parameter|opType=clay |parLabel=Distance |parName=dist |parOrder=0 |parSummary=Specifies the translation distance along the given vector. |opFamily=SOP |parType=Float |parReadOnly= |parItems=}} {{Parameter|opType=clay |parLabel=Normal |parName=normal |parOrder=1 |parSummary=When On, the translation will be performed along the primitive normal at the target (U, V) point. Otherwise an explicit direction is required, see Direction parameter below. If the input contains face primitives, the primitive normal is independent of the target (U) point. Primitive normals can be displayed from the Display Options dialog. |opFamily=SOP |parType=Toggle |parReadOnly= |parItems=}} {{Parameter|opType=clay |parName=dir |parLabel=Direction |parItems= {{ParameterItem|itemName=dirx |parName=dir |itemSummary= |itemLabel=X |opFamily=SOP }}{{ParameterItem|itemName=diry |parName=dir |itemSummary= |itemLabel=Y |opFamily=SOP }}{{ParameterItem|itemName=dirz |parName=dir |itemSummary= |itemLabel=Z |opFamily=SOP }} |parOrder=2 |parSummary=The direction of the vector is the Normal parameter above is Off. |opFamily=SOP |parType=XYZ |parReadOnly=}} {{Parameter|opType=clay |parName=coord |parLabel=Coordinates |parItems= {{ParameterItem|itemName=coordx |parName=coord |itemSummary= |itemLabel=X |opFamily=SOP }}{{ParameterItem|itemName=coordy |parName=coord |itemSummary= |itemLabel=Y |opFamily=SOP }}{{ParameterItem|itemName=coordz |parName=coord |itemSummary= |itemLabel=Z |opFamily=SOP }} |parOrder=0 |parSummary=Specifies the absolute 3D location the (U, V) target must translate to. |opFamily=SOP |parType=XYZ |parReadOnly= }} {{Parameter|opType=clay |parName=uvsnap |parLabel=U and V |parItems= {{ParameterItem|itemName=uvsnap1 |parName=uvsnap |itemSummary= |itemLabel="" |opFamily=SOP }}{{ParameterItem|itemName=uvsnap2 |parName=uvsnap |itemSummary= |itemLabel="" |opFamily=SOP }} |parOrder=0 |parSummary=The primitive method allows the target point to be snapped to a point on another primitive specified by U and V here. See Warp Method parameter for details. |opFamily=SOP |parType=Float |parReadOnly=}} |opFamily=SOP }} {{ParameterPage |pageSummary= |pageName=U |items= {{Parameter|opType=clay |parLabel=Deform along U |parName=uwarp |parOrder=1 |parSummary=Determines whether the clay operation affects the U parametric direction. Both faces and surfaces respond to this option. If the primitives are face types and the toggle is off, clay doesn't change the inputs at all. If the inputs are surfaces and U is off, clay will pull the surfaces along the entire V direction (if V is on) or not at all. |opFamily=SOP |parType=Toggle |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|opType=clay |parLabel=U |parName=u |parOrder=0 |parSummary=This value defines a point in the parametric space of a face, representing the location to be affected by the clay operation. This location is referred to as the "target". For surfaces, U defines a line of constant value in the parametric space of the primitive and requires a second coordinate - V - to specify a unique location (see the V> Page below). Spline faces and surfaces have explicit parametric spaces known as domains; since domains are not restricted to the unit range [0, 1], the Clay SOP maps U to the real domain value of the primitive. For polygons and meshes, U is expressed in terms of the number or vertices and columns respectively and in terms of their relative positions. |opFamily=SOP |parType=Float |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|opType=clay |parLabel=U Bias |parName=uusebias |parOrder=1 |parSummary=Indicates whether the clay algorithm should use the bias it thinks works best for the given U parameter, or take the value explicitly stated beside the toggle. Since clay affects the CVs in the neighbourhood of the given parametric location, the bias can influence the amount of pull applied to the CVs on either side of this location. The effect is a slant of the "wave" the parametric point rides on - towards one side or the other. |opFamily=SOP |parType=Toggle |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|opType=clay |parLabel=U Bias |parName=ubias |parOrder=2 |parSummary= |opFamily=SOP |parType=Float |parReadOnly= |parItems=}} {{Parameter|opType=clay |parLabel=U Sharpness |parName=usharp |parOrder=3 |parSummary=This parameter affects only NURBS curves and surfaces. The pull generated by clay on these primitives can be smooth or sharp depending on the position of the target relative to the underlying domain (the farther away from a knot, the rounded the bulge) and the knot multiplicity near the target (the higher the multiplicity the sharper the pull). If the pull is too round or affects too big an area in U, the U Sharpness parameter can reduce it by inserting one or more knots at the target U value. When the U Sharpness is zero no knots are inserted. When the U Sharpness is 1, all "degree" knots are inserted and the shape becomes very sharp. The U Sharpness varies in discrete steps; the number of steps equals the U degree of the spline. '''Note:''' The range of the U Sharpness slider varies with the degree of the spline (i.e. the closer it is to 1, the more knots it adds). Since the number of knots added forms a discrete sequence, the slider will automatically jump to the valid positions. |opFamily=SOP |parType=Float |parReadOnly= |parItems=}} |opFamily=SOP }} {{ParameterPage |pageSummary= |pageName=V |items= {{Parameter|opType=clay |parLabel=Deform along V |parName=vwarp |parOrder=2 |parSummary=Determines whether the clay operation affects the V parametric direction of the surface. If the inputs are surfaces and V if off, clay will pull the surfaces along the entire U direction (if U is on) or not at all. If both U and V are on, clay will pull the surface at the target (U, V) point specified in the U and V folders below. This option does not affect face types. |opFamily=SOP |parType=Toggle |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|opType=clay |parLabel=V |parName=v |parOrder=0 |parSummary=This value affects only surface types. V defines a line of constant value in the parametric space of the surface and together with U specifies a unique location in that space. Spline surfaces have explicit parametric spaces known as domains; since domains are not restricted to the unit range [0, 1], the Clay SOP maps V to the real domain value of the surface. For meshes, V is expressed in terms of the number or rows and their relative positions. |opFamily=SOP |parType=Float |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|opType=clay |parLabel=V Bias |parName=vusebias |parOrder=1 |parSummary=Indicates whether the clay algorithm should use the bias it thinks works best for the given V parameter, or take the value explicitly stated beside the toggle. Since clay affects the CVs in the neighbourhood of the given parametric location, the bias can influence the amount of pull applied to the CVs on either side of this location. The effect is a slant of the "wave" the parametric point rides on -- towards one side or the other. |opFamily=SOP |parType=Toggle |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|opType=clay |parLabel=V Bias |parName=vbias |parOrder=2 |parSummary= |opFamily=SOP |parType=Float |parReadOnly= |parItems=}} {{Parameter|opType=clay |parLabel=V Sharpness |parName=vsharp |parOrder=3 |parSummary=This parameter affects only NURBS surfaces. The pull generated by clay on these primitives can be smooth or sharp depending on the position of the target relative to the underlying domain (the farther away from a knot, the rounded the bulge) and the knot multiplicity near the target (the higher the multiplicity the sharper the pull). If the pull is too round or affects too big an area in V, the V Sharpness parameter can reduce it by inserting one or more knots at the target V value. When the V Sharpness is zero no knots are inserted. When the V Sharpness is 1, all "degree" knots are inserted and the surface becomes very sharp. The V Sharpness varies in discrete steps; the number of steps equals the V degree of the spline. '''Note:''' The range of the V Sharpness slider varies with the degree of the spline (i.e. the closer it is to 1, the more knots it adds). Since the number of knots added forms a discrete sequence, the slider will automatically jump to the valid positions. |opFamily=SOP |parType=Float |parReadOnly= |parItems=}} |opFamily=SOP }} {{InputsPage |opFamily=SOP |opInputs={{OPInput |opFamily=SOP |inputIndex=0 |inputName= |inputSummary= }}{{OPInput |opFamily=SOP |inputIndex=1 |inputName= |inputSummary= }} }} {{InfoCHOPChannels |opFamily=SOP |opLabel=Clay |infoChannels=}} {{History }} {{SOPNavBox |opFamily=SOP }} {{#invoke:Category |list|SOPs}}

{{Summary |opType=clip |opFilter=True |short=The Clip SOP cuts and creases source geometry with a plane. |opLicense=Non-Commercial |opClass=clipSOP_Class |opLabel=Clip |long=The Clip SOP cuts and creases source geometry with a plane. |opFamily=SOP |opCategories= }} {{ParameterPage |pageName= |opFamily=SOP |pageSummary= |items= {{Parameter|opType=clip |parName=group |parLabel=Group |parItems= |parOrder=0 |parSummary=If there are input groups, specifying a group name in this field will cause this SOP to act only upon the group specified. Accepts patterns, as described in Pattern Matching in the [http://www.derivativeinc.com/Tools/Touch000/Manual/Guides/ScriptingGuide/ScriptingGuide.pdf Scripting Guide.] |opFamily=SOP |parType=StrMenu |parReadOnly= }} {{Parameter|opType=clip |parName=clipop |parLabel=Keep |parItems= {{ParameterItem|itemName=above |parName=clipop |itemSummary=Retain the primitives above the cutting plane. |itemLabel=Primitives Above the Plane |opFamily=SOP }}{{ParameterItem|itemName=below |parName=clipop |itemSummary=Retain the primitives below the cutting plane. |itemLabel=Primitives Below the Plane |opFamily=SOP }}{{ParameterItem|itemName=both |parName=clipop |itemSummary=Retain both the top and bottom primitives generated by the cutting plane. Creates a crease in the geometry. |itemLabel=All Primitives |opFamily=SOP }} |parOrder=1 |parSummary=Options controlling what part of the clip to keep: |opFamily=SOP |parType=Menu |parReadOnly= }} {{Parameter|opType=clip |parLabel=Distance |parName=dist |parOrder=2 |parSummary=Allows you to move the cutting plane along the Direction vector. If the Direction (plane's normal) is 0 1 0, putting a positive number in the Distance field moves the plane up in Y. |opFamily=SOP |parType=Float |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|opType=clip |parName=dir |parLabel=Direction |parItems= {{ParameterItem|itemName=dirx |parName=dir |itemSummary= |itemLabel=X |opFamily=SOP }}{{ParameterItem|itemName=diry |parName=dir |itemSummary= |itemLabel=Y |opFamily=SOP }}{{ParameterItem|itemName=dirz |parName=dir |itemSummary= |itemLabel=Z |opFamily=SOP }} |parOrder=3 |parSummary=The default values of 0 1 0 creates a Normal vector straight up in Y, which is perpendicular to the XZ plane, which becomes the clipping plane. 1 0 0 points the normal in positive X, giving a clipping plane in YZ. The plane may be positioned at an angle by using values typed in (1 1 0 gives a 45 angle plane) or interactively by using the direction vector jack. |opFamily=SOP |parType=XYZ |parReadOnly= }} {{Parameter|opType=clip |parLabel=Create Groups |parName=newg |parOrder=4 |parSummary=When checked, allows you to generate specific groups for the geometry above and below the cutting plane. See the two group option fields below. This option is only available when All Primitives are kept. |opFamily=SOP |parType=Toggle |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|opType=clip |parLabel=Above Plane |parName=above |parOrder=5 |parSummary=When Create Groups is checked, you can assign the geometry below the cutting plane to the Group name typed in this field. |opFamily=SOP |parType=Str |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|opType=clip |parLabel=Below Plane |parName=below |parOrder=6 |parSummary=When Create Groups is checked, you can assign the geometry above the cutting plane to the Group name typed in this field. |opFamily=SOP |parType=Str |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} }} {{InputsPage |opFamily=SOP |opInputs={{OPInput |opFamily=SOP |inputIndex=0 |inputName= |inputSummary= }} }} {{InfoCHOPChannels |opFamily=SOP |opLabel=Clip |infoChannels=}} {{History }} {{SOPNavBox |opFamily=SOP }} {{#invoke:Category |list|SOPs}}

{{Summary |opType=convert |opFilter=True |short=The Convert SOP converts geometry from one geometry type to another type. |opLicense=Non-Commercial |opClass=convertSOP_Class |opLabel=Convert |long=The Convert SOP converts geometry from one geometry type to another type. Types include polygon, mesh, Bezier patche, particle and sphere primitive. |opFamily=SOP |opCategories= }} {{ParameterPage |pageName= |opFamily=SOP |pageSummary= |items= {{Parameter|opType=convert |parName=group |parLabel=Group |parItems= |parOrder=0 |parSummary= If there are input groups, specifying a group name in this field will cause this SOP to act only upon the group specified. Accepts patterns, as described in [[Pattern Matching]]. |opFamily=SOP |parType=StrMenu |parReadOnly= }} {{Parameter|opType=convert |parName=fromtype |parLabel=From Type |parItems= {{ParameterItem|itemName=all |parName=fromtype |itemSummary=All geometry will be converted. |itemLabel=All Types |opFamily=SOP }}{{ParameterItem|itemName=sphere |parName=fromtype |itemSummary= |itemLabel=Sphere |opFamily=SOP }}{{ParameterItem|itemName=tube |parName=fromtype |itemSummary= |itemLabel=Tube |opFamily=SOP }}{{ParameterItem|itemName=part |parName=fromtype |itemSummary= |itemLabel=Particles |opFamily=SOP }}{{ParameterItem|itemName=metaball |parName=fromtype |itemSummary= |itemLabel=Meta-ball |opFamily=SOP }}{{ParameterItem|itemName=poly |parName=fromtype |itemSummary= |itemLabel=Polygon |opFamily=SOP }}{{ParameterItem|itemName=mesh |parName=fromtype |itemSummary= |itemLabel=Mesh |opFamily=SOP }}{{ParameterItem|itemName=bezcurve |parName=fromtype |itemSummary= |itemLabel=Bezier Curve |opFamily=SOP }}{{ParameterItem|itemName=bezsurf |parName=fromtype |itemSummary= |itemLabel=Bezier Surface |opFamily=SOP }}{{ParameterItem|itemName=nurbcurve |parName=fromtype |itemSummary= |itemLabel=NURBS Curve |opFamily=SOP }}{{ParameterItem|itemName=nurbsurf |parName=fromtype |itemSummary= |itemLabel=NURBS Surface |opFamily=SOP }}{{ParameterItem|itemName=circle |parName=fromtype |itemSummary= |itemLabel=Circle |opFamily=SOP }}{{ParameterItem|itemName=tristrip |parName=fromtype |itemSummary= |itemLabel=Triangle Strip |opFamily=SOP }}{{ParameterItem|itemName=trifan |parName=fromtype |itemSummary= |itemLabel=Triangle Fan |opFamily=SOP }} |parOrder=1 |parSummary=Determines which geometry by type will be converted. The default is All Types: |opFamily=SOP |parType=Menu |parReadOnly= }} {{Parameter|opType=convert |parName=totype |parLabel=Convert to |parItems= {{ParameterItem|itemName=poly |parName=totype |itemSummary= |itemLabel=Polygon |opFamily=SOP }}{{ParameterItem|itemName=mesh |parName=totype |itemSummary= |itemLabel=Mesh |opFamily=SOP }}{{ParameterItem|itemName=bezcurve |parName=totype |itemSummary= |itemLabel=Bezier Curve |opFamily=SOP }}{{ParameterItem|itemName=bezsurf |parName=totype |itemSummary= |itemLabel=Bezier Surface |opFamily=SOP }}{{ParameterItem|itemName=nurbcurve |parName=totype |itemSummary= |itemLabel=NURBS Curve |opFamily=SOP }}{{ParameterItem|itemName=nurbsurf |parName=totype |itemSummary= |itemLabel=NURBS Surface |opFamily=SOP }}{{ParameterItem|itemName=circle |parName=totype |itemSummary= |itemLabel=Circle |opFamily=SOP }}{{ParameterItem|itemName=trimbezsurf |parName=totype |itemSummary= |itemLabel=Trimmed Bezier Surface |opFamily=SOP }}{{ParameterItem|itemName=trimnurbsurf |parName=totype |itemSummary= |itemLabel=Trimmed NURBS Surface |opFamily=SOP }}{{ParameterItem|itemName=part |parName=totype |itemSummary= |itemLabel=Particles |opFamily=SOP }} |parOrder=2 |parSummary=Determines what the above From Type geometry will be converted to. Conversion to Polygons is the default: '''Notes''': Not all geometry can be converted to specific types. For example, a triangulated polygon surface to a single NURBS surface, or a Mesh sphere into a primitive sphere. Also, certain conversions will preserve shapes. For example, converting a Bzier curve to a NURBS curve or a polygonal mesh to a NURBS Surface. '''Circle Notes''': Converting to primitive circles is available for action users who are used to working with polygon circles so that you can convert them to primitive circles for the TouchDesigner Skeleton, Arm, and Limb SOPs. '''Trimmed Surface Notes''': If the primitive to be converted is a curve (NURBS or Bezier) and is flat, a trimmed surface will be generated such that the visible piece coincides with the curve. If the curve is not flat, it will be converted to a non-trimmed surface. The advantage of the trimmed solution is that it yields a very clean surface and handles concave curves perfectly. |opFamily=SOP |parType=Menu |parReadOnly=}} {{Parameter|opType=convert |parName=surftype |parLabel=Connectivity |parItems= {{ParameterItem|itemName=rows |parName=surftype |itemSummary=Creates horizontal lines. |itemLabel=Rows |opFamily=SOP }}{{ParameterItem|itemName=cols |parName=surftype |itemSummary=Creates vertical lines. |itemLabel=Columns |opFamily=SOP }}{{ParameterItem|itemName=rowcol |parName=surftype |itemSummary=Both Rows and Columns. Looks like Quadrilaterals in wire frame display, but all polygons are open (if the primitive type is polygon). |itemLabel=Rows and Columns |opFamily=SOP }}{{ParameterItem|itemName=triangles |parName=surftype |itemSummary=Build the grid with Triangles. |itemLabel=Triangles |opFamily=SOP }}{{ParameterItem|itemName=quads |parName=surftype |itemSummary=Generates sides composed of quadrilaterals (default). |itemLabel=Quadrilaterals |opFamily=SOP }}{{ParameterItem|itemName=alttriangles |parName=surftype |itemSummary=Generates triangles that are opposed; similar to the Triangles option. |itemLabel=Alternating Triangles |opFamily=SOP }} |parOrder=3 |parSummary=This option is used to select how the points of the created surface are connected. |opFamily=SOP |parType=Menu |parReadOnly= }} }} {{ParameterPage |pageSummary=This affects the use of the U/V/Trim Curve fields: * For Level of Detail: U, V, Trim Curve Level of Detail In a spline's case, the span is the curve arc between two breakpoints. The number of divisions per span specifies how many points to be created between the two breakpoints. If the number of divisions = 0, a single segment will connect the two breakpoints; if number of divisions = 1, two edges will be created; etc. The advantage of Divisions over the Level of Detail is that it tells you exactly how many points you'll end up with - extremely useful for polygonal modeling. |pageName=Level of Detail |items= {{Parameter|opType=convert |parLabel=U |parName=lodu |parOrder=0 |parSummary=When set to Level of Detail, controls the number of points or CVs that are used in the newly generated geometry depending on the above setting. Converting a NURBS surface into a polygon mesh with a Level of Detail of 1 results in a fair approximation of the NURBS surface whereas a value of 2 generates a very dense polygonal mesh. When set to Divisions per Span, specificies the number of divisions per span. '''Tip:''' Animate the Level of Detail based on how close your character or geometry is to the camera by using the primdist() expression. Then the detail will increase/decrease as the camera gets closer/further away. |opFamily=SOP |parType=Float |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|opType=convert |parLabel=V |parName=lodv |parOrder=1 |parSummary=When set to Level of Detail, controls the number of points or CVs that are used in the newly generated geometry depending on the above setting. Converting a NURBS surface into a polygon mesh with a Level of Detail of 1 results in a fair approximation of the NURBS surface whereas a value of 2 generates a very dense polygonal mesh. When set to Divisions per Span, specificies the number of divisions per span. '''Tip:''' Animate the Level of Detail based on how close your character or geometry is to the camera by using the primdist() expression. Then the detail will increase/decrease as the camera gets closer/further away. |opFamily=SOP |parType=Float |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|opType=convert |parLabel=Trim-Curve |parName=lodtrim |parOrder=2 |parSummary=The trimmed part of a surface will be converted using this Trim lod (level of detail) instead of using an implicit "1" constant. |opFamily=SOP |parType=Float |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} |opFamily=SOP }} {{ParameterPage |pageSummary=This affects the use of the U/V/Trim Curve fields: * For Divisions per Span: U, V, Number of Trim Curve Divisions. In a spline's case, the span is the curve arc between two breakpoints. The number of divisions per span specifies how many points to be created between the two breakpoints. If the number of divisions = 0, a single segment will connect the two breakpoints; if number of divisions = 1, two edges will be created; etc. The advantage of Divisions over the Level of Detail is that it tells you exactly how many points you'll end up with - extremely useful for polygonal modeling. |pageName=Divisions per Span |items= {{Parameter|opType=convert |parLabel=U |parName=divu |parOrder=0 |parSummary=When set to Level of Detail, controls the number of points or CVs that are used in the newly generated geometry depending on the above setting. Converting a NURBS surface into a polygon mesh with a Level of Detail of 1 results in a fair approximation of the NURBS surface whereas a value of 2 generates a very dense polygonal mesh. When set to Divisions per Span, specificies the number of divisions per span. '''Tip:''' Animate the Level of Detail based on how close your character or geometry is to the camera by using the primdist() expression. Then the detail will increase/decrease as the camera gets closer/further away. |opFamily=SOP |parType=Int |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|opType=convert |parLabel=V |parName=divv |parOrder=1 |parSummary=When set to Level of Detail, controls the number of points or CVs that are used in the newly generated geometry depending on the above setting. Converting a NURBS surface into a polygon mesh with a Level of Detail of 1 results in a fair approximation of the NURBS surface whereas a value of 2 generates a very dense polygonal mesh. When set to Divisions per Span, specificies the number of divisions per span. '''Tip:''' Animate the Level of Detail based on how close your character or geometry is to the camera by using the primdist() expression. Then the detail will increase/decrease as the camera gets closer/further away. |opFamily=SOP |parType=Int |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|opType=convert |parLabel=Trim-Curve |parName=divtrim |parOrder=2 |parSummary=The trimmed part of a surface will be converted using this Trim lod (level of detail) instead of using an implicit "1" constant. |opFamily=SOP |parType=Int |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} |opFamily=SOP }} {{Parameter|opType=convert |parLabel=U Order |parName=orderu |parOrder=5 |parSummary=When converting to a spline type, this specifies the degree + 1 of the U or V basis function. Paste Coordinates * From Feature Surfaces - The resulting mesh will have the shape of the paste hierarchy (i.e. the top-most features will determine the shape). * From Base Surface - The resulting mesh will take the shape of the bottom-most surface. Paste Attributes * From Feature Surfaces - Each mesh point has the attributes of the top-most feature at that location. * From Base Surface - The resulting mesh will inherit the primitive attributes of the root surface (e.g. the material), and the point attributes will be those of the root surface as well. By using base coordinates and feature attributes you are, in fact, pasting attributes onto the surface. |opFamily=SOP |parType=Int |parReadOnly= |parItems=}} {{Parameter|opType=convert |parLabel=V Order |parName=orderv |parOrder=6 |parSummary=When converting to a spline type, this specifies the degree + 1 of the U or V basis function. Paste Coordinates * From Feature Surfaces - The resulting mesh will have the shape of the paste hierarchy (i.e. the top-most features will determine the shape). * From Base Surface - The resulting mesh will take the shape of the bottom-most surface. Paste Attributes * From Feature Surfaces - Each mesh point has the attributes of the top-most feature at that location. * From Base Surface - The resulting mesh will inherit the primitive attributes of the root surface (e.g. the material), and the point attributes will be those of the root surface as well. By using base coordinates and feature attributes you are, in fact, pasting attributes onto the surface. |opFamily=SOP |parType=Int |parReadOnly= |parItems=}} {{Parameter|opType=convert |parLabel=Preserve Original |parName=new |parOrder=7 |parSummary=When checked, the original geometry will be retained along with the converted geometry. |opFamily=SOP |parType=Toggle |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|opType=convert |parLabel=Interpolate Through Hulls |parName=interphull |parOrder=8 |parSummary=This option applies to the conversion between polygonal faces and grids to NURBS and Bzier surfaces and curves. When selected, the resulting curves retain the same topology as the original polygon. When not selected, the polygon points are used as a hull to define the new curve or surface. |opFamily=SOP |parType=Toggle |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|opType=convert |parName=prtype |parLabel=Particle Type |parItems= {{ParameterItem|itemName=lines |parName=prtype |itemSummary=Each particle will be rendered as a 2-point line, with the length determined based on the particles velocity. If the particle has no velocity it will just be a single pixel in size. |itemLabel=Render as Lines |opFamily=SOP }}{{ParameterItem|itemName=pointprites |parName=prtype |itemSummary=For use with the [[Point Sprite MAT]]. Each particle is a square of pixels that always face the camera. The size of the square is determined by parameters in the Point Sprite and the pscale vertex/point attribute. The point sprites will have texture coordinates generated for them automatically also ((0,0) in the bottom left and (1,1) in the top right). |itemLabel=Render as Point Sprites |opFamily=SOP }} |parOrder=9 |parSummary=Selects how the particles are rendered. |opFamily=SOP |parType=Menu |parReadOnly=}} {{OPSection |sectionName=Notes |sectionSummary=Face to Surface Conversion - When converting from a set of polygons to a mesh, a single mesh will result only if [[Facet SOP]]. Otherwise, each polygon is converted individually into a mesh. In fact, any individual face can be converted to any surface. This is accomplished by cutting the face into three or four adjacent sections, and then creating a patch from them. |opFamily=SOP}} {{InputsPage |opFamily=SOP |opInputs={{OPInput |opFamily=SOP |inputIndex=0 |inputName= |inputSummary= }} }} {{InfoCHOPChannels |opFamily=SOP |opLabel=Convert |infoChannels=}} {{History }} {{SOPNavBox |opFamily=SOP }} {{#invoke:Category |list|SOPs}}

{{Summary |opFamily=SOP |opFilter=True |opType=copy |opLicense=Non-Commercial |opClass=copySOP_Class |short=The Copy SOP lets you make copies of the geometry of other SOPs and apply a transformation to each copy. |long=The Copy SOP lets you make copies of the geometry of other SOPs and apply a transformation to each copy. It also allows you to copy geometry to points on an input template. |opLabel=Copy |opCategories= }} {{ParameterPage |pageName=Copy |opFamily=SOP |pageSummary=Specifies a subset of template primitives from which to copy onto. Accepts patterns, as described in [[Pattern Matching]]. |items={{Parameter |opFamily=SOP |opType=copy |parName=sourcegrp |parSummary=Specifies a subset of input primitives to copy from.
