{{Summary |opClass=lsystemSOP_Class |opType=lsystem |opLicense=Non-Commercial |opLabel=LSystem |long=The Lsystem SOP implements L-systems (Lindenmayer-systems, named after Aristid Lindenmayer (1925-1989)), allow definition of complex shapes through the use of iteration. They use a mathematical language in which an initial string of characters is evaluated repeatedly, and the results are used to generate geometry. The result of each evaluation becomes the basis for the next iteration of geometry, giving the illusion of growth. You begin building an L-system by defining a sequence of rules which are evaluated to produce a new string of characters. Each character of the new string represents one command which affects an imaginary stylus, or "turtle". Repeating this process will grow your geometry. You can use L-systems to create things such as: * Create organic objects such as trees, plants, flowers over time. * Create animated branching objects such as lightning and snowflakes. The file can be read in from disk or from the web. Use http:// when specifying a URL. ===
The Algorithmic Beauty of Plants
=== The descriptions located here should be enough to get you started in writing your own L-system rules, however, if you have any serious interests in creating L-systems, you should obtain the book: The Algorithmic Beauty of Plants Przemyslaw Prusinkiewicz & Aristid Lindenmayer Springer-Verlag, New York, Phone: 212.460.1500 ISBN: 0-387-94676-4, 1996. which is the definitive reference on the subject. It contains a multitude of L-systems examples complete with descriptions of the ideas and theories behind modelling realistic plant growth. |opFilter=False |opFamily=SOP |short=The Lsystem SOP implements L-systems (Lindenmayer-systems, named after Aristid Lindenmayer (1925-1989)), allow definition of complex shapes through the use of iteration. |opCategories= }} {{ParameterPage |items= {{Parameter|opType=lsystem |parOrder=0 |parItems= {{ParameterItem|itemLabel=Skeleton |itemName=skel |parName=type |itemSummary=Creates wire frame geometry. This option is ideal for geometry that is stiff and jagged like lightning or snowflakes. It is also useful to reduce SOP cooking time. |opFamily=SOP }}{{ParameterItem|itemLabel=Tube |itemName=tube |parName=type |itemSummary=Creates tube geometry. This option can be used with solid geometry that would need smooth curves, like trees or shrubs. Parameters on the [[#Parameters - Tube Page|Tube Page]] are only enabled when this Type is selected. |opFamily=SOP }} |parLabel=Type |parName=type |parSummary=Provides two options for output geometry: |opFamily=SOP |parType=Menu |parReadOnly= }} {{Parameter|opType=lsystem |parOrder=1 |parLabel=Generations |parName=generations |parSummary=Determines the number of times to apply the rules to the initial string. This value controls the growth of the L-system. Place a time-based function here to animate the L-system growth. |opFamily=SOP |parType=Float |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|opType=lsystem |parOrder=2 |parLabel=Random Scale |parName=randscale |parSummary=Random Scale as a percentage. This will apply a random scale to the changing geometry's lengths, angles and thickness. |opFamily=SOP |parType=Float |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|opType=lsystem |parOrder=3 |parLabel=Random Seed |parName=randseed |parSummary=Random Seed for the SOP. This value can be used to select different sequences of random values. |opFamily=SOP |parType=Int |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|opType=lsystem |parOrder=4 |parLabel=Continuous Angles |parName=contangl |parSummary=Calculates the incremental angles of branches, if a non-integer generational value is used. If the Generations field is animating, this should be set to ensure smooth growth. |opFamily=SOP |parType=Toggle |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|opType=lsystem |parOrder=5 |parLabel=Continuous Length |parName=contlength |parSummary=Calculates the incremental lengths of the geometry points if a non-integer generational value is used. As with Continuous Angles, if the Generations field is animating, this should be set to ensure smooth, continuous growth. The Continuous Width field applies to tube thickness. |opFamily=SOP |parType=Toggle |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|opType=lsystem |parOrder=6 |parLabel=Continuous Width |parName=contwidth |parSummary=Calculates the incremental lengths of the geometry points if a non-integer generational value is used. As with Continuous Angles, if the Generations field is animating, this should be set to ensure smooth, continuous growth. The Continuous Width field applies to tube thickness. |opFamily=SOP |parType=Toggle |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|opType=lsystem |parOrder=7 |parLabel=Apply Color |parName=docolor |parSummary=Use a TOP to apply color to the L-system as it grows. |opFamily=SOP |parType=Toggle |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|opType=lsystem |parOrder=8 |parItems= |parLabel=Image File |parName=colormap |parSummary=Defines a TOP to use when the Apply Color button is selected. Also see the ` and # turtle operators. |opFamily=SOP |parType=TOP |parReadOnly= }} {{Parameter|opType=lsystem |parOrder=9 |parItems= {{ParameterItem|itemLabel="" |itemName=incu |parName=inc |itemSummary= |opFamily=SOP }}{{ParameterItem|itemLabel="" |itemName=incv |parName=inc |itemSummary= |opFamily=SOP }} |parLabel=UV Increment |parName=inc |parSummary=Defines the default color U, V index increments when the turtle symbols ` or # are used. |opFamily=SOP |parType=UV |parReadOnly= }} {{Parameter|opType=lsystem |parOrder=10 |parLabel=Point Width Attribute |parName=pointwidth |parSummary=Adds a point width attribute to each point in the geometry. This width is effected by the Thickness and Thickness Scale parameters on the Tube Page. |opFamily=SOP |parType=Toggle |parReadOnly= |parItems=}} |pageName=Geometry |opFamily=SOP |pageSummary= }} {{ParameterPage |items= {{Parameter|opType=lsystem |parOrder=0 |parLabel=Rows |parName=rows |parSummary=The first option sets the number of tube sides and the second sets the number of divisions per step length if tube geometry is selected. |opFamily=SOP |parType=Int |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|opType=lsystem |parOrder=1 |parLabel=Columns |parName=cols |parSummary=The first option sets the number of tube sides and the second sets the number of divisions per step length if tube geometry is selected. |opFamily=SOP |parType=Int |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|opType=lsystem |parOrder=2 |parLabel=Tension |parName=tension |parSummary=Tension defines the smoothness of branching corners. |opFamily=SOP |parType=Float |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|opType=lsystem |parOrder=3 |parLabel=Branch Blend |parName=smooth |parSummary=Enabling this option allows a child branch to be continuously joined to its parent branch. |opFamily=SOP |parType=Float |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|opType=lsystem |parOrder=4 |parLabel=Thickness |parName=thickinit |parSummary=This number defines the default tube thickness. |opFamily=SOP |parType=Float |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|opType=lsystem |parOrder=5 |parLabel=Thickness Scale |parName=thickscale |parSummary=This number is the scale factor used with the ! or ? operator. |opFamily=SOP |parType=Float |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|opType=lsystem |parOrder=6 |parLabel=Apply Tube Texture Coordinates |parName=dotexture |parSummary=When enabled, UV texture coordinates are applied to the tube segments, such that the texture wraps smoothly and continuously over branches. |opFamily=SOP |parType=Toggle |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|opType=lsystem |parOrder=7 |parLabel=Vertical Increment |parName=vertinc |parSummary=Defines the vertical spacing of texture coordinates over tube geometry when tube texture is applied. |opFamily=SOP |parType=Float |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} |pageName=Tube |opFamily=SOP |pageSummary=The parameters on this page are active only if [[#Parameters - Geometry Page|Geometry Page]] > Type has been set to the Tube type. }} {{ParameterPage |items= {{Parameter|opType=lsystem |parOrder=0 |parLabel=Step Size |parName=stepinit |parSummary=Step Size allows you to define the default length of the edges when new geometry is generated. |opFamily=SOP |parType=Float |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|opType=lsystem |parOrder=1 |parLabel=Step Size Scale |parName=stepscale |parSummary=Step Size Scale defines the scale by which the geometry will be modified by the " or _ (double quote, or underscore) turtle operators. |opFamily=SOP |parType=Float |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|opType=lsystem |parOrder=2 |parLabel=Angle |parName=angleinit |parSummary=Angle defines the default turning angle for turns, rolls and pitches. |opFamily=SOP |parType=Float |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|opType=lsystem |parOrder=3 |parLabel=Angle Scale |parName=anglescale |parSummary=Angle Scale allows you to enter the scaling factor to be employed when the ; or @ operators are used. |opFamily=SOP |parType=Float |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|opType=lsystem |parOrder=4 |parLabel=Variable b |parName=varb |parSummary=Substitutes user-defined b, c and d variables in rules or premise. These variables are expanded and so may include system variables such as $F and $T. |opFamily=SOP |parType=Float |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|opType=lsystem |parOrder=5 |parLabel=Variable c |parName=varc |parSummary=Substitutes user-defined b, c and d variables in rules or premise. These variables are expanded and so may include system variables such as $F and $T. |opFamily=SOP |parType=Float |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|opType=lsystem |parOrder=6 |parLabel=Variable d |parName=vard |parSummary=Substitutes user-defined b, c and d variables in rules or premise. These variables are expanded and so may include system variables such as $F and $T. |opFamily=SOP |parType=Float |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|opType=lsystem |parOrder=7 |parLabel=Gravity |parName=gravity |parSummary=This parameter determines the amount of gravity applied to the geometry via the T (tropism vector) turtle operator. '''Tropism''' is when a plant bends or curves in response to an external stimulus. L-systems employ a tropism vector to simulate this behaviour. The bending is characterised by the fact that the thicker or shorter parts bend less than the longer or thinner parts. |opFamily=SOP |parType=Float |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} |pageName=Values |opFamily=SOP |pageSummary= }} {{ParameterPage |items= {{Parameter|opType=lsystem |parOrder=0 |parItems= |parLabel=Pic Image TOP |parName=pictop |parSummary=This is the TOP which the pic() function uses. See [[#Expressions L-system Specific Expression Functions]] below. |opFamily=SOP |parType=TOP |parReadOnly= }} {{Parameter|opType=lsystem |parOrder=1 |parLabel=Group Prefix |parName=grpprefix |parSummary=If the production g(n) is encountered, all subsequent geometry is included in a primitive group prefixed with this label and ending with the ascii value of n. See [[#CreateGroup Creating Groups within L-systems]] below for an example. |opFamily=SOP |parType=Str |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|opType=lsystem |parOrder=2 |parLabel=Channel Prefix |parName=chanprefix |parSummary=If the expression chan(n) is encountered, it is replaced with the local channel prefixed with this label and ending with the ascii value of n. |opFamily=SOP |parType=Str |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|opType=lsystem |parOrder=3 |parLabel=Leaf Param A |parName=stampa |parSummary=You can determine which parameters are used by leaves.
See [[#CreateGroup Creating Groups within L-systems]] below for an example. |opFamily=SOP |parType=Str |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|opType=lsystem |parOrder=4 |parLabel=Leaf Param B |parName=stampb |parSummary=You can determine which parameters are used by leaves.
See [[#CreateGroup Creating Groups within L-systems]] below for an example. |opFamily=SOP |parType=Str |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|opType=lsystem |parOrder=5 |parLabel=Leaf Param C |parName=stampc |parSummary=You can determine which parameters are used by leaves.
See [[#CreateGroup Creating Groups within L-systems]] below for an example. |opFamily=SOP |parType=Str |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|opType=lsystem |parOrder=6 |parLabel=Rules DAT |parName=rules |parSummary=Path to the DAT defining the rules for the LSystem. *Context Ignore context_ignore: - Defining this in the Rules DAT specifies all characters which are to be skipped when testing context sensitivity in the rules below. *Premise premise: - Define an initial string of characters to which the substitution rules are applied. *Rules - This is where the turtle substitution rules are defined. |opFamily=SOP |parType=DAT |parReadOnly= |parItems=}} |pageName=Funcs |opFamily=SOP |pageSummary=The parameters on this page allow you to stamp your leaf geometry (each copy can be different) as opposed to simply copying them. See the example in [[#Example - Stamping L-system Leaves|Example - Stamping L-system Leaves]]. }} {{OPSection |sectionName=Rule Substitution |sectionSummary=You create the highly structured organic and branching objects using L-systems grammar. An L-system is a process in which a sequence of rules are applied to an initial string of characters to create a new string. To build the geometry, each character of the final string represents one command which affects an imaginary stylus, or "turtle". The process begins by examining the first character of the premise string. All sixteen rules are searched sequentially until an applicable rule is found. The current character is then replaced with one or more characters as defined by the rule. The remaining characters in the premise string are replaced in a similar fashion. The entire process is repeated once for each generation. |items= {{OPSubSection |opFamily=SOP |sectionName=Limitations to Rules |sectionSummary=* Polygon {} and branch [] operators can be nested 30 levels deep * Rules can be 256 characters in length * Variables can have up to 5 parameters * Up to 25 rules can be defined }} {{OPSubSection |opFamily=SOP |sectionName=Turtle Operators |sectionSummary=F Move forward (creating geometry) H Move forward half the length (creating geometry) G Move forward but don't record a vertex f Move forward (no geometry created) h Move forward a half length (no geometry created) J K M Copy geometry source J, K or M at the turtle's position
after rescaling and reorienting the geometry. T Apply tropism vector + Turn right - Turn left (minus sign) & Pitch up ^ Pitch down \ Roll clockwise / Roll counter-clockwise {{!}} Turn 180 degrees * Roll 180 degrees ~ Pitch / Roll / Turn random amount " Multiply current length ! Multiply current thickness ; Multiply current angle _ Divide current length (underscore) ? Divides current width @ Divide current angle ' Increment color index U (single quote) # Increment color index V % Cut off remainder of branch $ Rotate `up' towards the sun about heading [ Push turtle state (start a branch) ] Pop turtle state (end a branch) { Start a polygon . Make a polygon vertex } End a polygon g Create a new primitive group to which subsequent geometry is added }} |opFamily=SOP}} {{OPSection |sectionName=Production Rule Syntax |sectionSummary=A Touch L-system rule is specified as: ['''lc'''<] '''pred''' [>'''rc'''] [:'''cond''']='''succ''' [:'''prob'''] where: * '''lc''' - Optional left context * '''pred''' - predecessor symbol to be replaced * '''rc''' - Optional right context * '''cond''' - Condition expression (optional) * '''succ''' - Replacement string * '''prob''' - Probability of rule execution (optional) |items= {{OPSubSection |opFamily=SOP |sectionName=Context Sensitivity |sectionSummary=The most basic type of rule is: '''pred''' = '''succ''' In this case, a character is replaced with the characters of '''succ''' if, and only if, it matches '''pred'''. For example: Premise: ABC
Rule 1: B=DOG will result in ADOGC '''pred''' can only specify one letter, but left and right context symbols can be specified. The general syntax is ['''lc'''<] '''pred''' [>'''rc'''] = '''succ'''. '''For example:''' Premise: ABC
Rule 1: A<B=DOG again results in ADOGC because B is preceded by A. If the rule were: Z<B=DOG or B>A=DOG the rule would not be applied. }} |opFamily=SOP}} {{OPSection |sectionName=Parameter Symbols |sectionSummary=Each symbol can have up to five user-defined variables associated with it which can be referenced or assigned in expressions. Variables in the predecessor are instanced while variables in the successor are assigned. For example: The rule A(i, j) = A(i+1, j-1), will replace each A with a new A in which the first parameter has been incremented and the second parameter decremented. Note that the variables in the predecessor can also be referenced by the condition or probability portions of the rule. For example: The rule A(i):i<5 = A(i+1) A(i+1), will double each A a maximum of five times (assuming a Premise of A(0)).
Parameters assigned to geometric symbols (e.g. F, +, or !) are interpreted geometrically. For example: The rule F(i, j) = F(0.5*i, 2*j), will again replace each F with a new F containing modified parameters. In addition to this, the new F will now be drawn at half the length and twice the width. |opFamily=SOP}} {{OPSection |sectionName=Operator Override |sectionSummary=Normally turtle symbols use the current length/angle/thickness etc. to determine their effect. By providing a turtle operator with an explicit parameter, it will override the value normally used by the turtle operator. Override parameters for F, f, G, h, H take the form of:
F('''i''','''j''','''k''','''l''','''m''')
* '''i''' - Override Length. * '''j''' - Override Thickness. * '''k''' - Override # Tube Segments. * '''l''' - Override # Tube Rows. * '''m''' - User parameter. The '''k''' and '''l''' override parameters allow dynamic resolution of tube segments. |items= {{OPSubSection |opFamily=SOP |sectionName=Examples |sectionSummary='''F''' - Moves forward current length creating geometry. ''' H''' - Moves forward half current length creating geometry. '''F(i, j)''' - Moves forward a distance of i, creating geometry of thickness j. ''' H(i, j)''' - Move forward half the distance of i, creating geometry of thickness half of j. '''+''' - Turn by current angle amount.
''' ~''' - Rotate by random angle. '''+(i)''' - Turn by i degrees.
''' ~(i)''' - Override random angle with value of i. '''$(x0,y0,z0)''' - Points the turtle to location (x0,y0,z0). Given the above, the Premise:
F(1) +(90) F(1) +(90) F(1) +(90) F(1)
generates a unit box regardless of the default Step Size or Angle settings. }} {{OPSubSection |opFamily=SOP |sectionName=List of Operator Overrides |sectionSummary=The following list describes the geometric interpretation of parameters assigned to certain turtle symbols: [[Image:TouchGeometry84.gif]] [[Image:TouchGeometry93.gif]] [[Image:TouchGeometry98.gif]] }} |opFamily=SOP}} {{OPSection |sectionName=Edge Rewriting |sectionSummary=In The Algorithmic Beauty of Plants, many examples use a technique called Edge Rewriting which involve left and right subscripts. A typical example might look like: Generations 10
Angle 90
Premise F(l)
Rules
F(l) = F(l)+F(r)+
F(r) = -F(l)-F(r) However, Touch doesn't know what F(l) and F(r) are. In this case, we can modify the rules to use parameter passing. For the F turtle symbol, the first four parameters are length, width, tubesides, and tubesegs, leaving the last parameter user-definable. We can define this last parameter such that 0 is left, and 1 is right: Generations 10
Angle 90
Premise F(1,1,3,3,0)
Rules After two generations this produces: Fl+Fr+-Fl-Fr. There should not be any difference between this final string and F+F+-F-F. Another approach is to use two new variables, and use a conditional statement on the final step to convert them to F: Variable b ch("generations")
Premise l
Rules
l:t<b=l+r+
r:t<b=-l-r
l=F
r=F
'''Output''' l
F
F+F+
F+F++-F-F+ |opFamily=SOP}} {{OPSection |sectionName=Expressions |sectionSummary=In the earlier example, the expressions 0.5*i and 2*j are used. In fact, expressions can be used anywhere a numeric field is expected. Currently the following symbols can be used in expressions: ( ) - brackets for nesting priority ^ + - * / % - arithmetic operators min() max() sin() cos() asin() acos() pic() in() - supported functions == != = < <= > >= - logical operators & {{!}} ! - logical operators: and, or, not b c d - SOP b, c, d parameters after expansion x y z - current turtle position g - age of symbol t - time (generations) of L-system a - SOP angle parameter T - SOP tropism (gravity) parameter The pre-defined variables above should not be used in the arguments of the predecessor. '''For example:''' A(a,b) = B(a*2,b*2) is wrong (a is the SOP Angle parameter). a<b (A,B) = b(A+1,B) is right. The last statement is correct because a and b are used as symbols and not variable names. A and B are correct because variable names are case sensitive. |items= {{OPSubSection |opFamily=SOP |sectionName=L-System Specific Expression Functions |sectionSummary=* '''pic(u, v, c)''' - Using the image specified with Pic Image File, this function returns a normalized value (between 0 and 1) of the pixel at the normalized coordinates (u,v); c selects one of four channels to examine:
0
1
2
3 * '''in(q, r, s)''' - Given a MetaTest input source containing a metaball geometry, this function returns a 1 if the point (q, r, s) is contained within the metaball, and 0 if not. Use in(x, y, z) (the letters x, y, and z are special and contain the X, Y, and Z location of the turtle) to test whether or not the turtle is currently inside the metaball to create pruned outputs. }} {{OPSubSection |opFamily=SOP |sectionName=Conditions |sectionSummary=Each rule may have an optional condition specified. The syntax is: [lc<] pred [>rc]:cond = succ '''For example:''' The Rule1 A:y>2=J includes source J at all A's above the height of 2. }} {{OPSubSection |opFamily=SOP |sectionName=Probability |sectionSummary=Each rule can specify the probability that it is used (provided it is otherwise applicable). The syntax is: [lc<] pred [>rc]:cond=succ=prob '''For example:''' Rule1 A=B:0.5
Rule2 A=C:0.5 will replace A with either B or C with equal probability. }} |opFamily=SOP}} {{OPSection |sectionName=Creating Groups with L-Systems |sectionSummary=There is a group operator ''''g'''' which lumps all geometry currently being built into group g. '''For example:''' g[F] lumps geometry from F into a group called lsys0. You can set the lsys prefix from the [[#Parameters - Funcs Page|Funcs page]]. |items= {{OPSubSection |opFamily=SOP |sectionName=Optional Group Parameters |sectionSummary=g takes an optional parameter as well. '''For example:''' g(1)[F] lumps geometry from f into a group called lsys1. If no parameter is given, the default index is bumped up appropriately. The current group container is pushed/popped with the turtle state so you can do things like:
gF [ gFF] F - The first and last F's are put into group 0, and the middle FF's are put into group 1.
gF [ FF] F - The geometry from all four F's are put into group 0, (pushing the turtle adopts the parent's group). To exclude the middle FF from the parent's group type: gF [ g(-1)FF ] F }} |opFamily=SOP}} {{OPSection |sectionName=Controlling the Length over Time |sectionSummary=To create an L-system which goes forward X percent less for each iteration, you need to start your Premise with a value, and then within a rule, multiply that value by the percentage you want to remain: Premise A(1)
Rule A(i) = F(i)A(i*0.5) This way "i" is scaled before A is again evaluated. The important part is the Premise. You need to start with a value to be able to scale that value. |opFamily=SOP}} {{OPSection |sectionName=Example |sectionSummary='''Step 1)''' Place a [[Circle SOP]], and set the Number of Divisions to: param("lsys", 3) It then displays a triangle (3 is default value). '''Step 2)''' Pipe this into the J input of a L-System SOP. If the L-system Premise is: J A
J(,,4) A
J(,,5) A This way, you can customize each leaf before it gets copied. '''Step 3)''' Change the Premise and Rule to: PremiseA(0)
Rule1A(i)=FJ(,,i+3)A(i+1) This creates a line of increasing-order polygons. '''Step 4)''' Finally, we will want to create 20 leaves, and put them all into a [[Switch SOP]]. Do this by entering the following expression into the Switch SOP's Select Input: param("lsys",0)
'''Step 5)''' Then in your L-system, J(,,0) gives you the first SOP, J(,,1) gives you the second, and so on. This solves the problem of a limited number of leaves using only JKM. Also note that these examples use only the first stamp parameter, you can use up to three parameters: e.g. J(,,1,2,3) The first two parameters of J, K, M are used to override length and width, like symbol F. |opFamily=SOP}} {{InputsPage |opFamily=SOP |opInputs={{OPInput |opFamily=SOP |inputIndex=0 |inputName= |inputSummary= }}{{OPInput |opFamily=SOP |inputIndex=1 |inputName= |inputSummary= }}{{OPInput |opFamily=SOP |inputIndex=2 |inputName= |inputSummary= }}{{OPInput |opFamily=SOP |inputIndex=3 |inputName= |inputSummary= }} }} {{InfoCHOPChannels |opFamily=SOP |opLabel=LSystem |infoChannels=}} {{History }} {{SOPNavBox |opFamily=SOP }} {{#invoke:Category |list|SOPs}}

{{Summary |opClass=magnetSOP_Class |opType=magnet |opLicense=Non-Commercial |opLabel=Magnet |long=The Magnet SOP allows you to affect deformations of the input geometry with another object using a "magnetic field" of influence, defined by a metaball field. It allows the creation of animated bumps and dents within objects, and other special effects. It is important to note that the actual deformation comes from the Translate parameters of the Magnet SOP, and not from the metaball. The metaball defines the area of effect for the Translate parameters of the Magnet SOP. The weight of the metaball determines the effectiveness of the Translate within the Magnet SOP. The power of the magnet is greatest at the centre of a metaball field and diminishes to nothing at the edge of the field. |opFilter=True |opFamily=SOP |short=The Magnet SOP allows you to affect deformations of the input geometry with another object using a "magnetic field" of influence, defined by a metaball field. |opCategories= }} {{ParameterPage |pageName= |opFamily=SOP |pageSummary= |items= {{Parameter|opType=magnet |parOrder=0 |parItems= |parLabel=Deform Group |parName=deformgrp |parSummary=Allows you to specify a group of geometry to be deformed, and a group that will act as the magnet respectively. Accepts patterns, as described in [[Pattern Matching]]. |opFamily=SOP |parType=StrMenu |parReadOnly= }} {{Parameter|opType=magnet |parOrder=1 |parItems= |parLabel=Magnet Group |parName=magnetgrp |parSummary=Allows you to specify a group of geometry to be deformed, and a group that will act as the magnet respectively. Accepts patterns, as described in [[Pattern Matching]]. |opFamily=SOP |parType=StrMenu |parReadOnly= }} }} {{ParameterPage |items= {{Parameter|opType=magnet |parOrder=0 |parItems= {{ParameterItem|itemLabel=Scale Rotate Translate |itemName=srt |parName=xord |itemSummary= |opFamily=SOP }}{{ParameterItem|itemLabel=Scale Translate Rotate |itemName=str |parName=xord |itemSummary= |opFamily=SOP }}{{ParameterItem|itemLabel=Rotate Scale Translate |itemName=rst |parName=xord |itemSummary= |opFamily=SOP }}{{ParameterItem|itemLabel=Rotate Translate Scale |itemName=rts |parName=xord |itemSummary= |opFamily=SOP }}{{ParameterItem|itemLabel=Translate Scale Rotate |itemName=tsr |parName=xord |itemSummary= |opFamily=SOP }}{{ParameterItem|itemLabel=Translate Rotate Scale |itemName=trs |parName=xord |itemSummary= |opFamily=SOP }} |parLabel=Transform Order |parName=xord |parSummary=Sets the overall transform order for the transformations. The transform order determines the order in which transformations take place. Depending on the order, you can achieve different results using the exact same values. Choose the appropriate order from the menu. |opFamily=SOP |parType=Menu |parReadOnly= }} {{Parameter|opType=magnet |parOrder=1 |parItems= {{ParameterItem|itemLabel=Rx Ry Rz |itemName=xyz |parName=rord |itemSummary= |opFamily=SOP }}{{ParameterItem|itemLabel=Rx Rz Ry |itemName=xzy |parName=rord |itemSummary= |opFamily=SOP }}{{ParameterItem|itemLabel=Ry Rx Rz |itemName=yxz |parName=rord |itemSummary= |opFamily=SOP }}{{ParameterItem|itemLabel=Ry Rz Rx |itemName=yzx |parName=rord |itemSummary= |opFamily=SOP }}{{ParameterItem|itemLabel=Rz Rx Ry |itemName=zxy |parName=rord |itemSummary= |opFamily=SOP }}{{ParameterItem|itemLabel=Rz Ry Rx |itemName=zyx |parName=rord |itemSummary= |opFamily=SOP }} |parLabel=Rotate Order |parName=rord |parSummary=Sets the order of the rotations within the overall transform order. |opFamily=SOP |parType=Menu |parReadOnly= }} {{Parameter|opType=magnet |parOrder=2 |parItems= {{ParameterItem|itemLabel=X |itemName=tx |parName=t |itemSummary= |opFamily=SOP }}{{ParameterItem|itemLabel=Y |itemName=ty |parName=t |itemSummary= |opFamily=SOP }}{{ParameterItem|itemLabel=Z |itemName=tz |parName=t |itemSummary= |opFamily=SOP }} |parLabel=Translate |parName=t |parSummary=These three fields move the Source geometry in the three axes. The Translates of the metaball only affect the position of the area of influence. The influence itself is provided by an imaginary magnet within the Magnet SOP itself, and the attitude of this influence is determined by the Translates of the Magnet SOP. '''Note:''' If the '''Translate''' values of the Magnet SOP are all zero, the magnet will have no deforming influence. The weight of the [[Metaball SOP]] scales the influence of the Magnet SOP's Translates. |opFamily=SOP |parType=XYZ |parReadOnly=}} {{Parameter|opType=magnet |parOrder=3 |parItems= {{ParameterItem|itemLabel=X |itemName=rx |parName=r |itemSummary= |opFamily=SOP }}{{ParameterItem|itemLabel=Y |itemName=ry |parName=r |itemSummary= |opFamily=SOP }}{{ParameterItem|itemLabel=Z |itemName=rz |parName=r |itemSummary= |opFamily=SOP }} |parLabel=Rotate |parName=r |parSummary=These three fields rotate the Source geometry in the three axes. |opFamily=SOP |parType=XYZ |parReadOnly= }} {{Parameter|opType=magnet |parOrder=4 |parItems= {{ParameterItem|itemLabel=X |itemName=sx |parName=s |itemSummary= |opFamily=SOP }}{{ParameterItem|itemLabel=Y |itemName=sy |parName=s |itemSummary= |opFamily=SOP }}{{ParameterItem|itemLabel=Z |itemName=sz |parName=s |itemSummary= |opFamily=SOP }} |parLabel=Scale |parName=s |parSummary=These three fields scale the input geometry in the three axes. |opFamily=SOP |parType=XYZ |parReadOnly= }} {{Parameter|opType=magnet |parOrder=5 |parItems= {{ParameterItem|itemLabel=X |itemName=px |parName=p |itemSummary= |opFamily=SOP }}{{ParameterItem|itemLabel=Y |itemName=py |parName=p |itemSummary= |opFamily=SOP }}{{ParameterItem|itemLabel=Z |itemName=pz |parName=p |itemSummary= |opFamily=SOP }} |parLabel=Pivot |parName=p |parSummary=The pivot point for the transformations. Not the same as the pivot point in the pivot channels. |opFamily=SOP |parType=XYZ |parReadOnly= }} |pageName=Deform |opFamily=SOP |pageSummary= }} {{ParameterPage |items= {{Parameter|opType=magnet |parOrder=0 |parLabel=Affect Position |parName=position |parSummary=Allow the magnet to affect the position of the input geometry. This is enabled by default. |opFamily=SOP |parType=Toggle |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|opType=magnet |parOrder=1 |parLabel=Affect Point Color |parName=color |parSummary=Allow the magnet to affect the point color of the input geometry. '''Tip:''' To control the contribution of each magnet on the surface's Point Color when the '''Affect Point Color''' option is enabled, set your point colors to black (0,0,0) before the Magnet SOP by using a [[Point SOP]]. The Translate fields in the Magnet SOP will then add per-point rgb color with values of 2,2,2 approaching white. The scale and rotate channels of the magnet move you about in 3D color space. This is not recommended. |opFamily=SOP |parType=Toggle |parReadOnly= |parItems=}} {{Parameter|opType=magnet |parOrder=2 |parLabel=Affect Point Normal |parName=nml |parSummary=Allow the magnet to affect the point normals of the input geometry. |opFamily=SOP |parType=Toggle |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|opType=magnet |parOrder=3 |parLabel=Affect Point Velocity |parName=velocity |parSummary=Allow the magnet to affect the velocity of the input geometry. |opFamily=SOP |parType=Toggle |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} |pageName=Attributes |opFamily=SOP |pageSummary= }} {{InputsPage |opFamily=SOP |opInputs={{OPInput |opFamily=SOP |inputIndex=0 |inputName= |inputSummary= }}{{OPInput |opFamily=SOP |inputIndex=1 |inputName= |inputSummary= }} }} {{InfoCHOPChannels |opFamily=SOP |opLabel=Magnet |infoChannels=}} {{History }} {{SOPNavBox |opFamily=SOP }} {{#invoke:Category |list|SOPs}}

{{Summary |long=The Metaball SOP creates metaballs and meta-superquadric surfaces. Metaballs can be thought of as spherical force fields whose surface is an implicit function defined at any point where the density of the force field equals a certain threshold. Because the density of the force field can be increased by the proximity of other metaball force fields, metaballs have the unique property that they change their shape to adapt and fuse with surrounding metaballs. This makes them very effective for modeling organic surfaces. For example, below we have a metaball. The surface of the metaball exists whenever the density of the metaball's field reaches a certain threshold: [[Image:MetaExample1.jpg]] When two or more metaball force fields are combined, as in the illustration below, the resulting density of the force fields is added, and the surface extends to include that area where the force fields intersect and create density values with a value of one. For more information on metaballs, see [[Metaball]]s. [[Image:MetaExample2.jpg]] {{OPSubSection |opFamily=SOP |sectionName=Level of Detail for Metaball Display |sectionSummary=You can change the level of detail of the metaball and NURBS display by adjusting the Level of Detail parameter in the Display Option Dialog > Viewport page > Level of Detail option. To open the Display Options Dialog, press "p" in a SOP viewport. }} {{OPSubSection |opFamily=SOP |sectionName=Better Metaball Shading Tip |sectionSummary=Accurate metaball normals will be computed if the normal attribute exists when conversion to polygons is done. Thus, to get improved shading on polygonized metaballs, it's a good idea to add the normal attribute (i.e. use a [[Facet SOP]]) before converting the metaballs. }} |opLabel=Metaball |opLicense=Non-Commercial |opFamily=SOP |short=The Metaball SOP creates metaballs and meta-superquadric surfaces. |opType=metaball |opFilter=False |opClass=metaballSOP_Class |opCategories= }} {{ParameterPage |pageName= |opFamily=SOP |pageSummary= |items= {{Parameter|parOrder=0 |parSummary=Available only when an input is connected to the Metaball SOP to set bounds for the metaball. When Modify Bounds = On the transform parameters below will further modify the position and radius of the bounds. |parLabel=Modify Bounds |opType=metaball |opFamily=SOP |parName=modifybounds |parType=Toggle |parReadOnly= |parItems=}} {{Parameter|parOrder=1 |parSummary=Controls the radius of the metaball field. |parLabel=Radius |opType=metaball |opFamily=SOP |parItems= {{ParameterItem|itemSummary= |itemLabel=X |opFamily=SOP |parName=rad |itemName=radx }}{{ParameterItem|itemSummary= |itemLabel=Y |opFamily=SOP |parName=rad |itemName=rady }}{{ParameterItem|itemSummary= |itemLabel=Z |opFamily=SOP |parName=rad |itemName=radz }} |parName=rad |parType=XYZ |parReadOnly= }} {{Parameter|parOrder=2 |parSummary=Metaball center in X, Y and Z. |parLabel=Center |opType=metaball |opFamily=SOP |parItems= {{ParameterItem|itemSummary= |itemLabel=X |opFamily=SOP |parName=t |itemName=tx }}{{ParameterItem|itemSummary= |itemLabel=Y |opFamily=SOP |parName=t |itemName=ty }}{{ParameterItem|itemSummary= |itemLabel=Z |opFamily=SOP |parName=t |itemName=tz }} |parName=t |parType=XYZ |parReadOnly= }} {{Parameter|parOrder=3 |parSummary=Defines the weight of the Metaball iso-surface within metaball field. An increase in weight makes the density of the metaball greater, and thus the defined implicit surface of it and surrounding metaballs will be enlarged. |parLabel=Weight |opType=metaball |opFamily=SOP |parName=metaweight |parType=Float |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|parOrder=4 |parSummary=There are four different metaball interpretations: Wyvill, Elendt, Blinn and Links. See the [[:Category:Geometry|Geometry]] articles for illustrations of the differences between these. |parLabel=Kernel Function |opType=metaball |opFamily=SOP |parItems= |parName=kernel |parType=StrMenu |parReadOnly= }} {{Parameter|parOrder=5 |parSummary=The XY Exponent determines inflation / contraction in the X and Y axes. |parLabel=XY Exponent |opType=metaball |opFamily=SOP |parName=expxy |parType=Float |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|parOrder=6 |parSummary=The Z Exponent determines inflation / contraction in the Z axis. |parLabel=Z Exponent |opType=metaball |opFamily=SOP |parName=expz |parType=Float |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|parOrder=7 |parSummary=Creates normals on the geometry. |parLabel=Compute Normals |opType=metaball |opFamily=SOP |parName=normals |parType=Toggle |parReadOnly= |parItems=}} {{OPSubSection |opFamily=SOP |sectionName=What is an Exponent? |sectionSummary=In the instance of metaballs, the exponent determines the inflation towards "squarishness" or contraction towards "starishness" as described below: * Value > 1 - Results in metaballs that appear more like a "star". * Value < 1 - Results in metaballs that appear more "squarish". * Value = 1 - Results in metaballs that appear spherical. }} }} {{InputsPage |opFamily=SOP |opInputs={{OPInput |opFamily=SOP |inputIndex=0 |inputName= |inputSummary= }} }} {{InfoCHOPChannels |opFamily=SOP |opLabel=Metaball |infoChannels=}} {{History }} {{SOPNavBox |opFamily=SOP }} {{#invoke:Category |list|SOPs}}

		|parName=period	
		|parSummary=The approximate separation between peaks of a noise cycle. It is expressed in Units. Increasing the period stretches the noise pattern out.	
			
Period is the opposite of frequency. If the period is 2 seconds, the base frequency is 0.5 cycles per second, or 0.5Hz for short. Hz refers to Hertz, the electrical and audio engineer of the 19th century, not the car guy.			
			
If the Type is set to Random, setting this to zero will produce completely random noise. Otherwise, the period should be greater than zero.

	{{Parameter|opType=noise	
		|parOrder=5	
		|parLabel=Harmonics	
		|parName=harmon	
		|parSummary=The number of higher frequency components to layer on top of the base frequency. The higher this number, the bumpier the noise will be (as long as roughness is not set to zero). 0 Harmonics give the base shape.	
			
Harmonics with a base frequency of 0.1Hz will by default produce harmonics at 0.2Hz, 0.4Hz, 0.8Hz, etc. (up to the number of harmonics specified by the Harmonics parameter).			
		|opFamily=SOP	
	|parType=Int
	|parReadOnly=	
		|parItems=}}		
	{{Parameter|opType=noise	
		|parOrder=6	
		|parLabel=Harmonic Spread	
		|parName=spread	
		|parSummary=The factor by which the frequency of the harmonics are increased. It is normally 2. A spread of 3 and a base frequency of 0.1Hz will produce harmonics at 0.3Hz, 0.9Hz, 2.7Hz, etc.. This parameter is only valid for the Harmonic Summation type.	
		|opFamily=SOP	
	|parType=Float
	|parReadOnly=	
		|parItems=	
		}}		
	{{Parameter|opType=noise	
		|parOrder=7	
		|parLabel=Roughness	
		|parName=rough	
		|parSummary=Controls the effect of the higher frequency noise. When Roughness is zero, all harmonics above the base frequency have no effect. At one, all harmonics are equal in amplitude to the base frequency. When Roughness is between one and zero, the amplitude of higher harmonics drops off exponentially from the base frequency.	
			
The default roughness is 0.5. This means the amplitude of the first harmonic is 0.5 of the base frequency, the second is 0.25, the third is 0.125. The harmonics are added to the base to give the final shape. The Harmonics parameter and the Roughness parameter must both be non-zero to see the harmonic effects.			
			
		|opFamily=SOP	
	|parType=Float
	|parReadOnly=	
		|parItems=}}		
	{{Parameter|opType=noise	
		|parOrder=8	
		|parLabel=Exponent	
		|parName=exp	
		|parSummary=Pushes the noise values toward 0, or +1 and -1. (It raises the value to the power of the exponent.) Exponents greater than one will pull the channel toward zero, and powers less than one will pull peaks towards +1 and -1. It is used to reshape the channels.	
		|opFamily=SOP	
	|parType=Float
	|parReadOnly=	
		|parItems=	
		}}		
	{{Parameter|opType=noise	
		|parOrder=9	
		|parLabel=Number of Integrals	
		|parName=numint	
		|parSummary=Defines the number of times to integrate (see the [[Speed CHOP]]) the Brownian noise. Higher values produce smoother curves with fewer features. Values beyond 4 produce somewhat identical curves. This parameter is only valid for the Random noise type.	
		|opFamily=SOP	
	|parType=Int
	|parReadOnly=	
		|parItems=	
		}}		
	{{Parameter|opType=noise	
		|parOrder=10	
		|parLabel=Amplitude	
		|parName=amp	
		|parSummary=Defines the noise value's amplitude (a scale on the values output).	
		|opFamily=SOP	
	|parType=Float
	|parReadOnly=	
		|parItems=	
		}}		
	{{Parameter|opType=noise	
		|parOrder=11	
		|parLabel=Keep Computed Normals	
		|parName=keepnormals	
		|parSummary=	
		|opFamily=SOP	
	|parType=Toggle
	|parReadOnly=	
		|parItems=}}

	|pageName=Transform		
	|opFamily=SOP		
	|pageSummary=The Translate, Rotate, Scale and Pivot parameters let you sample in a different part of the 3D noise space. Imagine a different noise value for every XYZ point in space. Normally, the Noise SOP samples the noise space from (0,0,0) along the X-axis in steps of 2/period.		
			
By changing the transform, you are translating, rotating and scaling the line along which the Noise SOPs samples the noise space. A slight Y-rotation is like walking in a straight path in the mountains, recording your altitude along the way, then re-starting from the same initial location, walking in a slightly different direction. Your altitude starts off being similar but then diverges.			
}}

{{Summary |opClass=particleSOP_Class |opType=particle |opLicense=Non-Commercial |opLabel=Particle |long=The Particle SOP is used for creating and controlling motion of "particles" for particle systems simulations. Particle systems are often used to create simulations of natural events such as rain and snow, or effects such as fireworks and sparks. In Touch, the points of the input geometry are used as the starting positions of the particles. Each point of the input can be affected by external force (gravity) and wind. Particles can collide and bounce off another object, set by the Collision Source. They can also bounce off, or die at, limit planes set in X, Y and Z. Particles are created with an initial velocity/direction that comes from the source geometry’s point normals, and that velocity can be controlled by modifying the normals using, for instance, a [[Point SOP]], [[Facet SOP]] or [[Script SOP]]. A point with a Normal of magnitude 1 emit bear particles with a velocity of 1 unit per second in the direction of the normal. Particles have various [[Attribute]]s that regular geometry do not have, such as velocity, life expectancy and age. These attributes must be carried with each point in order to carry out the simulation. The fourth input is Surface Attractors that cause the particles to be attached to areas of a surface. Each particle's id is used to determine a random target primitive, and random u,v on that primitive. That target position is used to modify the current velocity. |opFilter=True |opFamily=SOP |short=The Particle SOP is used for creating and controlling motion of "particles" for particle systems simulations. |opCategories= }} {{ParameterPage |pageName= |opFamily=SOP |pageSummary= |items= {{Parameter|opType=particle |parOrder=0 |parItems= |parLabel=Source Group |parName=sourcegrp |parSummary=Limit the particle emission to the points found in the specified point groups. |opFamily=SOP |parType=StrMenu |parReadOnly=}} }} {{ParameterPage |items= {{Parameter|opType=particle |parOrder=0 |parItems= {{ParameterItem|itemLabel=Render as Lines |itemName=lines |parName=prtype |itemSummary=Each particle will be rendered as a 2-point line, with the length determined based on the particles velocity. If the particle has no velocity it will just be a single pixel in size. |opFamily=SOP }}{{ParameterItem|itemLabel=Render as Point Sprites |itemName=pointprites |parName=prtype |itemSummary=For use with the [[Point Sprite MAT]]. Each particle is a square of pixels that always face the camera. The size of the square is determined by parameters in the Point Sprite and the pscale vertex/point attribute. The point sprites will have texture coordinates generated for them automatically also ((0,0) in the bottom left and (1,1) in the top right). |opFamily=SOP }} |parLabel=Particle Type |parName=prtype |parSummary=Selects how the particles are rendered. |opFamily=SOP |parType=Menu |parReadOnly= }} {{Parameter|opType=particle |parOrder=1 |parItems= {{ParameterItem|itemLabel=Particle System |itemName=psystem |parName=behave |itemSummary=Act like a particle system, where particles are born from the input points. |opFamily=SOP }}{{ParameterItem|itemLabel=Modify Source Geometry |itemName=modify |parName=behave |itemSummary=Deforms the source input geometry. '''Tip:''' You can also instance geometry to particles. Use a [[SOP to CHOP]] to get the particle positions into CHOPs, and on the Instance page of the [[Geometry COMP]] to position any geometry at each particle positions. This is by far the most efficient way of animating many copies of geometry with a particle system. |opFamily=SOP }} |parLabel=Behavior |parName=behave |parSummary=Select between emitting particles from the geometry's points or deforming the original geometry using the Particle SOP's behavior. |opFamily=SOP |parType=Menu |parReadOnly=}} {{Parameter|opType=particle |parOrder=2 |parLabel=Compute Normals |parName=normals |parSummary=Creates normals on the geometry. Only used when Behaviour is set to Modify Source Geometry. |opFamily=SOP |parType=Toggle |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|opType=particle |parOrder=3 |parItems= {{ParameterItem|itemLabel=Reuse Points in Loop |itemName=loop |parName=ptreuse |itemSummary= |opFamily=SOP }}{{ParameterItem|itemLabel=Reuse First Available Point |itemName=unused |parName=ptreuse |itemSummary= |opFamily=SOP }}{{ParameterItem|itemLabel=Don't Reuse Points |itemName=none |parName=ptreuse |itemSummary= |opFamily=SOP }} |parLabel=Point Reuse |parName=ptreuse |parSummary=Decide how the internal memory for points is reused when a point needs to be created or when a point dies. |opFamily=SOP |parType=Menu |parReadOnly= }} {{Parameter|opType=particle |parOrder=4 |parLabel=Preroll Time |parName=timepreroll |parSummary=How many seconds of the simulation to bypass, after the reset time is reached. For example, if you put the number 33 into this field (and reset is at Tstart), frame one will show the simulation that was at a time of 33 seconds. In other words, the first thirty-two seconds have been bypassed, and the time at thirty-three seconds is shifted to frame one. The first thirty-two seconds must still be calculated in order to compute the status of the points, so you will notice some delay upon reset. |opFamily=SOP |parType=Float |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|opType=particle |parOrder=5 |parLabel=Time Inc |parName=timeinc |parSummary=The Time Inc parameter determines how often to cook the SOP. By default, this parameter is set to 1/$FPS. This means that the SOP will cook once for every frame. When complex dynamics are involved, the SOP may require more frequent cooking for increased mathematical accuracy. To get sub-frame accuracy in the cooking, set the Time Inc to something smaller than 1/$FPS. '''For example:''' Setting the Time Inc to 0.5/$FPS will mean that the SOP gets cooked twice for every frame. '''Note:''' Never set this parameter to be greater than 1/$FPS. |opFamily=SOP |parType=Float |parReadOnly= |parItems=}} {{Parameter|opType=particle |parOrder=6 |parLabel=Max Steps |parName=maxsteps |parSummary=Limits how far back in time TouchDesigner calculates particle positions for proper interactions. If frame rates are slow this computation back in time can become high, this parameter limits that effect. |opFamily=SOP |parType=Int |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|opType=particle |parOrder=7 |parLabel=Jitter Births |parName=jitter |parSummary=This allows you to jitter the location pixels of each particle as they are born. |opFamily=SOP |parType=Toggle |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|opType=particle |parOrder=8 |parLabel=Accurate Moves |parName=accurate |parSummary=This option makes the particles move more accurately between frames by calculating their trajectories for fractional frame values. |opFamily=SOP |parType=Toggle |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|opType=particle |parOrder=9 |parLabel=Remove Unused Points |parName=rmunused |parSummary=Removes all unused points from the input geometry. This is provided as an explicit option instead of automatically because it saves the time needed to purge the points from memory during the simulation. This prevents unnecessary slowdowns during the simulation. |opFamily=SOP |parType=Toggle |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|opType=particle |parOrder=10 |parItems= {{ParameterItem|itemLabel=All Points |itemName=all |parName=attractmode |itemSummary=All point attractors affect all particles (or points). |opFamily=SOP }}{{ParameterItem|itemLabel=Single Point per Particle |itemName=single |parName=attractmode |itemSummary=When enabled, each particle is assigned a single attractor point, and is affected by only that point. Assignment is done by point number modulo the total number of attractor points. |opFamily=SOP }} |parLabel=Attractor Use |parName=attractmode |parSummary=Select which mode of attraction to use for Surface Attractors. |opFamily=SOP |parType=Menu |parReadOnly=}} {{Parameter|opType=particle |parOrder=11 |parLabel=Reset |parName=reset |parSummary=When On the particle system is held in a reset state and does not emit particles. |opFamily=SOP |parType=Toggle |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|opType=particle |parOrder=12 |parLabel=Reset Pulse |parName=resetpulse |parSummary=Instantly reset the particle system to its starting state. |opFamily=SOP |parType=Pulse |parReadOnly= |parItems=}} |pageName=State |opFamily=SOP |pageSummary= }} {{ParameterPage |items= {{Parameter|opType=particle |parOrder=0 |parItems= {{ParameterItem|itemLabel=X |itemName=externalx |parName=external |itemSummary= |opFamily=SOP }}{{ParameterItem|itemLabel=Y |itemName=externaly |parName=external |itemSummary= |opFamily=SOP }}{{ParameterItem|itemLabel=Z |itemName=externalz |parName=external |itemSummary= |opFamily=SOP }} |parLabel=External Force |parName=external |parSummary=Forces of gravity acting on the particles. When drag is zero, the particles can accelerate with no limit on their speed. |opFamily=SOP |parType=XYZ |parReadOnly= }} {{Parameter|opType=particle |parOrder=1 |parItems= {{ParameterItem|itemLabel=X |itemName=windx |parName=wind |itemSummary= |opFamily=SOP }}{{ParameterItem|itemLabel=Y |itemName=windy |parName=wind |itemSummary= |opFamily=SOP }}{{ParameterItem|itemLabel=Z |itemName=windz |parName=wind |itemSummary= |opFamily=SOP }} |parLabel=Wind |parName=wind |parSummary=Wind forces acting on the particles. Similar to External Force. Using Wind (and no other forces, such as Turbulence), the particles will not exceed the wind velocity. ====Discussion - Wind vs External Force==== The application of External Force directly affects a particles' acceleration, the rate of which is determined by the mass (F = Mass Acceleration). Wind is an additional force, but one that is velocity sensitive. If a particle is already travelling at wind velocity, then it shouldn't receive any extra force from it. This implies a maximum velocity when using Wind on its own. An increase in mass impedes acceleration for a given constant force. Drag is a force opposing the direction of motion which is velocity sensitive, i.e. the larger the velocity, the greater the effect of drag. Its useful for limiting the velocity of particles. |opFamily=SOP |parType=XYZ |parReadOnly=}} {{Parameter|opType=particle |parOrder=2 |parItems= {{ParameterItem|itemLabel=X |itemName=turbx |parName=turb |itemSummary= |opFamily=SOP }}{{ParameterItem|itemLabel=Y |itemName=turby |parName=turb |itemSummary= |opFamily=SOP }}{{ParameterItem|itemLabel=Z |itemName=turbz |parName=turb |itemSummary= |opFamily=SOP }} |parLabel=Turbulence |parName=turb |parSummary=The amplitude of turbulent (chaotic) forces along each axis. Use positive values, if any. |opFamily=SOP |parType=XYZ |parReadOnly= }} {{Parameter|opType=particle |parOrder=3 |parLabel=Turb Period |parName=period |parSummary=A small period means that the turbulence varies quickly over a small area, while a larger value will cause points close to each other to be affected similarly. |opFamily=SOP |parType=Float |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|opType=particle |parOrder=4 |parLabel=Seed |parName=seed |parSummary=Random number seed for the particle simulation. |opFamily=SOP |parType=Int |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} |pageName=Forces |opFamily=SOP |pageSummary= }} {{ParameterPage |items= {{Parameter|opType=particle |parOrder=0 |parLabel=Add Particle ID |parName=doid |parSummary=Adds an ID number to each particle as it is born. '''Note:''' New attributes only appear once the particle system is reset via the reset parameter or loads for first time. |opFamily=SOP |parType=Toggle |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|opType=particle |parOrder=1 |parLabel=Add Mass Attribute |parName=domass |parSummary=When selected, calculates the mass of the particle, as specified in the Mass field. |opFamily=SOP |parType=Toggle |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|opType=particle |parOrder=2 |parLabel=Mass |parName=mass |parSummary=The relative mass of each particle. Heavier particles take longer to start moving, and longer to slow down. |opFamily=SOP |parType=Float |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|opType=particle |parOrder=3 |parLabel=Add Drag Attribute |parName=dodrag |parSummary=When selected, calculates the drag coefficient of the particle, as entered in the Drag field. |opFamily=SOP |parType=Toggle |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|opType=particle |parOrder=4 |parLabel=Drag |parName=drag |parSummary=Drag of each particle. |opFamily=SOP |parType=Float |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|opType=particle |parOrder=5 |parLabel=Birth |parName=birth |parSummary=The number of particles born each second. Particles are not released in clusters. They are born at random times during the first frame of their existence. Their birth time is set randomly during the first frame. |opFamily=SOP |parType=Float |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|opType=particle |parOrder=6 |parLabel=Life Expect |parName=life |parSummary=How long each particle will exist, in seconds. The default is 3 seconds. You may want to adjust this number based on the length of your animation. |opFamily=SOP |parType=Float |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|opType=particle |parOrder=7 |parLabel=Life Variance |parName=lifevar |parSummary=Variance of a particle's life expectancy in seconds. If life expectancy is one second, and the variance is zero seconds, each particle will live exactly one second. If variance is set to 0.5, then some particles will live only a half second, while others will live a second and a half. The rest will live some time in-between. This randomness gives a more natural look to the particle births. |opFamily=SOP |parType=Float |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|opType=particle |parOrder=8 |parLabel=Alpha Speed |parName=alpha |parSummary=As a particle goes faster, it should become more transparent. The Alpha Speed parameter defaults to 0, which doesn't change alpha as the speed increases. A typical value of 0.5 causes the particle to be 70% opaque when it's going 1 unit/second. Increasing the Alpha Speed parameter makes it more transparent at a given speed. At zero speed, a particle is always 100% opaque. |opFamily=SOP |parType=Float |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} |pageName=Particles |opFamily=SOP |pageSummary= }} {{ParameterPage |items= {{Parameter|opType=particle |parOrder=0 |parItems= {{ParameterItem|itemLabel=X |itemName=limitposx |parName=limitpos |itemSummary= |opFamily=SOP }}{{ParameterItem|itemLabel=Y |itemName=limitposy |parName=limitpos |itemSummary= |opFamily=SOP }}{{ParameterItem|itemLabel=Z |itemName=limitposz |parName=limitpos |itemSummary= |opFamily=SOP }} |parLabel=+ Limit Plane |parName=limitpos |parSummary=The particles will die or bounce off the limit planes when it reaches them. The six limit plane fields define a bounding cube. The default settings are 1000 units away, which is very large. Reduce the values to about one to see the effect. |opFamily=SOP |parType=XYZ |parReadOnly= }} {{Parameter|opType=particle |parOrder=1 |parItems= {{ParameterItem|itemLabel=X |itemName=limitnegx |parName=limitneg |itemSummary= |opFamily=SOP }}{{ParameterItem|itemLabel=Y |itemName=limitnegy |parName=limitneg |itemSummary= |opFamily=SOP }}{{ParameterItem|itemLabel=Z |itemName=limitnegz |parName=limitneg |itemSummary= |opFamily=SOP }} |parLabel=- Limit Plane |parName=limitneg |parSummary=The particles will die or bounce off the limit planes when it reaches them. The six limit plane fields define a bounding cube. The default settings are 1000 units away, which is very large. Reduce the values to about one to see the effect. |opFamily=SOP |parType=XYZ |parReadOnly= }} {{Parameter|opType=particle |parOrder=2 |parItems= {{ParameterItem|itemLabel=Die on Contact |itemName=die |parName=hit |itemSummary=The particles will disappear when they collide with the Collision input. |opFamily=SOP }}{{ParameterItem|itemLabel=Bounce on Contact |itemName=bounce |parName=hit |itemSummary=The particles will bounce upon contact with the Collision input. |opFamily=SOP }}{{ParameterItem|itemLabel=Stick on Contact |itemName=stick |parName=hit |itemSummary=The particles will stick to the Collision input. |opFamily=SOP }} |parLabel=Hit Behavior |parName=hit |parSummary=Control over what happens when a particle hits either the six collision planes or the collide object. The options are: |opFamily=SOP |parType=Menu |parReadOnly= }} {{Parameter|opType=particle |parOrder=3 |parLabel=Gain Tangent |parName=gaintan |parSummary=Friction parameters which can be regarded as energy loss upon collision. The first parameter affects the energy loss (gain) perpendicular to the surface. 0 means all energy (velocity) is lost, 1 means no energy is lost perpendicular to surface. The second parameter is the energy gain tangent to the surface. |opFamily=SOP |parType=Float |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter|opType=particle |parOrder=4 |parLabel=Gain Normal |parName=gainnorm |parSummary=Friction parameters which can be regarded as energy loss upon collision. The first parameter affects the energy loss (gain) perpendicular to the surface. 0 means all energy (velocity) is lost, 1 means no energy is lost perpendicular to surface. The second parameter is the energy gain tangent to the surface. * 1 and 1 means nothing is lost or gained. * 0.1 and 1 cause the particles to strike the surface and dribble along it, like rain atop a roof. * 1 and 0 makes them bounce perpendicular to the surface, no matter what angle they came in at. * -1 and 1 makes the particle bounce back from whence it came. * Gains greater than 1 cause energy gain (like a pinball machine bumper). |opFamily=SOP |parType=Float |parReadOnly= |parItems=}} {{Parameter|opType=particle |parOrder=5 |parItems= {{ParameterItem|itemLabel=No Splitting |itemName=no |parName=splittype |itemSummary=The default setting, this keeps the particles intact. |opFamily=SOP }}{{ParameterItem|itemLabel=Split on Contact |itemName=bounce |parName=splittype |itemSummary=The particles will split upon contact with the Collision Source. |opFamily=SOP }}{{ParameterItem|itemLabel=Split on Death |itemName=die |parName=splittype |itemSummary=The particles will split when they die. |opFamily=SOP }} |parLabel=Split |parName=splittype |parSummary=Select if the particle will split and under what conditions. |opFamily=SOP |parType=Menu |parReadOnly=}} {{Parameter|opType=particle |parOrder=6 |parItems= {{ParameterItem|itemLabel="" |itemName=splitmin |parName=split |itemSummary= |opFamily=SOP }}{{ParameterItem|itemLabel="" |itemName=splitmax |parName=split |itemSummary= |opFamily=SOP }} |parLabel=Min/Max Splits |parName=split |parSummary=When a particle splits, it splits into a number of other particles. The number of particles is randomly set between this range. |opFamily=SOP |parType=Int |parReadOnly= }} {{Parameter|opType=particle |parOrder=7 |parItems= {{ParameterItem|itemLabel=X |itemName=splitvelx |parName=splitvel |itemSummary= |opFamily=SOP }}{{ParameterItem|itemLabel=Y |itemName=splitvely |parName=splitvel |itemSummary= |opFamily=SOP }}{{ParameterItem|itemLabel=Z |itemName=splitvelz |parName=splitvel |itemSummary= |opFamily=SOP }} |parLabel=Split Velocity |parName=splitvel |parSummary=Each split particle is given this base velocity. |opFamily=SOP |parType=XYZ |parReadOnly= }} {{Parameter|opType=particle |parOrder=8 |parItems= {{ParameterItem|itemLabel=X |itemName=splitvarx |parName=splitvar |itemSummary= |opFamily=SOP }}{{ParameterItem|itemLabel=Y |itemName=splitvary |parName=splitvar |itemSummary= |opFamily=SOP }}{{ParameterItem|itemLabel=Z |itemName=splitvarz |parName=splitvar |itemSummary= |opFamily=SOP }} |parLabel=Velocity Variance |parName=splitvar |parSummary=This is a random amount that is added to the split velocity. When creating fireworks, the variance is large while the velocity is low. When rendering raindrops splashing, the split velocity is large in Y, and the variance in X and Z causes the particles to bounce up - but randomly - in the XZ plane. |opFamily=SOP |parType=XYZ |parReadOnly= }} |pageName=Limits |opFamily=SOP |pageSummary= }} {{InputsPage |opFamily=SOP |opInputs={{OPInput |opFamily=SOP |inputIndex=0 |inputName= |inputSummary= }}{{OPInput |opFamily=SOP |inputIndex=1 |inputName= |inputSummary= }}{{OPInput |opFamily=SOP |inputIndex=2 |inputName= |inputSummary= }}{{OPInput |opFamily=SOP |inputIndex=3 |inputName= |inputSummary= }} }} {{InfoCHOPChannels |opFamily=SOP |opLabel=Particle |infoChannels=}} {{History }} {{SOPNavBox |opFamily=SOP }} {{#invoke:Category |list|SOPs}}

{{Summary |opClass=pointSOP_Class |opType=point |opLicense=Non-Commercial |opLabel=Point |long=The Point SOP allows you to get right into the geometry and manipulate the position, color, texture coordinates, and normals of the points in the Source, and other attributes. The Point SOP also lets you create custom point attributes. It is the complement to the [[Primitive SOP]]. Using a second input allows for combining of two SOPs using their respective expressions (see: [[PointSOP Class]]). If the second input has less points than the first input, the points in the second input will be cycled. For example, you can create point coloring, or flip the normals of incoming geometry. Using expressions in Position X, Y and Z, you can move any given input point to a new place as defined by the expression with any standard attributes. The Width (width) attribute affects the line width in the [[Line MAT]]. The Scale attribute (pscale) affects particle size, and in the [[Line MAT]] it affects the dot size at each point. '''Tip''': For greater flexibility, use the [[Script SOP]]. |opFilter=True |opFamily=SOP |short=The Point SOP allows you to get right down into the geometry and manipulate the position, color, texture coordinates, and normals of the points in the Source, and other attributes. |opCategories= }} {{ParameterPage |opFamily=SOP |pageName=Point |pageSummary= |items={{Parameter |opFamily=SOP |opType=pointSOP |parLabel=Group |parName=group |parType=StrMenu |parReadOnly= |parOrder=0 |parSummary=If there are input groups, specifying a group name in this field will cause this SOP to act only upon the group specified. Accepts patterns, as described in [[Pattern Matching]]. |parItems= }} {{Parameter |opFamily=SOP |opType=pointSOP |parLabel=Position |parName=t |parType=XYZ |parReadOnly= |parOrder=1 |parSummary=Expressions to translate the XYZ coordinates of a given point can be entered here. The attributes to modify here are: me.inputPoint.x, me.inputPoint.y and me.inputPoint.z. Simply entering me.inputPoint.x into the Position X field means that the X coordinate of each point that comes in is passed straight through with no modification. Changing this entry to me.inputPoint.x+5 means that the X coordinate of each point that comes in will be displaced by 5 units. This expression can be expanded to produce many useful effects. Transformations can also be effected in the Y and Z fields. |parItems={{ParameterItem |opFamily=SOP |parName=t |itemLabel=Position |itemName=tx |itemSummary= }}{{ParameterItem |opFamily=SOP |parName=t |itemLabel=Position |itemName=ty |itemSummary= }}{{ParameterItem |opFamily=SOP |parName=t |itemLabel=Position |itemName=tz |itemSummary= }} }} {{Parameter |opFamily=SOP |opType=pointSOP |parLabel=Weight |parName=doweight |parType=Menu |parReadOnly= |parOrder=2 |parSummary=Select between keeping the weight or adding a new weight. |parItems= {{ParameterItem |opFamily=SOP |parName=doweight |itemLabel=Keep Weight |itemName=off |itemSummary= }}{{ParameterItem |opFamily=SOP |parName=doweight |itemLabel=New Weight |itemName=on |itemSummary= }} }} {{Parameter |opFamily=SOP |opType=pointSOP |parLabel=Weight |parName=weight |parType=Float |parReadOnly= |parOrder=3 |parSummary=If you select 'New Weight' from the menu above, enter expressions here to control the values of the point weights here. The attribute to modify is: me.inputPoint.w. Values for the weight of the point can range from 0.0001 to infinity. |parItems= }} {{Parameter |opFamily=SOP |opType=pointSOP |parLabel=Color |parName=doclr |parType=Menu |parReadOnly= |parOrder=4 |parSummary=Select between keeping the color, adding new color, or using no color. |parItems={{ParameterItem |opFamily=SOP |parName=doclr |itemLabel=Keep Color |itemName=off |itemSummary= }}{{ParameterItem |opFamily=SOP |parName=doclr |itemLabel=Add Color |itemName=on |itemSummary= }}{{ParameterItem |opFamily=SOP |parName=doclr |itemLabel=No Color |itemName=remove |itemSummary= }} }} {{Parameter |opFamily=SOP |opType=pointSOP |parLabel=Color |parName=diff |parType=RGB |parReadOnly= |parOrder=5 |parSummary=If you select 'Add Color' from the menu above, Cd color attributes will be added/modified in the SOP. Enter expressions below to control the values of the point colors. The attributes to modify are: me.inputColor[0] for red, me.inputColor[1] for green, me.inputColor[2] for blue, and me.inputColor[3] for alpha. If you select 'No Color' from the menu above, the Cd color attribute will be removed from the SOP. |parItems= {{ParameterItem |opFamily=SOP |parName=diff |itemLabel=Color |itemName=diffr |itemSummary= }}{{ParameterItem |opFamily=SOP |parName=diff |itemLabel=Color |itemName=diffg |itemSummary= }}{{ParameterItem |opFamily=SOP |parName=diff |itemLabel=Color |itemName=diffb |itemSummary= }} }} {{Parameter |opFamily=SOP |opType=pointSOP |parLabel=Alpha |parName=alpha |parType=Float |parReadOnly= |parOrder=6 |parSummary=Control the alpha attribute in the same manner as the rgb colors above. Alpha is Cd[3] and comes from input via me.inputColor[3] |parItems= }} {{Parameter |opFamily=SOP |opType=pointSOP |parLabel=Normal |parName=donml |parType=Menu |parReadOnly= |parOrder=7 |parSummary=Select between keeping the normals, adding new normals, or using no normals. |parItems= {{ParameterItem |opFamily=SOP |parName=donml |itemLabel=Keep Normal |itemName=off |itemSummary= }}{{ParameterItem |opFamily=SOP |parName=donml |itemLabel=Add Normal |itemName=on |itemSummary= }}{{ParameterItem |opFamily=SOP |parName=donml |itemLabel=No Normal |itemName=remove |itemSummary= }} }} {{Parameter |opFamily=SOP |opType=pointSOP |parLabel=Normals |parName=n |parType=XYZ |parReadOnly= |parOrder=8 |parSummary=If you select 'Add Normal' from the menu above, N normal attributes will be added/modified in the SOP. Enter expressions to change a given point normal here. Point normals are directional vectors used by other SOPs, such as Turbulence, Facet and Copy. See [[Attributes]] article for detailed information. The attributes to modify are: me.inputNormal[0], me.inputNormal[1] and me.inputNormal[2]. If you select 'No Normal' from the menu above, the N normal attribute will be removed from the SOP. |parItems={{ParameterItem |opFamily=SOP |parName=n |itemLabel=Normals |itemName=nx |itemSummary= }}{{ParameterItem |opFamily=SOP |parName=n |itemLabel=Normals |itemName=ny |itemSummary= }}{{ParameterItem |opFamily=SOP |parName=n |itemLabel=Normals |itemName=nz |itemSummary= }} }} {{OPSubSection |opFamily=SOP |sectionName=Flipping Normals |sectionSummary=You can flip the point normals of incoming geometry by entering: (-me.inputNormal[0] -me.inputNormal[1] -me.inputNormal[2]) in the fields with this parameter set to Add Normals. This works, because it takes the existing normals (me.inputNormal[0] me.inputNormal[1] me.inputNormal[2]) and inverts them (the preceding - ). }} {{Parameter |opFamily=SOP |opType=pointSOP |parLabel=Texture |parName=douvw |parType=Menu |parReadOnly= |parOrder=9 |parSummary=Select between keeping the texture coordinates, adding new texture coordinates, or using no texture coordinates. |parItems= {{ParameterItem |opFamily=SOP |parName=douvw |itemLabel=Keep Texture |itemName=off |itemSummary= }}{{ParameterItem |opFamily=SOP |parName=douvw |itemLabel=Add Texture |itemName=on |itemSummary= }}{{ParameterItem |opFamily=SOP |parName=douvw |itemLabel=No Texture |itemName=remove |itemSummary= }} }} {{Parameter |opFamily=SOP |opType=pointSOP |parLabel=Texture |parName=map |parType=UVW |parReadOnly= |parOrder=10 |parSummary=If you select 'Add Texture' from the menu above, uv texture coordinate attributes will be added/modified in the SOP. Enter expressions here to control the values of the texture coordinates here. The attributes to modify are: me.inputTexture[0], me.inputTexture[1] and me.inputTexture[2]. If you select 'No Texture' from the menu above, the uv texture coordinate attribute will be removed from the SOP. |parItems={{ParameterItem |opFamily=SOP |parName=map |itemLabel=Texture |itemName=mapu |itemSummary= }}{{ParameterItem |opFamily=SOP |parName=map |itemLabel=Texture |itemName=mapv |itemSummary= }}{{ParameterItem |opFamily=SOP |parName=map |itemLabel=Texture |itemName=mapw |itemSummary= }} }} {{Parameter |opFamily=SOP |opType=pointSOP |parLabel=Width(Line MAT) |parName=dowidth |parType=Menu |parReadOnly= |parOrder=11 |parSummary=Select between keeping the width attribute or adding a new width. This Width (width) attribute is used exclusively with [[Line MAT]] to control line width when the material is rendered. |parItems= {{ParameterItem |opFamily=SOP |parName=dowidth |itemLabel=Keep Width |itemName=off |itemSummary= }}{{ParameterItem |opFamily=SOP |parName=dowidth |itemLabel=New Width |itemName=on |itemSummary= }} }} {{Parameter |opFamily=SOP |opType=pointSOP |parLabel=Width(Line MAT) |parName=width |parType=Float |parReadOnly= |parOrder=12 |parSummary=If you select 'New Width' from the menu above, width attribute will be added/modified in the SOP. Enter expressions here to control the values of the point widths here. The attribute to modify is: me.inputPoint.width[0]. |parItems= }} {{Parameter |opFamily=SOP |opType=pointSOP |parLabel=Scale |parName=dopscale |parType=Menu |parReadOnly= |parOrder=13 |parSummary=Select between keeping the scale attribute, adding new scale, or using no scale. This scale (pscale) attribute is used with the [[Particle SOP]] and acts as a multiplier for the size of particles. The value of this attribute is multiplied by the size specified in the [[Particle SOP]]'s render attributes to scale each particle. This attribute is used by the [[Point Sprite MAT]] when rendering point sprites. |parItems= {{ParameterItem |opFamily=SOP |parName=dopscale |itemLabel=Keep Scale |itemName=off |itemSummary= }}{{ParameterItem |opFamily=SOP |parName=dopscale |itemLabel=Add Scale |itemName=on |itemSummary= }}{{ParameterItem |opFamily=SOP |parName=dopscale |itemLabel=No Scale |itemName=remove |itemSummary= }} }} {{Parameter |opFamily=SOP |opType=pointSOP |parLabel=Scale |parName=pscale |parType=Float |parReadOnly= |parOrder=14 |parSummary=If you select 'Add Scale' from the menu above, pscale attribute will be added/modified in the SOP. Enter expressions here to control the values of the point particle scales here. The attribute to modify is: me.inputPoint.pscale[0]. If you select 'No Scale' from the menu above, the pscale attribute will be removed from the SOP. |parItems= }} }} {{ParameterPage |opFamily=SOP |pageName=Custom |pageSummary= |items= {{Parameter |opFamily=SOP |opType=pointSOP |parLabel=Custom Attrib 1 |parName=custom1 |parType=Str |parReadOnly= |parOrder=0 |parSummary=Creates a custom attribute with this name. |parItems= }} {{Parameter If you select 'No Velocity' from the menu above, the v velocity attribute will be removed from the SOP. |opFamily=SOP |parType=XYZ |parReadOnly= }} {{Parameter |opType=point |parOrder=9 |parItems={{ParameterItem |opFamily=SOP |parName=doup |itemLabel=Keep Up Vector |itemName=off |itemSummary= }}{{ParameterItem |opFamily=SOP |parName=doup |itemLabel=Add Up Vector |itemName=on |itemSummary= }}{{ParameterItem |opFamily=SOP |parName=doup |itemLabel=No Up Vector |itemName=remove |itemSummary= }} |parLabel=Up Vector |parName=doup |parSummary=Creates/Removes the "up" attribute for points. Enter expressions to change a given point up vector here. The attributes to modify here are: me.inputPoint.up[0], me.inputPoint.up[1] and me.inputPoint.up[2]. If you select 'No Up Vector' from the menu above, the up attribute will be removed from the SOP. |opFamily=SOP |parType=XYZ |parReadOnly= }} |pageName=Particle |opFamily=SOP |pageSummary= }} {{ParameterPage |items={{Parameter |opType=point |parOrder=0 |parItems= {{ParameterItem |opFamily=SOP |parName=doradius |itemLabel=Keep Radius |itemName=off |itemSummary= }}{{ParameterItem |opFamily=SOP |parName=doradius |itemLabel=Add Radius |itemName=on |itemSummary= }}{{ParameterItem |opFamily=SOP |parName=doradius |itemLabel=No Radius |itemName=remove |itemSummary= }} |parLabel=Radius |parName=doradius |parSummary=Retains, adds, or removes radiusf attributes for points, used to modify the distance roll-off effect. The roll-off is: r /(r+d^2) Where r is radius, and d is distance from attractor point. If no radius is set, no attenuation is performed. |opFamily=SOP |parType=Menu |parReadOnly= }} {{Parameter |opType=point |parOrder=1 |parLabel=Radius |parName=radiusf |parSummary=If you select 'Add Radius' from the menu above, radiusf attribute will be added/modified in the SOP. Enter expressions here to control the values of the distance roll-off here. If you select 'No Radius' from the menu above, the radiusf attribute will be removed from the SOP. |opFamily=SOP |parType=Float |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter |opType=point |parOrder=2 |parItems= {{ParameterItem |opFamily=SOP |parName=doscale |itemLabel=Keep F Scale |itemName=off |itemSummary= }}{{ParameterItem |opFamily=SOP |parName=doscale |itemLabel=Add F Scale |itemName=on |itemSummary= }}{{ParameterItem |opFamily=SOP |parName=doscale |itemLabel=No F Scale |itemName=remove |itemSummary= }} |parLabel=F Scale |parName=doscale |parSummary=Retains, adds, or removes scalef attributes for points, a multiplier for total force associated with this attractor point. Both Radius and Force Scale will default to 1 if not created as point attributes. '''Radial / Normal / Edge / Directional Force''' - These four parameters introduce a type of force when created and each has a corresponding multiplier associated with it. |opFamily=SOP |parType=Menu |parReadOnly= }} {{Parameter |opType=point |parOrder=3 |parLabel=F Scale |parName=scalef |parSummary=If you select 'Add F Scale' from the menu above, scalef attribute will be added/modified in the SOP. Enter expressions here to control the values of the force multiplier here. If you select 'No F scale' from the menu above, the scalef attribute will be removed from the SOP. |opFamily=SOP |parType=Float |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter |opType=point |parOrder=4 |parItems={{ParameterItem |opFamily=SOP |parName=doradialf |itemLabel=Keep Radial F |itemName=off |itemSummary= }}{{ParameterItem |opFamily=SOP |parName=doradialf |itemLabel=Add Radial F |itemName=on |itemSummary= }}{{ParameterItem |opFamily=SOP |parName=doradialf |itemLabel=No Radial F |itemName=remove |itemSummary= }} |parLabel=Radial F |parName=doradialf |parSummary=Retains, adds, or removes radialf attributes for points, the force directed towards the attractor point. If you select 'No Radial F' from the menu above, the radialf attribute will be removed from the SOP. |opFamily=SOP |parType=Float |parReadOnly= |parItems= }} {{Parameter |opType=point |parOrder=6 |parItems={{ParameterItem |opFamily=SOP |parName=donormalf |itemLabel=Keep Normal F |itemName=off |itemSummary= }}{{ParameterItem |opFamily=SOP |parName=donormalf |itemLabel=Add Normal F |itemName=on |itemSummary= }}{{ParameterItem |opFamily=SOP |parName=donormalf |itemLabel=No Normal F |itemName=remove |itemSummary= }} |parLabel=Normal F |parName=donormalf |parSummary=Retains, adds, or removes normalf attributes for points, the force directed along the point normal direction. |opFamily=SOP |parType=Menu |parReadOnly= }} {{Parameter |opType=point |parOrder=7 |parLabel=Normal F |parName=normalf |parSummary=If you select 'Add Normal F' from the menu above, normalf attribute will be added/modified in the SOP. {{Summary
	|opFamily=SOP
	|opType=polyreduceSOP
	|opLabel=Polyreduce
	|opClass=polyreduceSOP_Class
	|opFilter=True
	|opLicense=Non-Commercial
	|short=The Polyreduce SOP reduces a high detail polygonal model into one consisting of fewer polygons.
	|long=The Polyreduce SOP reduces a high detail polygonal model into one consisting of fewer polygons. The second input's polygons represent feature edges. They are matched to the input mesh by point numbers.	
		
The methods to reduce polygonal models are:		
		
* A percentage of their former size		
* A specfic number of polys (within a few)		
* According to distance from a camera		
		
Note that as it requires (and outputs) a triangular mesh, the polygon count may increase as a result of this operation.		
		
A second input for feature edges is provided.
	|opCategories=
	}}
